Move over Kate: TLC delivers two more broods

Author: Ryan, Andrew

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/move-over-kate-tlc-delivers-two-more-broods/docview/748065875/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Not long after the birth of their daughter, Eliot, they decided she needed a brother or sister, so they tried the same fertility procedure again. Nine months later, the family of three was a family of eight, and suddenly reality-TV cameras were all over the house. Ain't that America? But hey, it's a blessing. The quints arrived in January, 2009, and the [Ethan Jones] clan was first introduced in a Discovery Channel special titled

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Move+over+Kate%3A+TLC+delivers+two+more+broods&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-30&amp;spage=R.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Move+over+Kate%3A+TLC+delivers+two+more+broods&amp;author=Ryan%2C+Andrew&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-30&amp;spage=R.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: jaryan@globeandmail.com
There's an old adage in the publishing trade, attributed to William Randolph Hearst, that any magazine with a picture of a beautiful girl, a dog or a baby on the cover will be eagerly snapped up by the public. On television, all you need is the baby. Or several babies.
Quints by Surprise (TLC, 10 p.m.) is the newest entry in big-brood reality series designed to tug at viewer heartstrings. If only the Dionne quintuplets could have cashed in like this.
Naturally the new show originates from TLC, the U.S. cable channel that previously gave viewers such family-friendly fare as Jon & Kate Plus 8, 19 Kids and Counting, Table for 12 and Kids by the Dozen . Most likely Planned Parenthood canvassers give the TLC building a wide berth.
In this instance, viewers are introduced to a decent enough young Texan couple named Casey and Ethan Jones, who spent considerable time and money on fertility treatments to have a baby a few years back.
Not long after the birth of their daughter, Eliot, they decided she needed a brother or sister, so they tried the same fertility procedure again. Nine months later, the family of three was a family of eight, and suddenly reality-TV cameras were all over the house. Ain't that America? But hey, it's a blessing. The quints arrived in January, 2009, and the Jones clan was first introduced in a Discovery Channel special titled Too Many Babies?
Now the kids are at the 18-month stage and unbearably cuddly. Tonight's special is their coming-out party, of sorts, before the show settles into a regular Monday timeslot next week.
In some ways, it's amazing to see how far the multiple-bassinet genre has evolved in the few short years since Jon & Kate Plus 8 became a hit with viewers.
Tonight's introductory special naturally follows the quints tumbling around like cute little teddy bears at a picnic, but there's equal time devoted to the cold reality of having to pay for five tiny tots.
The concept does not shy away from the financial problems, and filming took place around the same time the real-estate market dropped in the Austin, Tex., area where they reside. Although their family is bursting at the seams, the Joneses are forced to sell their large home and downsize.
Big family shows are a narrow slice of the reality genre, of course, and regular viewers are already intimately familiar with the woes of the Gosselin clan, particularly their messy divorce.
There doesn't seem much likelihood of that happening in the Jones household. On first glance, Casey and Ethan appear to be solid, if slightly bewildered, life-partners, and fully devoted to launching these kids into the world. Like most parents, they're making it up as they go along.
As reality shows go, it feels more honest than the old Jon & Kate show, in case that matters. And there's more of the same coming soon.
Yes, it's true. TLC will expand its reality family even further with the upcoming series Sextuplets Take New York , which has a due date of Sept. 14.
The new arrival will follow the daily lives of Victor and Digna Carpio, a working-class couple raising cute-as-a-bug sextuplets - four boys, two girls - in downtown Queens, N.Y. In recent promos, TLC is deriving great mileage from the fact that the family is billed as America's first Latino sextuplets. Ay caramba .
Oh, and whatever happened to those eight Gosselin kids? The kids are a few years older now and the show has been transformed into a single-mom travelogue series called Kate Plus 8 (TLC, 9 p.m.).
Papa Jon seems to have disappeared into the ether, but Kate is still around and keeping her profile up to pay the bills. Last night, you may have noticed, she was working the red carpet for Entertainment Tonight . A single mom does what she has to these days. Check local listings.
John Doyle will return.
********
Also airing
Lie to Me (Fox, Global, 9 p.m.) recently switched to a later timeslot, which actually makes sense considering some of the storylines. In tonight's new episode, human lie-detector Cal Lightman (Tim Roth) ventures into the seamy adult-film industry to find a missing girl.
Dating in the Dark (ABC, CITY-TV, 10 p.m.) is still going on and still defies belief. Tonight, six of the remaining singles put on swimsuits to spend time together on a makeshift beach set in a pitch-black darkroom. As before, the infra-red footage makes them look like deer caught in the headlights.
A.R.

Full text: FRIDAY
AUGUST 27
DOCUMENTARY
In The Land
of Northern Lights
TVO, 7 p.m.
Joanna Lumley explores her inner wanderlust in this offbeat BBC documentary. Best known for her role as the hard-drinking fashion doyenne Patsy on Absolutely Fabulous , Lumley grew up in steamy Malaysia, so she never felt the cold embrace of winter as a child. Accompanied by a camera crew and experienced guides, Lumley heads off to the Arctic Circle in search of the famed Northern Lights. Travelling by dogsled and snowmobile, she cheerfully helps out a Sami herdsman look for his missing reindeer, but nobody prepared her for the -30 weather.
NEWS
Global Currents
Global, 8 p.m.
Week after week, this series has been delivering some of the best Canadian documentaries of recent memory. Tonight's chapter, titled Dads Who Fought Back , follows the emotional and acrimonious child custody battles of two desperate fathers. Their respective experiences have led them to believe the Canadian family-court system is biased against fathers. The program also follows the efforts of several activist groups who are working to change the seemingly antiquated system. FINANCE
Til Debt Do Us Part
Slice, 9 p.m.
Arguably the strongest show on Slice's nightly lineup, this series relies on the common-sense advice of financial planner Gail Vaz-Oxlade. Tonight, she comes to the rescue of Jeff and Tara, two young social workers who tend to the needs of others. Unfortunately, they also break the budget on over-the-top luxury weekends. . REALITY
UFO Hunters
OLN, 10 p.m.
The truth is still out there. Or so believes UFO enthusiast William J. Birnes and his team in this popular reality series. Tonight, they're off to Sonora, Calif., to investigate the increasing volume of sightings of large black triangles hovering in the sky. Local newspapers have dubbed the area "Triangle Alley." The scary part: Most of the sightings have been reported in the daytime!
SATURDAY
AUGUST 28
HISTORY
The Captain Bligh
Conspiracy: Revealed
History, 7 p.m.
History books have not been kind to Captain William Bligh. According to the events related in the novel Mutiny on the Bou nty , the captain of the HMS Bounty was a heartless bounder whose cruel treatment virtually forced his crew into declaring mutiny back in 1789. Led by Fletcher Christian, the mutineers set Bligh and those loyal to him afloat in a small boat, then sailed off to spend their lives on the tropical paradise of Tahiti. With interviews from naval historians and literary experts, this program tells the rest of the story. REAL ESTATE
Flipping Out
HGTV, 8 p.m.
Tightly wound house-flipper Jeff Lewis is the reason to watch this series. Driven by the promise of profit, Lewis is constantly buying/fixing/selling properties on the show. Lewis is also prone to his own flip-outs when a deal doesn't go his way (though he did start seeing a therapist in the show's second season). Tonight, watch him direct his ire toward contractors who bungle a fix-up job in a swank neighbourhood in Orange County. MOVIE
Fido
Citytv, 9 p.m.
This Canadian feature neatly merges comedy and horror. and takes place in an alternate universe where every household has a zombie to help with chores. Suburban mom Helen (Carrie-Anne Moss) buys a zombie named Fido (Billy Connolly) to help around the house. Her son Timmy (K'Sun Ray) befriends him, but has second thoughts when the neighbours start to die horribly.

Family Guy creator Seth MacFarlane serves as roastmaster, and the former Baywatch star is forced to endure character attacks from Hulk Hogan, Jerry Springer and comedians Lisa Lampanelli and Jeffrey Ross.

MOVIE
Waterworld
CH, 8:30 p.m.
Watch this movie and decide for yourself whether or not it's one of the worst movies of all time. A box-office bomb, the 1995 feature was roasted by critics. Set in the future, the story stars Kevin Costner as Mariner, a man who swims the seas of Earth after the melting of the polar ice caps. Mariner is enlisted by an idealistic young woman (Jeanne Tripplehorn) in her fight against nefarious terrorists, whose eye-patched leader, The Deacon (Dennis Hopper), has plans to rule the planet.

Joe was introduced to recreational drug use in high school and thereafter graduated to become a full-fledged heroin addict. Rise Up: Canadian Pop Music in the 80s

History, 10 p.m.

The first episode focuses on London, and rewinds the clock all the way back to 43 AD, when workers used mounds of trash to support the docks of the Roman outpost of Londinium. As the city of London grew, so did the daily output of garbage. And were you aware that an Englishman invented the world's first toilet? It's true.

Howard's end - a rich testament to lives lived

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/howards-end-rich-testament-lives-lived/docview/747416980/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Woodlawn was in this injured state when the present owner bought the property in 1995. His ongoing contribution to the house and its history since around 2000 has been a mix of historical preservation and sensible modernization. He has restored the principal doorway to its central place on the long side of the house's volume, where [John George Howard], following Palladio's example, had intended it to be.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Howard%27s+end+-+a+rich+testament+to+lives+lived&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-27&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Howard%27s+end+-+a+rich+testament+to+lives+lived&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-27&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: John George Howard-designed mansion a beautifully restored reminder of Toronto's past
jmays@globeandmail.com
For many well-to-do politicians, lawyers and businessmen in early Victorian Toronto, the perfect house was a rural villa up Yonge Street, on the picturesque rise of land north of the built-up village of Yorkville, and far from the busy wharves, warehouses and immigrant tenements of Front Street.
Some of these people hired fashionable local architects, constructed and lived in their dream homes for a while, though almost all the mansions vanished when the once-expansive estates on which they stood were divided into small residential lots in the later nineteenth century. If these pleasant houses, with their handsome stables and orchards and gracious sociability, are remembered at all today, it's because they have left a trace in the names of streets and neighbourhoods such as Summerhill, Farnham, Humewood and Rathnelly.
But at least one still exists. Last week, I visited Woodlawn, as this brick architectural survivor has been known since its construction on a 12-acre site in 1841. (Today, it is nestled deep among sturdy family homes built later along Woodlawn and Walker avenues.)
Designed by high-society Toronto architect John George Howard, who had earlier done Colborne Lodge on his suburban estate of High Park, the original parts of Woodlawn embody the ideals of Georgian taste in country-house building. These sober, anti-urban values include the very plain, symmetrical façade treatment popularized by Palladio in his rural projects, enormous windows (the better to frame views of the gardens and countryside), and a shallow veranda with ornamental Gothic ogee arches between slender pillars.
The interior of what's left of the original house speaks even more clearly about the Palladian roots of Howard's Georgian style. The rooms used by the present owner as a study and a formal dining area are not vast, but they are majestically proportioned. Especially in the study, the crown moulding and tall windows - which have been preserved from John Howard's time - are elegant and restrained components of this highly successful room.
As you can imagine, Woodlawn has undergone numerous changes over its long career, not all of them favourable to Howard's 1841 scheme. The first of these transformations took place after 1845, when ownership of the estate passed from Howard's client, the prosperous lawyer William Hume Blake, to the future railway magnate Joseph Curran Morrison. A horticulturalist as well as a powerful businessman, Morrison built a conservatory and heated greenhouses adjacent to the house.
Subdivision of the estate by Morrison's heirs might have been the end of Woodlawn's story - had it not been for a certain reluctance on the part of these heirs to see the dwelling demolished then and there. They saved the house, while stripping back much of the land on which it stood.
But they did not remain kind to Woodlawn. In 1886, a Morrison child lopped some 1,200 square feet off the 7,300-square-foot original structure. (The reason is not known.) Around the same time, a "modern" two-storey annex - viz., ordinary to the point of being factory-like - was tacked on perpendicular to the long axis of Howard's plan.
Woodlawn was in this injured state when the present owner bought the property in 1995. His ongoing contribution to the house and its history since around 2000 has been a mix of historical preservation and sensible modernization. He has restored the principal doorway to its central place on the long side of the house's volume, where Howard, following Palladio's example, had intended it to be. But he has also retained certain embellishments of owners after Howard's time - a florid staircase that sweeps up to the upper storey, for example - and faithfully cast and reused some later Victorian mouldings.
And at the owner's request, Toronto architect Peter Turner brought back just over 2,000 square feet to the garden façade of the building. This addition has been done with effective sensitivity to the architectural fabric of John Howard's original structure - the exterior is clad in a modern compound that mimics very well the rugged plaster of lime, shells and pebbles used to cover the oldest brick surfaces - but it brings the interior up to date: The part of the house facing the garden is now an open-plan ensemble of kitchen, informal dining room, and living room, all opening outward through tall French doors.
Today, Woodlawn is what an old house should be: not frozen in time or reconstructed with archaeological accuracy and rigour, but a richly layered document of the many lives lived within its walls.

Property firm building foundation for dividend

Author: Taylor, Fabrice

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/property-firm-building-foundation-dividend/docview/747416939/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. [Bob Dhillon] doesn't rule out a dividend, but he seems reluctant to go in that direction now (technically, it's the board's decision, but he's chairman and major shareholder so he has veto power). He says he wants to finish stabilizing his units (that is renovating them), get rid of rental incentives that are running at $4-million a year, spend some money on maintenance and squeeze some more rent out of his properties.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Property+firm+building+foundation+for+dividend&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Fabrice&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-27&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Property+firm+building+foundation+for+dividend&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Fabrice&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-27&amp;spage=B.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Fabrice Taylor is a Chartered Financial Analyst.
It's time we stopped using the S & P TSX index to measure the health of the stock market. It's deeply flawed. For starters, it goes down way too often. How is that helpful?
Not all stocks are going down though. Dividend stocks are stealthily rising - some of them, anyway. Look at BCE or Atco (both recommended in this space, I hasten to add). Investors apparently want to own companies that send them cheques every three months or so.
Stocks that might pay dividends are also doing relatively well. You wonder why more companies don't. Take Mainstreet Equity, a real estate concern out of Calgary that focuses on smaller rental properties.
The company has about 10 million shares outstanding and a market cap of $110-million.
Although most of its buildings are in places where the local economy is sensitive to commodity prices - Alberta and Saskatchewan, notably - the company has done surprisingly well. It emerged from the recession in better shape than it went in by some measures, generating enough cash to buy back four million shares.
And while it has a very good record of buying and occasionally selling properties, it's been a laggard operationally, with stubbornly high vacancy. But that's changing too, and fast: the vacancy rate fell to 10 per cent from 19 per cent last year. Mainstreet's business model means it will always have a relatively high vacancy rate but it was higher than necessary before management rolled up its sleeves and beat it down to much more profitable levels. It's still falling fast.
Funds from operations on a per-share basis are rising nicely, up 36 per cent in the nine months to June 30, to 45 cents.
By and large, things are looking up for this company, whose stock I own. Most investment dealers that cover it rate it a "strong buy" with big upside.
I think it should pay a dividend. The company can probably generate 80 cents a share of cash in relatively short order. Despite having spent $26-million buying back stock last year, it has $6-million in the bank.
And it can finance unmortgaged properties and refinance existing debt to put another $60-million in the coffers - in total, that's more than $6 a share. Plus it's generating a growing stream of cash flow. I think it could pay a dividend, and I'm not alone.
TD Newcrest says Mainstreet could pay a 34-cent dividend in 2011, giving the stock a roughly 3-per-cent yield using today's price. "A dividend would be a positive catalyst for the stock," says the analyst, whose target is $14. The stock is $11 now.
Buying back more stock isn't really an option. CEO Bob Dhillon owns about 40 per cent of it and the float is already pretty thin.
Mr. Dhillon doesn't rule out a dividend, but he seems reluctant to go in that direction now (technically, it's the board's decision, but he's chairman and major shareholder so he has veto power). He says he wants to finish stabilizing his units (that is renovating them), get rid of rental incentives that are running at $4-million a year, spend some money on maintenance and squeeze some more rent out of his properties. (Mainstreet's business model is to buy up low-rent buildings, spruce them up and raise the rents.) More importantly, he wants to acquire more properties when prices are low and financing is cheap. He says he can borrow five-year money for less than 3 per cent and prices are softening.
But if so, why did the company buy back four million shares? That buyback didn't stop Mainstreet from buying buildings.
"Because it was the best use of cash at that time, when the stock was about $6. Now the best use is to bulk up," he says.
I think he could do it all, and I suspect he might. It would be good for the stock price.
Mainstreet Equity
Thursday's close $11.18, up 18 cents

Making a profit from problem properties

Author: Ladurantaye, Steve

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/making-profit-problem-properties/docview/746403173/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We always pay market value when we take over a property and we never sell low because there's no need for us to engage in fire sales," said Gordon McIvor, Canada Lands' vice-president of strategic acquisitions. "We have the luxury of time and remediation. When we sell, we are getting maximum value for those assets."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Making+a+profit+from+problem+properties&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-23&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Making+a+profit+from+problem+properties&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-23&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: REAL ESTATE REPORTER
The Dominion Building in downtown Charlottetown was every landlord's nightmare when the federal government declared it surplus to its needs.
The feds had built a new home for its employees on the island, leaving the run-down six-storey building without a single tenant to occupy its 176,000 square feet of office space. The 55-year-old property was in need of some major repairs and would be unlikely to fetch much beyond its scrap value on the open market.
There was only one real option: sell it to Canada Lands, a Crown corporation that has been discreetly disposing of problem properties for 15 years. It was a good call - Canada Lands sold the building last week for $1-million, twice as much as it paid in 2007.
The agency has been working behind the scenes for 15 years, but has suddenly found itself the subject of global interest as governments from around the world send delegations to learn how Canada turns a profit on properties that would be difficult to sell without improvements and updating.
In the past few months it has hosted delegations from China, the United States and Eastern Europe.
They are all interested in the same thing - how to redevelop government properties such as abandoned army bases in a way that they earn profits for the taxpayers instead of only the developers.
"We always pay market value when we take over a property and we never sell low because there's no need for us to engage in fire sales," said Gordon McIvor, Canada Lands' vice-president of strategic acquisitions. "We have the luxury of time and remediation. When we sell, we are getting maximum value for those assets."
Foreign governments are interested for one main reason - Canada Lands has never received a cent of federal funding and has paid $370-million in dividends to the state. It has spent about $61-million on environmental improvements to its properties, and every building and piece of land in its sizable portfolio will eventually be sold to the private sector.
Mr. McIvor points to an executive order issued in June by U.S. President Barrack Obama in which he called for the government to undertake a review of its properties with an eye of unloading surplus space onto the private sector as a sign the Canadian government has been ahead of the rest of the world in dealing with unwanted properties.
Here at home, the government's decisions about what is and is not surplus has led to the creation of a quirky portfolio of properties for Canada Lands to deal with. It owns five military bases (it has already redeveloped and sold six others), a trendy housing development in Calgary, a bustling industrial park in Burnaby, B.C., and plots of land in the downtown cores of many of the country's largest cities.
In each case, it buys the property and then consults with the local governments about what each site's best use would be. If there are environmental issues - many old military homes are packed with asbestos, for example - it will take care of them before marketing the site to developers.
Its most high profile holdings are in downtown Toronto, where it inherited the CN Tower, the Metro Toronto Convention Centre and the Intercontinental Hotel as a side effect of CN Rail's initial public offering in 1995.
The properties could be sold at any time, at least in theory, but Queen's University real estate professor John Andrew said Canada Lands is a convenient way for the government to park valuable properties it doesn't want to be seen as holding onto as a landlord. "The role of Canada Lands is a bit odd because on the surface of it their job is to dispose of real estate assets, yet they hold some for a long time and others are really not for sale," he said.
"Some of these are so unusual that it is difficult to determine their fair market value, or for any buyer to offer what they might be worth to the government," he said. "If the asset is of great value to a wide range of potential buyers - an office building with government tenants, for example - one wonders why the government is selling it at all."
Mr. McIvor insists every property is on the table except the CN Tower. Everything else in downtown Toronto - the hotel and convention centre as well as an office tower - will make it to market at some point.
"Since the company does not engage in fire sales and because of the serious economic downtown last year, the properties have not yet been put on the market but we intend to do so in the near future," Mr. McIvor said.
That could happen as soon as this fall. The Canadian commercial real estate market rebounded sharply in the first half of the year from the recessionary lows of 2009, up around 60 per cent compared to the year earlier period.
If ever there was a time to sell, he said, this may be it.
"The interesting thing about being a large national organization is we can have a balanced approach to development and hold on to things until the time is right," he said. "You'll see three very big commercial announcements from Canada Lands this fall in three different areas of the country."
***
PORTFOLIO SNAPSHOT
CN Tower, Toronto
Inherited from CN Rail in 1995 when the company left government hands via an initial public offering, Canada Lands also took over the Metro Toronto Convention Centre and the attached Intercontinental Hotel. It also owns the land beneath the Rogers Centre.
CFB Calgary
The former 200-acre army base is now divided into three hip sub-divisions called Currie Barracks, Garrison Woods and Garrison Green. They will collectively have about 5,000 housing units, with some retail mixed in for good measure and are built to LEED Gold environmental standards.
Glenlyon Business Park, Burnaby, B.C.
Located on 133 acres bordering the Fraser River, the business park was also acquired by Canada Lands from CN Railway in 1995. Tenants include Nokia, Future Shop/Best Buy and Ritchie Bros. When fully developed, it will consist of over two million square feet of office, research and development space.
Pleasantville, Nfld.
A former U.S. and Canadian military base in St. John's, built during the Second World War. The 64-acre site has been rezoned to allow for a residential development with a mix of town homes, single family homes and condominium units.
Senneville, Que.
Former site of the Senneville Lodge, located on the western tip of the island of Montreal. The 60.5-acre property had been owned by Veterans Affairs Canada and is the site of a former veterans care facility which operated from 1946 until its closure in 1990. There are no redevelopment plans yet.

Burying our heads in the sand

Author: Rochon, Lisa

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/burying-our-heads-sand/docview/746244712/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: That design got the go-ahead despite the fact that an independent committee of experts, struck to review the proposed revitalization design, heavily favoured a competing submission.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Burying+our+heads+in+the+sand&amp;author=Rochon%2C+Lisa&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-21&amp;spage=R.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Burying+our+heads+in+the+sand&amp;author=Rochon%2C+Lisa&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-21&amp;spage=R.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Sugar Beach is fab, but the building next door, and a new 'hood down the street, are less than visionary
lrochon@globeandmail.com
Blurred, soft, faint and flowing: Flou is a French word of such import that it should be a required addition to the English language. Because Toronto's new Sugar Beach is flou , it yields an impressionistic landscape rarely attempted in the hard-edged cities of North America. Don't confuse the pale pink umbrellas rising from the cream-coloured sand as design weakness. The advantage of flou - besides allowing for willow trees, granite rock and pink parasols to be read as sensory touchstones of colour and texture - is that it emphasizes the rigidity of Corus Entertainment corporate headquarters constructed next door.
It's a bit like spying Jackie Kennedy sheathed in shell-pink chiffon and sparkling sequins sitting next to Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev in a shapeless black suit. On a tiny, two-acre (eight-tenths of a hectare) park on Toronto's central waterfront, Montreal's Claude Cormier Architectes Paysagistes has accomplished a mesmerizing distraction from the dark green mask of Corus.
Such is the unsettling truth of the central waterfront as it is being currently rolled out - beautiful moments in its new public space marred by the construction of ordinary architecture. The chunky green-glass Corus building was one of those Waterfront Toronto cloak-and-dagger secrets, once referred to mysteriously and misleadingly as Project Symphony. Its architect, Jack Diamond of Diamond + Schmitt, had been hired without a design competition by the Toronto Economic Development Corporation (TEDCO), a city agency that owns more than 60 per cent of the 1,000 acres in the city's downtown brownfields known as the Portlands. Diamond had previously worked as a consultant for TEDCO on the precinct plan for East Bayfront, just next door to Toronto's Harbourfront.
Given that Diamond has made a career of creating buildings designed to fit into the streetscape rather than express something individualistic or exuberant, the match was made in heaven: Emotional architecture is not what TEDCO wanted. Flou ? Feed it to the seagulls. In its wisdom, TEDCO - representing the Toronto taxpayer - wanted something glassy and generic.
Why? "The market pays for view. View was paramount," says project architect David Dow. Still, was it really necessary to promote something this indistinguishable on one of the city's grand-finale waterfront sites? "It had to be a generic enough office building that it could satisfy other tenants in the future," explains Dow. Imagine for yourself the hint of regret in his voice.
In response, Diamond + Schmitt created two glass office buildings linked by an atrium. Hardly a jewel, but, nevertheless, a competent design solution. The glass is dark green - not the golden colour of glass kissed by the sun, as it appeared in one of the earlier renderings from 2007. It's sustainable, smart design; but to the eye, it's a corporate clunker.
Corus Entertainment is one of Canada's largest media-and-entertainment companies, owners of radio stations Q107 and The Edge, animation house Nelvana and Kids Can Press. Its new office and broadcast centre is planned for completion in late September, although a majority of its 1,200 employees has already moved here from disparate sites across the city.
In the earlier renderings, there's a groovy permeability to the headquarters: The big glass doors on the building's west side are opened wide, allowing masses of people, gathered on the stone promenade and sitting on the massive Sugar Beach hump of a rock, to look in at the TV studios. You can almost picture Lady Gaga arriving to flaunt her latest headdress.
But for now, the ground-floor glass is sheathed in some kind of reflective, anti-ballistic coating, so it's difficult to see in. It would be delightful if the monumental sliding doors facing the lake would regularly expose the building to the winds and the sounds of the water - alas, and I hope that Corus proves me wrong, that's unlikely, given security concerns. The tiny café at the north of the building, meanwhile, is too narrow and, during the morning rush, overcrowded. Still, the sense of flou resonates powerfully, thanks to Waterfront Toronto, in the public spaces around the Corus building. Double allees of maple trees and timber benches by Dutch landscape magicians West 8 now grace part of the East Bayfront promenade. A restaurant with breathtaking views along the waterfront edge of the building is still to come. And tiny motorized fish, by fantastic British design firm Troika, running the length of the ceiling in a public corridor inside Corus, are about to be turned on.
The building interior is being outfitted by Quadrangle Architects and is stoked with walls clad in wood recycled from the old Queen Elizabeth docks. What could have been an airy atrium, with clear views to the waterfront and a living green wall, is being clogged with stuff: a boxy recording studio; and a multi-
storey, careening tube slide for the daring employees of Corus.
But let's slip from the interior, privatized world of Corus and head outside and slightly east to Bayside, the largest new residential neighbourhood along Toronto's waterfront, poised to begin construction. Waterfront Toronto announced this week that an American development-and-design consortium has won the bid to build out the largest development parcels in East Bayfront, comprised of 10 acres between Lower Sherbourne and Parliament streets.
Hines, a large international real-estate firm, has partnered with American architect Cesar Pelli (renowned for his sky-scratching towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia) and Stanton Eckstut, one of the master-plan consultants of New York City's Battery Park City waterfront development. Adamson Architects are the local affiliates.
The Hines-Pelli consortium was favoured by a committee that included Waterfront Toronto CEO John Campbell and the city's deputy city manager, Richard Butts. I'm not exactly sure why. The financials, which are strictly confidential, must have seriously impressed, because the design itself is largely polite and formulaic but uninspired.
That design got the go-ahead despite the fact that an independent committee of experts, struck to review the proposed revitalization design, heavily favoured a competing submission. That vision - featuring smaller commercial buildings and glass residential studios engaged in an urban dance - was produced by homeboy architects Peter Clewes and Bruce Kuwabara, who joined forces with Walker Corporation of Australia and Cityzen Development Corporation (currently building the Marilyn Monroesque tower in Mississauga). In their report, the committee recommended the locally produced scheme for its permeability and heightened sense of Toronto, including lovely slips of water cut from the lake into the mainland. Unforgivably, the process leading up to the naming, this week, of the winning Bayside development partner has been shrouded in secrecy. All players - including all consultants - have been required by Waterfront Toronto to sign confidentiality agreements, provoking secret, hushed exchanges of information. Officially, I don't know anything. Bayside is the largest residential development to plant itself on Toronto's waterfront in decades. But, though it spreads over publicly owned land, none of its new residential designs has been seen or debated by the public. Keeping the Toronto waterfront as a secret harboured by only a very few is an old idea that smacks of Toronto in the 1980s. Definitely not flou , just tragically, dangerously passé.

The subject, Amy W., is afflicted with bipolar disorder, anorexia and self-mutilation - much of it stemming from the fact she was sexually molested as a child. To ease the pain, Amy routinely downs two bottles of vodka a night. Her friend Jessica tries to rally Amy's family for a last-ditch intervention before it's too late. BEAUTY PAGEANT

Full text: THIS WEEK / HIGHLIGHTS
FRIDAY
AUGUST 20
REALITY
House Hunters
HGTV, 7 p.m.
The housing market in America has never been healthier, or at least so it appears in this U.S. cable series hosted by Suzanne Whang. The veteran real-estate agent is a calming presence for couples and families for whom price never seems to be an object. Tonight, Suzanne counsels Gina and Rich, a young couple ready to buy their own place in scenic Summerville, South Carolina. The trick is finding a domicile that is move-in ready and suitable for their two demanding dogs. DRAMA
Pretty Little Liars
MuchMusic, 8 p.m.
Originating on ABC Family Channel a few months back, this cable series repeats in its entirety, starting with tonight's pilot episode. Based on the bestselling novels by Sara Shepard, the soapy series follows four teen high-schoolers - Spencer (Troian Bellisario), Hanna (Ashley Benson), Aria (Lucy Hale) and Emily (Shay Mitchell) - whose clique crumbles when their queen bee Alison disappears without a trace. One year later, the quartet are rattled to receive e-mails and text messages from Alison - now threatening to expose their darkest secrets. DRAMA
CSI: NY
CBS, CTV, 9 p.m.
Big Apple crime-lab boss Mac Taylor (Gary Sinise) and his team are handed a bizarre murder case: A woman turns herself into the police after stabbing her philandering husband to death. The subsequent investigation reveals that the supposedly spontaneous murder was in fact premeditated, and forensic evidence connects the woman to a vicious accomplice with ties to nearly two-dozen other violent crimes. Curiouser and curiouser, as they say. FOOD
Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives
Food Network, 10 p.m.
If you only know Guy Fieri from his hosting duties on NBC's Minute to Win It , be sure to catch him in his natural habitat in this lively Food Network series. The spiky-haired gourmand tours across the U.S. in search of greasy-spoon eateries famed for their specialties. Two typical shows air tonight: First, Fieri hits Boise, Idaho, to visit a family restaurant serving authentic brick-oven pizza. In the second show, he's at a Boston eatery where three brothers carry on their father's tradition of clam chowder and chipotle/pastrami sandwiches. SATURDAY
AUGUST 21
DOCUMENTARY
Curveball: W.P. Kinsella
Bravo!, 7 p.m.
A heartfelt profile of Canadian author W.P. Kinsella, best known for his 1982 novel Shoeless Joe , which was later adapted into the feature film Field of Dreams . Kinsella waxes eloquently on his childhood years growing up in Edmonton and reveals the inspiration behind his lifelong fascination with the great American game of baseball. MOVIE
The Sting
TCM, 8 p.m.
The con is on. Winner of seven Academy Awards - including Best Picture - this 1973 caper flick marked the perfect on-screen reunion for Paul Newman and Robert Redford. The former Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, Newman and Redford were perfectly cast as Henry and Johnny, respectively, two Depression-era hustlers trying to avenge the death of a fellow grifter by scamming a thuggish Irish gangster (Robert Shaw). The standout support cast include Eileen Brennan, Ray Walston and Charles Durning. MYSTERY
The Casebook of Sherlock Holmes
PBS, 9 p.m.
The great detective assumes rather unseemly duties in the 1992 story The Master Blackmailer . As Holmes (Jeremy Brett) tries to bring in the nefarious blackmailer Charles Augustus Milverton to justice, he's willing to impersonate a lowly plumber in order to infiltrate the Milverton estate. The stuffy Doctor Watson (Edward Hardwicke) is not amused. DOCUMENTARY
Fixing My Brain
CBS News Network, 10 p.m.
Consider the strange but true saga of Barbara Arrowsmith. Although she was born with a brilliant memory that stood her well through university, she still couldn't tell her right from her left, or read a clock. Instead of giving in her to limited abilities, Barbara created exercises to stimulate the weak areas of her brain. After several months, she was able to tell time. Every great journey begins with a single step. SUNDAY
AUGUST 22
DOCUMENTARY
The True Story of Black Hawk Down
History, 7 p.m.
If you've seen the 2001 movie Black Hawk Down , this documentary tells the rest of the story. The film recalls the factual events of the infamous Battle of Mogadishu, which resulted from a failed raid by U.S. military personnel trying to capture Somali warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid. The program includes interviews with eyewitnesses who were there that day and perspective from author Mark Bowden, who wrote the book that inspired the feature film. SCIENCE
Secrets of the Secret Service
Discovery, 8 p.m.
What's the history behind the law enforcement agency assigned with protecting the American president? This documentary provides heretofore unshared insight into the life of a Secret Service agent. Most of the program is devoted to the agency's use of cutting-edge technology, including specially-designed firearms and bulletproof fabrics. The sunglasses are, of course, standard issue. REALITY
Undercover Boss
CBS, 9 p.m.
One of last season's unexpected hits, this show follows corporate big shots as they slip anonymously into the rank and file of their own companies. Tonight's show focuses on Dave Rife, owner of the White Castle fast-food chain, who feels rather sheepish after accidentally ruining thousands of hamburger buns. Rife is more concerned by the level of low morale among employees working at his company. REALITY
Dancer with Tiny Legs
TLC, 10 p.m.
JoAnne Fluke is a study in perseverance. The 34-year-old was born with a rare birth defect - the bottom half of her spine is missing. As a result, she has tiny webbed legs and stands roughly the height of a 10-month-old child. Undaunted, Ms. Fluke has defied decades of predictions of her imminent demise and has steadfastly pursued her passion for dance.
MONDAY
AUGUST 23
REALITY
Intervention
A & E, 8 p.m.
Even by this show's usual grim standards, tonight's episode is a hard one to sit through. The subject, Amy W., is afflicted with bipolar disorder, anorexia and self-mutilation - much of it stemming from the fact she was sexually molested as a child. To ease the pain, Amy routinely downs two bottles of vodka a night. Her friend Jessica tries to rally Amy's family for a last-ditch intervention before it's too late. BEAUTY PAGEANT
The 2010 Miss Universe Pageant
NBC, 9 p.m.
Good heavens, is this still around? Once a huge TV event with ratings in the range of an Oscars broadcast, the annual beauty pageant has lost some of its lustre in recent years. One clue: This year's show is hosted by rocker-turned-reality-star Bret Michaels and Today correspondent Natalie Morales, who will host the live broadcast from a Las Vegas casino. As in years past, the contestants will hail from more than 80 countries and will compete in the three traditional categories: interview, evening gown and swimming suit. Musical guests include John Legend and the Roots. REALITY
Chainsaw Ice Sculptures
TLC, 10 p.m.
Were you aware the art of ice sculpting had become a very competitive field in recent years? It's true. This special was filmed at the World Ice Art Championships that take place in Fairbanks, Alaska, each year. How it works: Each four-man team is handed 10 enormous blocks of ice to be carved into sculptures by chainsaws, chisels and blow torches. Strangely, one of the favourite teams to win the championships hails from the state of Texas. MOVIE
Who's Afraid
of Virginia Woolf?
TCM, 11 p.m.
Released to theatres in 1966, this movie was adapted from the stage play by Edward Albee. The story cast real-life couple Liz Taylor and Richard Burton as Martha and George, a 40-something academic couple at a small New England college. George is a hard-core tippler and Martha is a crude flirt, so naturally they are constantly squabbling. The fighting intensifies when a young couple (George Segal and Sandy Dennis) spend time with the lovebirds following a faculty mixer. TUESDAY
AUGUST 24
FOOD
Ricardo & Friends
Food Network, 7 p.m.
Often referred to as the Quebecois equivalent of Jamie Oliver, chef Ricardo Larrivee is a huge celebrity in la belle province. In this series, he's constantly searching local suppliers for fresh ingredients that can be transformed into fabulous repasts. In tonight's episode, Ricardo invites a gaggle of family and friends over for several of his specialty desserts. The high-calorie menu includes caramelized Asian pears, crème caramel and chocolate genoise with ganache.
SCIENCE
NOVA
PBS, 8 p.m.
Was there truly a time when flying dinosaurs existed? Tonight's episode follows up on several unique fossils found in China's Liaoning Province. Among the strangest findings is the fossil of a small dinosaur with a set of wings on both its arms and legs. The microraptor is the smallest adult dinosaur ever found. NOVA brings together a team of paleontologists, aviation engineers and computer artists to determine whether the tiny creature really was capable of winged flight. DRAMA
NCIS: Los Angeles
CBS, Global, 9 p.m.
One of last season's hottest rookie hits, NCIS: Los Angeles focuses on a covert U.S. military team specializing in slick underground missions. In tonight's episode, special agents Callan (Chris O'Donnell), Hanna (LL Cool J) and the other members of the NCIS team race to save one of their own after receiving disturbing video evidence of a fellow agent being held hostage. This time, it's personal. REALITY
Growing Up Twisted
A & E, 10 p.m.
This new reality series starring 1980s heavy-metal rocker Dee Snider comes to an end tonight. Sticking to the template created by Gene Simmons Family Jewels and other A & E reality shows on faded rock stars, the concept follows Snider, wife Suzette and their four kids living under the same roof in suburban Long Island. In tonight's finale, Suzette makes the mistake of interfering in the romantic lives of her two teenaged sons. Ratings for the first season were not spectacular, so don't expect a second act.
WEDNESDAY
AUGUST 25
PROFILE
Private Screenings: Lauren Bacall
TCM, 6:45 p.m.
TCM host Robert Osborne sits down for a lively chat with screen legend Lauren Bacall in this special. In her typical candid manner, Ms. Bacall reveals how her experience modeling for Harper's Bazaar lead to her contract with Warner Bros. and a starring role in To Have and Have Not . The 1944 feature also marked Bacall's first meeting with her future husband, Humphrey Bogart. The program includes ample clips from the five films starring the couple, including Dark Passage , The Big Sleep and Key Largo . FOOD
MasterChef
Fox, CTV, 8 p.m.
Tonight's episode of the homespun cooking competition runs two hours - which is a lot of Gordon Ramsay to digest in one sitting. The bombastic Ramsay challenges each of the remaining home cooks to bake a single cupcake, a task that turns out to be much more difficult than it sounds. In the same show, the contestants are taken from the studio kitchen and transported to a truck stop to cook for truckers. Celebrity chef Cat Cora shows up to sample the diner-style grub.
DOCUMENTARY
Frontline
PBS, 9 p.m.
Airing days before the fifth anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, tonight's edition of the acclaimed documentary series examines serious charges levied against the New Orleans Police Department. According to this report, in the days and weeks following the devastation of Katrina, the New Orleans police readily used lethal force against citizens and then tried to cover up their actions. The Frontline team takes a closer look at the allegations. DOCUMENTARY
Inside the Saudi Kingdom
CBC News Network, 10 p.m.
First broadcast on the BBC, this film boasts a rare chat with one of the most senior royal princes in Saudi Arabia. The filmmakers interview Prince Saud bin Abdul Mohsen bin Abdul Aziz Al Saud, who talks frankly about the difficulties of maintaining Bedouin and Islamic traditions in the face of new technology. THURSDAY
AUGUST 26
REALITY
Wedding SOS
Slice, 6:30 p.m.
If she ever tires of television, wedding planner Jane Dayus-Hinch could easily find a career as a professional mediator. Every episode in this engaging reality series features Ms. Jane responding to a plea from couples asking her to assist with their chaotic wedding plans. Tonight she's called in to help Rhonda and Ray, who wanted to celebrate their storybook romance with a grand ceremony out of a Danielle Steel novel. Instead, Ray is edgy, Rhonda is depressed and the big day is weeks away. REALITY
Chuck's Day Off
Food Network, 7:30 p.m.
Not your typical TV chef, Chuck Hughes was working in advertising when he fell in love with the restaurant business. Next came cooking school and finding his true calling as the chef-owner of the popular Garde-Manger eatery in Old Montreal. In tonight's episode, Chuck hooks up with his best friend, a tattoo artist named Safwan, for a stove-top clambake on the hottest day in the year. To help beat the heat, Chuck whips up a batch of his deadly Tequila Lemonade.
MUSIC
Innovators in Music
Bravo!, 8 p.m.
One of the best Canadian music programs in years, this documentary series profiles six musicians from diverse backgrounds. The format explores how the creative process behind their songs is also expressed in other art forms. Tonight's episode profiles Grateful Dead drummer Mickey Hart, who has enjoyed considerable success outside the music field as a painter and author. Hart also reveals her personal theory on the connection between percussion and the Big Bang theory.
HISTORY
Did the Mob Kill JFK?
Discovery, 9 p.m.
Nearly a half-century after John F. Kennedy was murdered in Dallas, speculation on the parties responsible continues to run rampant. This special works off the theories of an informant who recently surfaced with alleged "inside information" on JFK's assassination. In lurid fashion, the program paints a conspiracy mosaic that includes involvement by the U.S. Justice Department, the CIA and, of course, the Mafia. FOOD
BBQ Pit Masters
TLC, 10 p.m.
One of the strangest entries currently on TLC's schedule, this series follows a handful of barbecue fanatics vying for the lofty honour of best BBQ chef in America. Five teams are showcased in the competition, which bestows a cash prize of $100,000 to the winners. In tonight's outing, the chefs have to adjust their usual methods when challenged to prepare beef brisket. Watch tempers flare when some of the chefs have trouble firing up the coals.

LAWRENCE AND MEADOWVALE

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lawrence-meadowvale/docview/745763409/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Cathedral ceilings and a floor-to-ceiling wood-burning fireplace are featured in the family room addition off the eat-in kitchen, which was updated with custom cabinetry, Corian counters and sliding doors to a gated yard with a flagstone patio and perennial gardens. The kitchen was also outfitted with hardwood floors, as were the living and dining rooms in the original section of the house, which has three upper bedrooms.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=LAWRENCE+AND+MEADOWVALE&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-20&amp;spage=G.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 7 Ramblewood Dr.
Asking price: $699,000
Selling price: $675,000
Taxes: $3,996 (2009)
Lot size: 80 by 120 feet
Days on the market: 20
Listing agent: Heather Lemieux, Royal LePage Connect Realty
On a prestigious cul-de-sac lined with one-of-a-kind houses, this renovated two-storey residence catches the attention of passersby with its unique design and layout on a premium corner, agent Heather Lemieux says.
What's immediately apparent is a brick façade covering the front of the 31-year-old house, while the rear addition is encased by a board and batten exterior with double garage doors and veranda to a side entrance.
Cathedral ceilings and a floor-to-ceiling wood-burning fireplace are featured in the family room addition off the eat-in kitchen, which was updated with custom cabinetry, Corian counters and sliding doors to a gated yard with a flagstone patio and perennial gardens. The kitchen was also outfitted with hardwood floors, as were the living and dining rooms in the original section of the house, which has three upper bedrooms.
The master suite has a walk-in closet and access to the largest of three remodelled bathrooms. On the east side of the house, the sellers - and original owners - had local award-winning architect John Robert Carley design a conservatory with a circular layout, ceramic floors, full-height windows and exits to the yard and lower level.
The basement was professionally finished with a workshop and media room with bi-folding closet doors to hide a gym and a sewing room, plus a kitchen disguised behind another set of doors.

Commercial real estate deals soar in first half

Author: Ladurantaye, Steve

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/commercial-real-estate-deals-soar-first-half/docview/744155916/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It is important to note that midyear figures from last year were far lower than the historical average, due to the global economic crisis that characterized much of 2008 and 2009," the report said. "When comparing the current national midyear figure to midyear 2005 - a year more reflective of the country's normal commercial real estate activity levels - volume is up by 22.8 per cent."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Commercial+real+estate+deals+soar+in+first+half&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-17&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Commercial+real+estate+deals+soar+in+first+half&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-17&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   REAL ESTATE REPORTER
Canada's commercial real estate market rebounded sharply in the first half of 2010, with the value of deals increasing by 60 per cent as the debt markets recovered from the recession.
Commercial real estate company CB Richard Ellis said in its midyear national investment report that $7.8-billion worth of deals were done from January to June, compared with $4.9-billion during the same period in 2009.
There were a total of 2,243 commercial deals done, compared with 1,565 at last year's halfway point.
"It is important to note that midyear figures from last year were far lower than the historical average, due to the global economic crisis that characterized much of 2008 and 2009," the report said. "When comparing the current national midyear figure to midyear 2005 - a year more reflective of the country's normal commercial real estate activity levels - volume is up by 22.8 per cent."
Real estate investment trusts and local private investors handled most of the deals, CBRE said, adding that they "led the charge using available debt aggressively."
Buyers were active across the country, CBRE chairman John O'Bryan said. "Unique to this year is the fact that market activity is consistently up across all major cities - a trend that does not happen often," he said. Here's a look at major centres:
TORONTO
Toronto recorded the highest midyear commercial real estate activity volume of all major cities, with $2.9-billion in transaction volume, and 563 deals. Current debt levels and available capital gave the Toronto market a boost - factors that have been missing from the market since 2008's economic downturn. The REIT and private investor groups have been particularly active in Toronto's commercial real estate market over the past several months. As one of the last-standing tax shelters, REITs have been extremely active in the market since the recession occurred.
VANCOUVER
In the January-to-June period, 632 commercial real estate transactions took place, totalling more than $1.6-billion in volume. Market activity was up across the industrial, retail and multiresidential classes - a trend unique to this year. The greatest year-over-year increase was recorded in small to mid-size buildings.
MONTREAL
The city continued to rebound positively in the first half of 2010, with increased market activity across all asset classes. During the first two quarters, 446 real estate transactions took place, totalling over $1.1-billion.
CALGARY
During the first two quarters, 188 real estate transactions took place, totalling more than $680-million.
EDMONTON
The commercial market recorded 161 transactions in the first half of this year, totalling $754-million.
OTTAWA
The capital city continued along its steady and stable course, recording 83 transactions totalling $267-million in investment volume.
HALIFAX
Halifax recorded significant deal flow over last year's activity, with 32 transactions totalling $111-million in volume.

ALBERT FRENCH BOWMAN

Author: Bowman, James Albert

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/albert-french-bowman/docview/744155904/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Ab and Flo bought a beautiful but rundown farm in Fullarton Township, Ont., in 1944 and moved there in 1946. Cash was in short supply but help came from the Upper Thames River Conservation Authority, the Veterans' Land Act and the Ontario Agricultural College. Ab was willing to try innovative farming techniques such as contour plowing to stop erosion, organized crop rotation and the building of a farm pond.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=ALBERT+FRENCH+BOWMAN&amp;author=Bowman%2C+James+Albert&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-17&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=ALBERT+FRENCH+BOWMAN&amp;author=Bowman%2C+James+Albert&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-17&amp;spage=L.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, pilot, farmer. Born May 25, 1920, in Portage la Prairie, Man. Died Aug. 1 in Stratford, Ont., of renal failure, aged 90.
Albert Bowman, or Ab as he was affectionately known, was a city boy who developed a lifelong love of farming. When his father, Albert Bowman, died in 1923, his mother, Hazel MacDonald, was left to look after four small children with the help of family.
During these years in Portage la Prairie, Man., Ab became friends with a local farmer and liked to visit the farm to help out. When his mother remarried in 1929, the family moved to Toronto.
An excellent athlete, Ab competed in running, lacrosse, hockey and softball. In his later teen years he worked at Ontario farms during the summers.
Ab enrolled at the Ontario Agricultural College in Guelph, Ont., but the Second World War interrupted his studies. He joined the air force and became a flying instructor, serving in southern Ontario. He retired from the air force at the end of the war and finished his studies at Kemptville Agricultural School.
In 1942, Ab married Florence Greenwood. They had eight children, Nancy, Keith, Jim, Peter, Judy, John, Marg and Ross.
Ab and Flo bought a beautiful but rundown farm in Fullarton Township, Ont., in 1944 and moved there in 1946. Cash was in short supply but help came from the Upper Thames River Conservation Authority, the Veterans' Land Act and the Ontario Agricultural College. Ab was willing to try innovative farming techniques such as contour plowing to stop erosion, organized crop rotation and the building of a farm pond. His farm was used as a demonstration site to show these new techniques to other veterans and farmers.
Over the years the farm improved as Ab built up a dairy herd of 35 to 40 milking cows. Because of his difficulties in borrowing money from the banks, he became interested in helping to organize the Mitchell and District Credit Union and was elected its first chairman. Ab served on the board for 25 years.
In 1962, Ab took a job away from the farm, first with the Ontario Federation of Agriculture and then with the Veterans' Land Act. He also became an accredited real estate appraiser. The farming continued but he phased out the dairy business and moved into beef and hogs. He retired from the VLA at 65 but continued to do real estate appraisals until he was 83. Along the way Ab also became a real estate developer and built several houses in the Mitchell, Ont., area.
Ab was always involved in community activities. In 1990, after they sold the farm and moved to Stratford, Ont., he volunteered with the Horticultural Society and with their church.
Ab accomplished much in his lifetime, but his proudest legacy was his family.
James Albert Bowman is Ab's son.
submissions: lives@globeandmail.com

Toronto condo market hits the 'down' button

Author: Ladurantaye, Steve

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/toronto-condo-market-hits-down-button/docview/743957692/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "My gut instinct tells me the condo market is skewered right now," said Paul Johnston of Right At Home Realty Brokerage, the listing agent on the project. "It's been a hell of a year. At the beginning, we finally had buyers after a year of banging our heads on the wall looking for them. But I think this year's deals have already been done."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Toronto+condo+market+hits+the+%27down%27+button&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-16&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Toronto+condo+market+hits+the+%27down%27+button&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-16&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Though prices remain firm, sales have slowed and supply is surging in Canada's condo capital
REAL ESTATE REPORTER
The developer thought it was a brilliant idea: Build a penthouse on top of an existing condo building in a chic Toronto neighbourhood to take advantage of the city's insatiable lust for expensive real estate.
For $1.8-million, the new owner could walk into a brand new, 1,800-square-foot condo designed to her specifications. That was the idea, anyway. But the listing in prime Rosedale hit the market in February, just as sales were beginning to slow for real estate of all kinds, and no one was interested in the unit its agent has dubbed "Project Perch."
The property is still for sale, but it no longer comes with an actual condo. Before a single brick was in place, the developer gave up and decided to try a different approach. For $599,000, a prospective buyer now gets blueprints, a stack of planning approvals and a list of local builders who can finish the project on the cheap.
"My gut instinct tells me the condo market is skewered right now," said Paul Johnston of Right At Home Realty Brokerage, the listing agent on the project. "It's been a hell of a year. At the beginning, we finally had buyers after a year of banging our heads on the wall looking for them. But I think this year's deals have already been done."
Following a spring marked by record sales and prices, growing evidence suggests that the air is finally beginning to go out of Toronto's remarkably resilient condo market. The debate in real estate circles is now this: is it a temporary lull or the harbinger of a more serious decline?
The outlook for one the key economic generators in Canada's largest city - a business that produces large numbers of construction and service jobs - hangs on that question.
Toronto is North America's new condo capital: Last year, developers completed about 16,000 units, twice as many as in New York and three times as many as Vancouver. As such, it's closely watched as a barometer for the sector.
In July, the picture turned negative. The Toronto Real Estate Board said last week the number of sales in the city fell 25 per cent compared with June. While prices have yet to waver, anecdotal evidence of a slowdown is rife. Bay Street office workers point out that many of the newly opened condo towers in the downtown core appear to be devoid of all signs of human life.
Meanwhile, the supply of condos is surging. In the second quarter, buyers had a record 10,997 units to choose from. Another 34,089 units are under construction. Eighty-eight per cent of those units have already been sold, but another 5,000 units are expected to begin construction in the next three months.
An estimated 40 per cent of Toronto condos are owned by investors - many of them from overseas - who often buy multiple units and rent them out. That's in contrast to the rest of the residential property market, which is dominated by people who live in what they own.
If the market were to weaken, and those investors disappeared, new projects would find it much harder to meet their sales and financing goals. Canadian banks typically require that a developer presell at least 70 per cent of the units in each building before the bank hands over any money.
In a worst case, investors might choose to cut their losses and rush to sell their condos rather than stick around and hope for a gradual recovery.
But not everyone is convinced that a downturn would spark a stampede to the exits.
"You hear about how so much of the market is made up of investors, and to me that's not a scary thing," said George Carras, president of RealNet Canada Inc., a tracker of real estate data. "These people aren't investing to lose money; they are patient and plan to stick around."
Condo prices have performed far better than equities in recent years, according to an index compiled by Mr. Carras's company. And he believes the market's fundamentals remain strong. Toronto needs about 40,000 housing units a year to keep up with immigration, he said. Restrictive building policies have made it difficult to build new communities of single-family homes within the city, forcing developers to build up instead of out.
But while demand might be there, it's unclear when the market will bump against the limits of what people can afford. Prices have run up dramatically over the past few years. In 2003, new condos in Toronto sold at $294 per square foot on average. Last quarter, it was $565, or 92-per-cent higher. As unemployment remains high and consumer debt sits at the highest level on record, worries grow that the market is no longer tilted toward the smart investor.
"Condo owners shouldn't assume they'll always be able to sell their units at a profit," said Kurt Rosentreter, a senior financial adviser at Manulife Securities Inc., who has been warning his clients off the asset class for the past year despite surging prices. "You see the big price gains, but you have to wonder about a breaking point - and that would be dangerous for everyone."
So far, prices are holding firm: In the second quarter, the average selling price in Toronto gained 1 per cent to $331,000. And despite slowing sales, developers are asking more for less. The average asking price for the 23 projects launched in the last three months was $565 a square foot, a 12-per-cent increase from the same time last year.
"The big concern is we're continuing to push pricing in the new sale market, and as you look at the rents the investors are able to charge, they certainly aren't moving higher at the same rate," said Ben Myers, executive vice-president of tracking firm Urbanation. "You have to wonder what happens next."

Title: Toronto condo market hits the 'down' button

Staking a claim in Muskoka - without breaking the bank

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/staking-claim-muskoka-without-breaking-bank/docview/742632829/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: For the structures of the Muskoka Bay Club, Mr. [Peter Freed] has taken a largely neo-traditional approach to architectural styling, with much local stone and exposed timber framing and gabling on show. Artistically admirable modern cottages have been designed and built in various districts of the Ontario countryside, but, given this development's proximity to a small town, backward-looking, respectful contextualism makes a certain sense.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Staking+a+claim+in+Muskoka+-+without+breaking+the+bank&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-13&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Staking+a+claim+in+Muskoka+-+without+breaking+the+bank&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2010-08-13&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   jmays@globeandmail.com
Though I am not one of them - I always opt for holidays in another city, preferably far away - I know that the vacation dream of a great many Torontonians involves having a perfect house in Ontario's getaway country. But the demand for such places on or near our sparkling northern lakes is high, and the supply is scanty and costly. It's not surprising, then, that some enterprising entrepreneurs have taken to building rural Ontario retreats for city folks that are more affordable than the usual cottage.
The example I'm thinking of today is the Muskoka Bay Club, which occupies an 850-acre site adjacent to the town of Gravenhurst and includes an award-winning 18-hole golf course designed by Doug Carrick. (I understand Mr. Carrick is a master at the art of golf courses.) This four-seasons project (which, like the golf course, has won numerous awards) is the handiwork of Toronto developer Peter Freed, who is best known for his thicket of modernistic residential buildings near the intersection of Bathurst Street and King Street West.
For the structures of the Muskoka Bay Club, Mr. Freed has taken a largely neo-traditional approach to architectural styling, with much local stone and exposed timber framing and gabling on show. Artistically admirable modern cottages have been designed and built in various districts of the Ontario countryside, but, given this development's proximity to a small town, backward-looking, respectful contextualism makes a certain sense. The influence of Muskoka's building practices from long ago is also evident in the old-fashioned 17,000-square-foot clubhouse by Toronto revivalist architect Richard Wengle.
The residences of the club come in three formats. The largest (1,350 square feet to more than 4,000 square feet) are the "homes," which range in price from about $465,000 to more than $1-million. The "villas" go up in area to 2,200 square feet, and they cost about $460,000 to more than $600,000. The least expensive units ($290,000 to about $370,000) are the "lofts," and they enclose spaces from 819 square feet to 1,040 square feet.
When it came to designing the lofts - the most recent offering at Muskoka Bay Club - Mr. Freed has indulged his modernist inclinations more freely than in the other edifices on the property. The two-storey open-plan suites, with their tall rock-framed fireplaces and expanses of glazing, are situated in flat-roofed buildings trimmed in wood and stone. In contrast to the romantic architectural styling of the houses and villas, the loft structures are barracks-like - though their brown cladding and finishes in natural materials could help them blend in a bit with the site's other structural types.
Whatever your taste or budget may be, however, ownership at the club brings with it amenities galore. The clubhouse, for instance, contains an indoor-outdoor dining area, a bar and grill and the Muskoka Room restaurant for finer dining, a fitness centre and spa rooms, and even babysitting facilities. Outside features include a swimming pool and tennis courts. For owners of villas or lofts who plan to live in them only part of the year, the club runs a rental service - a handy program for city-dwellers making a transition to full-time residence in the country.
The one amenity missing in this scheme - some may consider it essential - is direct access from the houses and suites to the open water. But at least for city slickers who don't care for boating or lake swimming, there are certain compensations here. One is the nearness of Gravenhurst, which opens toward Lake Muskoka and features various memorials to the town's ship-building past and a waterfront and wharf recently renovated to the tune of $170-million.
Meanwhile, back in the city core, another one of Mr. Freed's real estate ventures has opened its doors. It's the ultra-cool Thompson Hotel, near the corner of Bathurst and King West. I have heard rumours of a fabulous and very exclusive garden atop the mixed-use condo-hotel complex - a place restricted to hotel guests, condo dwellers and VIPs on a secret list Mr. Freed is keeping close to his chest. If I ever get invited up there, I'll let you know. Since I am devoted to cities and urban life and have no interest in visiting spots where bears and snakes may be lurking, this roof garden may be as close to nature as I ever get in this lifetime.
