He lived to see the torch lit

Author: Martin, Sandra

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/he-lived-see-torch-lit/docview/382612026/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: He immediately began working as a management trainee at Gulf Oil in Calgary. On the side he sold Fuller Brush products to supplement the family income, using a sales routine that he could re-enact half a century later. "You knock on the door, somebody opens, and you shoot that aerosol hand cream in their hands and you say: 'Now, rub it in, then put your hands under the tap. It's like an invisible glove of lanolin.' " Swearing that it really did feel that way, Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+lived+to+see+the+torch+lit&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-24&amp;spage=S.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=He+lived+to+see+the+torch+lit&amp;author=Martin%2C+Sandra&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-24&amp;spage=S.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The 2010 Games were the final test in the career of a businessman who defied the odds in many ways
smartin@globeandmail.com
They don't come much tougher than Jack Poole, the multimillionaire Vancouver real estate developer. Yet, when his pal, British Columbia Premier Gordon Campbell asked him to head up the city's bid for the 2010 Olympics, Mr. Poole agreed to sideline himself in the middle of a hot construction market to work gratis - and pay his own expenses - as chair of the Vancouver Organizing Committee for the 2010 Olympic and Paralympic Winter Games (VANOC).
"I joke that I gave him his first job and he gave me my last," Mr. Poole said in 2002. "I paid him $2.50 an hour [as a labourer waterproofing basements on a construction project near Smithers, B.C.] and he pays me $1 a year. So who got the best deal?" he asked jokingly of the province and the city he had called home since the early 1960s.
For nearly a decade, nothing deterred Mr. Poole - including devastating treatment for pancreatic cancer. He built the bid team; oversaw the lobbying and marketing effort, which resulted in the IOC choosing Vancouver as the site for the games by a slender three vote margin over Pyeongchang, South Korea; endured a frustrating plebiscite campaign to fulfill a rash campaign promise made by mayoralty candidate Larry Campbell; and navigated the inevitable cost overruns and political turmoil that stuck like mud patties to the construction of the Olympic facilities.
"He's tough," Mr. Campbell said in 2003, in the early days of his solitary term as mayor. "I look at him and think, I don't want to go up an alley with this guy. He's a hockey player. He didn't get that nose from not getting into the corners."
For Mr. Poole, the Olympics were the final test in a career that had as many peaks and plunges as a roller coaster ride. "I've learned with the failures to bear them, and with the successes to savour them. They are the ones that make the failures worth bearing," he confided in an interview in 2003.
A horribly smashed leg from a car accident when he was a teenager ruined his dreams of a hockey career; the recession of the early 1980s toppled his first, precariously leveraged, real estate empire. From these debacles he learned to regroup and to hone his laissez-faire management style.
More of a big picture guy than a details person, his best leadership attribute was his ability to recruit smart, self-motivated and hard working people, such as VANOC CEO John Furlong. He derived his own pleasure from watching them act, grow and succeed.
"That's what I call psychological income," he said earlier this year. "That's what's given me my satisfaction in life, with all of my business experiences."
Even so, taking on the Olympics was a massive undertaking, not only for him and his hand-picked team, but for the province and the country. The process forced all levels of government to work together, a legacy that he felt was even more significant than hosting the Games. "If we can't deliver a win with that, it's not going to look good on my resumé, I can tell you that," he said just before Vancouver won the bid.
As the deadline for the Games approached, the question on everybody's mind was whether Mr. Poole could defy the medical odds in an even bigger struggle against pancreatic cancer, one of the most lethal forms of the disease. After diagnosis and radical treatment in 2007, he appeared to have made a miraculous recovery - so much so that earlier this year he was entertaining the possibility of carrying the Olympic torch through his home town of Mortlach, Saskatchewan on its journey from Athens to Vancouver.
"It might be fun, if time allowed, to be there when the torch goes through, but the chances are I'd probably fall down," he said with his typically self-deprecating humour. Nobody is laughing now.
His remission proved merely a respite in a deadly battle when surgeons removed a metastasized tumour in his intestine this summer. Even so, he rallied long enough for the Olympic torch to be ignited in Athens on Thursday. "I called him immediately afterwards to provide a play-by-play description," Mr. Furlong said in a statement, "and truly believe that Jack was then ready to say goodbye."
John (Jack) Wilson Poole was born April 14, 1933, in a house without electricity or plumbing, in a community so tiny that it barely rates a dot on most maps. He was the youngest of three sons of John Vigors Poole and his wife Edith (nee Golen). Mr. Poole worked at the grain elevator after his Massey-Harris farm equipment dealership went broke during the Depression and Mrs. Poole was the local postmistress.
If you looked at lanky Jack Poole carefully, you could find traces of his first nations heritage - five per cent Cree - in his high cheekbones and dark eyes, but he never made much publicly of his aboriginal background until he was awarded the National Aboriginal Achievement Award in the business and commerce category in March, 2007.
His claim came through an 18th century British ancestor, who arrived in Moose Factory on James Bay to work for the Hudson's Bay Company in 1776, and then married a Cree woman. "I think I'm six generations removed from the Cree lady," Mr. Poole said after the awards ceremony, "but I have a Metis card, and by definition, in Canada, I'm an aboriginal person. I've always been very proud of this fact - to have Canadian roots that go that far back."
In a profile for B.C. Business Magazine, Gary Mason wrote that Mr. Poole "idolized his parents, even his alcoholic father who ruined many a Christmas by getting drunk before noon." Aside from his drinking bouts, John Poole was a nurturing father, who "bathed" his son in praise, helping him develop "a high self-esteem not common among children of alcoholics," he wrote.
The elder Poole also imparted two character building lessons: don't be quick to judge others; and live your life with integrity.
Along with his older brothers, Jack spent Grades 1 through 12 in a two room schoolhouse. Outside the classroom he played hockey, aiming to play defence in the NHL one day. That goal was shattered the summer he was 15 and working as crew on a highway paving project outside Lloydminster. One night, as he and some friends walked into town after dark, a car sideswiped them, leaving his best friend dead and him with his lower right leg "mangled and hanging on by the skin." For the rest of his days, he walked with a slight limp.
On the excruciating train journey back to Moose Jaw to have his triple compound fracture repaired, he managed a couple of philosophical insights: life can change in a flash; and it consists of a series of obstacles to be overcome with perseverance, ingenuity and grit.
Life whacked him again when, aged 16, he impregnated his high school girlfriend, Marilyn Pollock. While most kids his age were thinking about jobs and a date for the senior prom, he became a hasty bridegroom and a teenaged father.
Construction provided the tuition so he could enroll in civil engineering at the University of Saskatchewan - all those summers swallowing dust on highway projects had inspired him to acquire the credentials to run job sites. He graduated in 1954, the same year that he won the university's heavyweight wrestling championship.
He immediately began working as a management trainee at Gulf Oil in Calgary. On the side he sold Fuller Brush products to supplement the family income, using a sales routine that he could re-enact half a century later. "You knock on the door, somebody opens, and you shoot that aerosol hand cream in their hands and you say: 'Now, rub it in, then put your hands under the tap. It's like an invisible glove of lanolin.' " Swearing that it really did feel that way, Mr. Poole bragged that "there wasn't anyone who didn't buy that hand cream," in an interview with The Globe's Rod Mickleburgh before Vancouver's final IOC pitch in Prague.
After two years at Gulf Oil, Mr. Poole found his calling: heading up the construction division of Engineered Homes in Edmonton. He did so well that he was transferred to Vancouver to start up a West Coast office in the early 1960s. Just as EH won a contract to build a hundred homes for a mining company in Northern B.C., the head office in Calgary took a financial tumble and recalled him to Edmonton.
He didn't want to go. Instead, he persuaded Graham Dawson, son of the man who had built the Burrard Street Bridge in Vancouver, to buy EH's B.C. assets and form a new company called Daon Development Corporation. Initially, Daon built housing in resource towns from Prince Rupert to Port Alice, but eventually the company burgeoned into one of the largest real estate development empires in North America.
Daon's exponential growth was fuelled by massive debts at spiralling interest rates. When the 1982 recession hit, customers vanished and Daon owned $2.3-billion to 47 banks at double digit interest rates. The company survived, but it took two years, more than $20-million in legal fees and a protection plan that saw a phalanx of banks taking back shares in Daon.
"My personal wealth went from a paper worth of $100-million to a negative worth of $5-million," he admitted later. Amidst the financial chaos, his marriage, which had survived the birth of four daughters and the death of his infant son from the severest form of spina bifida, foundered. When the Pooles divorced in 1983, after more than 30 years of marriage, he had nothing but debts.
Bizarrely, life was both tough and blessed, for it was about this time, as he was crawling back to solvency - Bell Canada Enterprises acquired 68 per cent of Daon's common shares by March, 1985 - that he met Darlene Young. They married on March 21, 1987. Two years later, when he finally resigned from BCE Developments, he reportedly had $20-million in profits in his pocket.
Through a friend, Mr. Poole met David Podmore, a key player on Expo 86 in Vancouver, just as the exhibition was wrapping up and Mr. Podmore was sniffing around for new projects. Together, with a group of people including labour leader Ken Georgetti, they formed Vancouver Land Corporation (VLC) on June 1, 1989, a private/public company capitalized by union pension funds. They engaged in a joint venture to build low cost housing in Vancouver under the encouraging eye of Mr. Poole's pal and fellow Liberal, then mayor Gordon Campbell, himself a former property developer.
VLC moved into market-rate condos when the rental market fell apart and then morphed into Greystone Properties, which eventually became Concert Properties, now one of the largest and most successful construction companies in the province. Mr. Poole's money management and previous construction dealings came under intense scrutiny when Mr. Campbell, by then premier of B.C., appointed his friend to chair VANOC in 2003.
In fact, as Mr. Podmore complained two years before the start of the Games, taking on big civic projects such as chairing VANOC, is bad, rather than good, for business. Certainly that is true in an economic sense, but as Mr. Poole and his board of directors appreciated, community service is the best way to accrue cultural and social capital.
Life walloped Mr. Poole again in 2007, when, nearly 25 years after he had survived prostate cancer, he was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. Refusing to succumb passively to an almost certain death sentence, he had surgery in Vancouver and then signed up for a $60,000 experimental course of treatment at Virginia Mason Medical Centre in Seattle, Washington. For 40 days he was bombarded with radiation, topped by toxic doses of chemotherapy three times a week.
The brutal regimen left him so gaunt his close friends barely recognized him and even he confessed that the treatment "puts you on your knees," a rare admission from a man, described by Mr. Furlong as, "made of iron."
Although he was declared cancer free early this year, he was back under the surgeon's scalpel at the beginning of July. In a five hour operation, doctors removed a tumour containing pancreatic cancer cells from his intestine, but had to leave another one intact because of its location.
"This is not the way the story was supposed to go," Mr. Poole told Globe columnist Gary Mason in July. "But ... you just deal with what you're handed. You have no choice, do you?"
JACK POOLE, OC, OBC
John (Jack) Poole was born in Mortlach, Saskatchewan on April 13, 1933. He died of complications from pancreatic cancer in hospital in Vancouver early on Oct. 22, 2009. Mr. Poole, who was 76, leaves his second wife Darlene, four daughters, a stepson and his extended family.

Full text: THIS WEEK / HIGHLIGHTS
FRIDAY
OCTOBER 23
REAL ESTATE
House Hunters
HGTV, 7 p.m.
Real-estate veteran Suzanne Whang facilitates the home-buying process for helpless singles, couples and families in this lively series. Tonight she's at the beck and call of Heath and Cara, a young couple looking to purchase a house in Nashville. Their wish list includes at least four bedrooms and two bathrooms, but first Suzanne has to impart a lesson on home prices in the country-music mecca.
REALITY
Supernanny
ABC, CITY-TV, 8 p.m.
Brisk British nanny Jo Frost returns for a sixth season of correcting dysfunctional Americans, one family at a time. The new show finds her moving in with the blended clan of Jason and Dawn Colier in Cleveland. Dad Jason spoils his three young sons, while railing at his 13-year-old stepdaughter Madison; his wife Dawn is caught in the middle and afraid to take sides. With the family on the verge of collapse, Supernanny advises the parents to shape up or seek out a divorce lawyer.
HISTORY
History's Secrets
History, 9 p.m.
The fate of famed aviatrix Amelia Earhart continues to confound historians and inspire conspiracy theorists. Earhart was one of the most famous people in America back in the thirties, courtesy of her successful solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean. During her 1937 attempt to circumnavigate the globe, she went missing somewhere over the central Pacific Ocean. Since then, her disappearance has inspired countless theories that she was captured and killed by Japanese, or that she lived the rest of her days as an island castaway.
DRAMA
Flashpoint
CTV, 10 p.m.
Back with gritty new episodes and earning knockout ratings - more than 1.6-million viewers for last Friday's broadcast - Flashpoint continues to be the success story of Canadian dramatic television. Tonight's show features guest star Michael Riley ( Being Erica ) as radio talk host Pat Cosgrove, who takes a prominent politician hostage. As the SRU team race to find his secret remote location, Cosgrove stages a live on-air trial for a homicide he believes the man committed years before.
SATURDAY
OCTOBER 24
RETRO
It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown
YTV, 7 p.m.
Prep the kids for Halloween - or relive your own childhood memories - with this animated special from 1966. The story features all the principal characters from the comic strip Peanuts , but focuses largely on Linus, who waits anxiously for Halloween and the arrival of the Great Pumpkin -a mythical creature that will supposedly visit the town's most sincere pumpkin patch and deliver toys to boys and girls who believe in him. Elsewhere, the other kids go trick-or-treating and poor old Charlie Brown gets a bag of rocks. A Halloween classic.
REALITY
Scream Queens
Star!, 8 p.m.
One of last season's best new reality shows, Scream Queens brings together 10 unknown actresses looking to break into the horror-film genre. With a high-profile prize at stake - a role in Saw VI - the women are put through a fright-film boot camp and subjected to demanding acting challenges. Tonight, the remaining contestants put their screaming abilities to the test in a Blair Witch re-enactment. Get out the earplugs.
MOVIE
The Devil Wears Prada
W, 9 p.m.
Film diva Meryl Streep earned strong reviews - and her record 14th best-actress Oscar nomination - for her performance in this 2006 feature based on a bestselling novel. Streep morphs into the role of Miranda Priestly, the demanding and shrewish editor of a successful fashion magazine; Anne Hathaway plays Andy, a recent college graduate who suffers much abuse as Miranda's latest assistant. The scene-stealer is character actor Stanley Tucci as the magazine's pragmatic art director Nigel.
COMEDY
Steven Wright: When the Leaves Blow Away
Comedy, 10 p.m.
The career of deadpan comic Steven Wright is laid out for examination in this unique comedy special. The program begins with a 2006 performance at Toronto's Elgin Theatre, in which the frizzy-haired standup dryly expounds on such topics as baby monitors and his placebo addiction. The film also includes clips of Wright's early career performances and his existential short comedy film One Soldier .

CNN special correspondent Soledad O'Brien hosts this two-night, four-hour report confirming that Latinos comprise America's largest minority group. In the first half, O'Brien profiles several families with the surname Garcia - now one of the 10 most popular last names in the U.S. - and interviews such prominent show-business people as Edward James Olmos and Eva Longoria Parker.
BIOGRAPHY
Killer Comebacks
TVtropolis, 9 p.m.
The resurgence of eighties movie mainstay Mickey Rourke comes under scrutiny in this unauthorized profile. Following his breakout roles in Body Heat (1981) and Diner (1982), Rourke became a solid leading man who garnered critical praise for his performances in films like Barfly and Year of the Dragon . Following his inexplicable attempt to become a professional boxer in the nineties, Rourke spent a decade trying to reestablish his acting career, which finally occurred with his Oscar-nominated turn in the 2008 feature The Wrestler .
REALITY
Restaurant Makeover
Food, 11 p.m.
The precarious restaurant business takes a competitive bent in this reality-style series. The format: Two top-gun restaurateurs are given one week to relaunch a flagging restaurant from top to bottom. Tonight, renowned chef Lynn Crawford and designer Cherie Stinson tackle a restaurant named Lucero's, whose owner is regretting her decision to focus on Mexican food. The first challenge is to renovate the eatery's shabby interior.
MONDAY
OCTOBER 26
HISTORY
Exploring Hitler's Munich
History, 7 p.m.
This program reveals the storied history behind the German city once beloved by Adolf Hitler. According to historians interviewed in the film, the National Socialist Party was first formed in Munich's beer cellars. At the height of the Second World War, Hitler frequently referred to the city as the "capital of the movement." The program also reveals the German leader's secret plans to turn Munich into a sprawling super-city, which thankfully never came to fruition.
FOOD
David Rocco's Dolce Vita
Food, 7:30 p.m.
Celebrity chef David Rocco proudly explores his lineage in this cooking series filmed in Italy. In the fourth season, Rocco and his family are settled in a rustic farmhouse situated in the Tuscan countryside. In tonight's show, they participate in the annual harvest and pressing of olives into olive oil, one of the region's principal exports. And since he's a gourmet chef, Rocco naturally digs out his family's favourite recipes featuring olive oil.
REALITY
Intervention
A & E, 9 p.m.
In one of the most stark entries in the series, Intervention profiles a young addict named Cristy. Born into a tight-knit Catholic family, Cristy spent her teen years exploring the artistic endeavours of dance and jazz music, and aspired to become a fashion designer. She later became hopelessly hooked on alcohol and crystal meth, and now earns a living as a stripper in a seedy club. Her family's attempt to get Cristy into rehab is heartbreaking and real.
DRAMA
Castle
ABC, A, 10 p.m.
On the eve of Halloween, novelist-sleuth Nick Castle (Nathan Filion) and NYPD detective Kate Beckett (Stana Katic) are summoned to a graveyard where the body of a young man sporting vampire fangs has been found with a wooden stake driven through his heart. The case takes the pair into the heart of New York's underground vampire-fetish community, where they discover that the man's murder connects to a graphic novel he was writing shortly before his death. Be afraid.

OCTOBER 27

Food, 6:30 p.m.
Chef Michael Smith gears up for Halloween in this special episode in the series. Mischievous by nature, Smith decides to put the chill into the neighbours' and his own children by mixing tricks into his treats. Throwing caution, and dental care, to the wind, Chef Smith first prepares brownies in ice-cream cones and tops them with homemade marshmallow. Next he creates his own version of the traditional favourites of candied apples and peanut brittle. But watch the kids' faces when Smith brings out his roasted eight-winged bat.

Vision, 8:30 p.m.
This series, which first aired from 1978 to 1981, has lost none of its cheeky charm. The show stars ex- Coronation Street regular Arthur Lowe as irascible Catholic parish priest Father Duddleswell, who tends to his flock while keeping an eye on the bottom line (translation: He's terribly stingy). His crustiness is offset by the young Father Neil (Daniel Abineri). Most storylines are blessedly simple. Tonight, Father Duddleswell steps in when a female war orphan brought up in the local convent falls in love with a rabbi's son. Heaven forbid.
DOCUMENTARY
Age of Terror
PBS, 10 p.m.
This documentary recalls a terrorist event several years before the tragedy of 9/11. In 1994, as an Air France plane was preparing to depart Algiers, four men entered the aircraft. Although they passed themselves off as Algerian officials, there were in fact members of the GIA, an Islamist extremist group. Two days elapsed and three passengers were executed before Algerian authorities allowed the flight to depart for Marseilles; once there, a commando team killed the terrorists and liberated the passengers. This program reveals the GIA's real goal: to crash the plane in the middle of Paris.
DRAMA
the forgotten
ABC, 10 p.m.
Launched last month, this crime drama has already lived up to its name: Most viewers have already forgotten it's on. The concept casts former movie regular Christian Slater as a former cop heading up an ad hoc group of civilian volunteers trying to provide closure to the families of unidentified murder victims. Tonight, the team investigates the death of a John Doe found buried at a popular vacation spot. The only clue is a stray dog standing vigil over the shallow grave.

In tonight's back-to-back episodes tonight, the Little Couple jet off to Disney World, but their holiday plans hit a snag when Jen gets a monster migraine. DOCUMENTARY
Ben: Diary of a Heroin Addict
TVO, 10 p.m.
This British documentary chronicles the slow and steady decline of a heroin addict. The film follows the final days of Ben Rogers, hailing from a middle-class family in the village of Alton in Staffordshire, who spent more than a decade battling his addiction to heroin. In diary style, the program follows the young man's stints in and out of rehab, to no avail, and includes brutally graphic footage of Rogers injecting himself in various areas of his body once the veins in his arms give out. A dark and haunting portrait of addiction.

A canvas in search of a painter

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canvas-search-painter/docview/382615546/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "You just keep walking and walking and you're still on the property," says the agent. "It's so expansive. Some is quite wild."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+canvas+in+search+of+a+painter&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+canvas+in+search+of+a+painter&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With the old mansion lost to fire, the storied Nokomis estate needs a new vision
967 NORTH SHORE RD., HOWE ISLAND, ONT.
WHAT: A storied estate known as Nokomis, set in 28 acres overlooking the Bateau Channel in the St. Lawrence River. The island property offers more than 3,500 feet of waterfront, a gatehouse, gazebo, refurbished barn, a marina complex and five tiny islets.
ASKING PRICE: $3.750-million
TAXES: $9,848.00 (2009)
AGENT: Royal LePage Real Estate Services Ltd., Johnston & Daniel Division (Carolyn McIntire Smyth)
The historic estate known as Nokomis is a property in need of a house.
The mansion that once stood on the land was destroyed by fire, rebuilt, and consumed by fire again.
In 1899, the property was purchased by industrialist William Nichols who, with his wife Hannah, built a summer retreat. A kitchen fire sparked the first conflagration in 1914.
The 10,000-square foot house was rebuilt, and that sprawling 14-bedroom lodge also burned down in 2003. Firefighters arrived at the scene after being alerted by an alarm inside the house and found the dwelling engulfed by flames and partly collapsed.
According to reports in the Kingston Whig-Standard, the original house commissioned by Mr. Nichols was of a Tudor-style stucco and timber construction.
When that burned down, Mr. Nichols hired architect Frank T. Lent to create its replacement. The new house had a steep roof and butterfly-shaped layout with a wide veranda overlooking the channel.
Over the years, the property changed hands a few times, with owners who used it variously for a convalescent home, a summer camp and a bed-and-breakfast resort. One prominent former owner was the author Mazo de la Roche, who was born in Ontario in 1879. Ms. de la Roche wrote romance novels and was best known for the family chronicle Whiteoaks of Jalna, which was also the inspiration for a mini-series for Canadian television.
To visit the property today, prospective buyers need to make their way to Howe Island, which is one of the Thousand Islands. (The island is located in the St. Lawrence River, in Frontenac County.)
A few minutes' drive east of Kingston, visitors will find a bucolic landing and two car ferries serving the island.
The ferries don't follow any particular schedule - they just make the short journey across the channel when enough people and their vehicles arrive to make the trip worthwhile.
The gentle Howe Island is about 13 kilometres long and 5 kilometres wide, with about 500 permanent residents.
On a recent tour of the property, real estate agent Carolyn McIntire Smyth pointed out the long shoreline and lingered at the 2,000-foot stone sea wall.
"It makes a beautiful walkway all the way around," says Ms. McIntire Smyth.
The water of the Bateau Channel surrounds the land on three sides. The marina includes three covered boat docks, each 50 feet long.
"Three yachts could be visiting at once," says Ms. McIntire Smyth.
Guests and residents can set their chairs on a 200-foot deep water dock or jump from the high diving board. On land, a rustic shed is used for storing small boats and equipment.
"It's a pretty little boathouse," says the agent.
Children can play on a small sandy beach. Nearby, a footbridge crosses an inlet.
Water lilies float in the bay, and a great blue heron often stands at the water's edge. The perennial gardens and undulating lawns are surrounded by deep stands of trees.
"The combination of some landscaped and some wild is magical," says Ms. McIntire Smyth.
Visitors to the estate will find little remaining of the majestic house, but among the ruins, the fireplace still stands. Large oil-painted panels that once adorned the building are now housed at Queen's University in Kingston.
Rumours among the locals suggest some trespassers held an unsanctioned party and a bonfire at the time of the latest fire, says the agent.
But new owners can still be accommodated: A gatehouse perched next to some woods has 1,800 square feet of living space. It offers a renovated kitchen with stainless steel appliances and a porch overlooking green lawns stretching down to a quiet bay. The large master bedroom upstairs has a cathedral ceiling and views of the water.
Ms. McIntire Smyth suggests that a new owner might use the gatehouse as a residence during construction of another landmark dwelling.
One owner could build a country house of great elegance, says the agent, or the buyer could build a more modest home and sell four other lots. Agreements allowing severance into five parcels are already in place, she says.
A refurbished barn has been used as the setting for large social events and parties. At other times, it provides storage space for wooden boats.
The land also offers rolling hills, wilderness and trails.
"You just keep walking and walking and you're still on the property," says the agent. "It's so expansive. Some is quite wild."
Small stone ruins, such as a former pumphouse, add a picturesque quality to the landscape.
"Imagine being a child and getting to play in this - you have a fort already built for you," says Ms. McIntire Smyth.
Several carved wood sculptures oversee the grounds. Offshore, five tiny islands dotting the St. Lawrence River are included.
"They're just fun to have as part of your estate," says Ms. McIntire Smyth.
The channel is a popular - and at times challenging - route for sailors.
The boat traffic on the channel in front of the cottage is relatively quiet, she says.
"It's lovely to see the odd sailboat pass by."

A blueprint for new homes on a forgotten shore

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/blueprint-new-homes-on-forgotten-shore/docview/382615335/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's a gloriously beautiful park," Mr. [David Wex] says. "They didn't take any of the industry down. There's this hard infrastructure and then parkland and prairie."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+blueprint+for+new+homes+on+a+forgotten+shore&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+blueprint+for+new+homes+on+a+forgotten+shore&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Along the Don River, a post-industrial wasteland amid high-speed traffic is set to be reborn
cireland@globeandmail.com
In some ways, it's unfortunate that the cement factory and the train shed were long ago demolished.
David Wex, a developer who will bring housing to the manufacturing wasteland of Toronto's West Don Lands, likely would have found a way to incorporate those industrial remnants into the neighbourhood that will rise up over the next few years.
As it is, the partner at Urban Capital Property Group will have to rely on a busy Don Valley Parkway overpass and the Adelaide Street ramps to provide the urban context for the towers and buildings of glass and metal.
Standing at the windblown apex of the overpass as cars whizzed by on a recent afternoon, Mr. Wex leaned over the railing and pointed out the progress that marks the desolate landscape below.
Behind the blue construction hoardings is the site of River City, which will one day combine lofts, condominium towers and townhouses in an area of parks, stores and cafes on the banks of the Don River.
The way the buildings are designed, he explains, it's almost as if the cars travelling over the ramps will be running through the complex.
"The ramps are both very interesting and also a challenge."
Mr. Wex handed that challenge to Montreal-based architectural firm Saucier + Perrotte and, with his Urban Capital partner Mark Reeve, submitted their design to an international competition run by Waterfront Toronto.
"I think the thing that won it for us is we understand the beauty of industry and nature," he said.
Mr. Wex pointed to a bulldozer crawling over a massive mound of earth. That berm will protect the finished dwellings from the river, should it ever swell beyond its banks. Dodging six lanes of traffic, Mr. Wex reaches the opposite side of the overpass and points out the sites for two more phases.
A park created in the underpass will connect the buildings.
The site where Peter's Taxi Ltd. and a gravel parking lot now stand will eventually become part of the new neighbourhood. The Victorian-era smokestacks of the Distillery District are just down the road.
Cities around the world are grappling with brownfield redevelopment. Mr. Wex points to the remarkable result at Duisburg-Nord Landscape Park in Germany, which has become the prototype for architects and planners who aim to rejuvenate the abandoned yards and rusting factories that exist in many cities.
In Duisburg, architect Peter Latz and his colleagues allowed nature to reclaim the industrial land surrounding a decommissioned metal works.
Visitors now climb Blast Furnace No. 5. for a panoramic view. Cooling tanks, railway tracks and slag heaps have all become part of the landscape.
"It's a gloriously beautiful park," Mr. Wex says. "They didn't take any of the industry down. There's this hard infrastructure and then parkland and prairie."
Some proponents of similar plans in other cities have had trouble selling the schemes to local politicians.
Mr. Wex says the design he presented had to meet the environmental and community goals of Waterfront Toronto. Many of the units will be family-friendly.
Waterfront Toronto chief executive John Campbell says his team was looking for a developer who wouldn't churn out the "same old sausages" for the West Don Lands renewal.
"We're not peddling real estate: We're here to build a community."
He says the Saucier + Perrotte design addressed that vision with units that can accommodate families as well as young singles.
"They really impressed us with the thinking they put into this design."
The development, which will have four phases, will comprise 900 loft-style condominiums, penthouses and townhouses.
In Phase 1, a five-storey building will hold about 100 units. Phase 2 will be a 14-storey building with about 230 units, and a food store below. The second structure will be connected to the first by a three-storey, industrial-looking glass bridge.
Phase 3 will consist of four glass mini-towers that combine to make an 11-storey building sharing a courtyard with Phase 1. Phases 4 and 5 will be towers of 24 and 10 storeys with boutiques and restaurants at their bases.
Work will start next spring, with the first residents able to move their furniture in in 2012 if the current schedule holds.
Mr. Wex says the Saucier + Perrotte design emphasizes the interplay between light and dark with expanses of glass and metal panels.
"They're very much about drama."
At the same time, the industrial aesthetic of the buildings will contrast with the soft land forms and gardens, he says.
The team led by Gilles Saucier and André Perrotte - whose firm was honoured this year for architectural excellence by the Royal Architectural Institute of Canada - has undertaken designs in Nigeria, Japan, China and the Middle East, including Mecca.
The firm has experience with preserving the cultural heritage of cities: Their plan for refurbishing the Port of Montreal and Silo No. 5 is not a break with the past, they explain, but a recognition of the way industrial labour has enriched the area.
At West Don Lands, Mr. Wex is also overseeing the renovation of an old foundry that will hold a model suite. He has no plans to clean up the grimy bricks of the building's exterior.
The developer, who lives in Toronto's Beaconsfield neighbourhood, says this type of infill project is a niche for Urban Capital, which has built condos and lofts in such previously undeveloped areas as Ottawa's Byward Market and Montreal's industrial areas.
River City will help connect disparate neighbourhoods in downtown Toronto.
"This is stitching the city together from really strong areas like Leslieville through to the Distillery and Corktown."
The builder says cities are finding new ways to combine industry with housing and parklands.
"I'm not a fan of sprawl," Mr. Wex says. "The way we develop cities is important for our environment and our economy. We've been bad at it for 30 years."

On the second floor of a brick building in the historic Corktown community, this one-bedroom suite drew multiple offers in a short amount of time, says agent Sandra Pate.
"It's in a small building, and there had not been a sale in there for quite some time," says Ms. Pate. "This one was really popular because it's a low rise, it's rarely available and it's a great location."
Locals and tourists alike flock to the galleries, boutique shops and upscale restaurants in the Distillery District nearby, in addition to furniture shops, cafes and public transit along King Street.
The 800-square-foot unit also has several unusual perks, such as a spacious layout spanning the building's depth. This allows for east-facing windows in the living and dining area and a west-facing balcony off the master suite.
"You get the morning and afternoon sun, which is really nice," says Ms. Pate.
Furthermore, the principal room features a wood-burning fireplace, which is "pretty hard to find anywhere," says Ms. Pate. "Occasionally you find it on a high floor in a more expensive building."
Broadloom carpeting covers most areas, except for the ceramic tile in the kitchen. The latter is stocked with cooking appliances and stacked laundry machines.
A semi-ensuite bathroom completes the unit, which also comes with outdoor parking and a locker.
Part of the monthly fee of $268 pays for the upkeep of common areas, such as a gym and sauna.

CARLAW AND QUEEN

BANKING ON THE TUG OF PENDER HARBOUR

Author: Hadani Ditmars

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/banking-on-tug-pender-harbour/docview/382615012/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Whittakers - only a 15-minute boat ride or a 30-minute drive from Rockwater Resort - is a boutique development of 25 houses that engages craftsman and West Coast contemporary styles to form a singular aesthetic that embraces the spectacular site. Located in the Pender Harbour area, Whittakers overlooks a protected bay and deepwater marina.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BANKING+ON+THE+TUG+OF+PENDER+HARBOUR&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=BANKING+ON+THE+TUG+OF+PENDER+HARBOUR&amp;author=Hadani+Ditmars&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=S.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Whittakers, a new project on the Sunshine Coast, seeks to marry contemporary architecture with respect for the site in a spectacular landscape
There is still a pristine quality to parts of the Sunshine Coast, the bucolic 86-kilometre strip of coastline northwest of Vancouver.
But rapid development is at its heels, as the traditional forest and fishery industries (Gibsons, the main town on the Coast, was the local for the CBC's The Beachcombers ) are replaced by tourism and retirement homes for burnt-out city folk.
But the further north you go along the coast, the further you get from the madding crowds. Although in relative terms, a place like Gibsons (pop. 4,000 ) fast becoming a bedroom community of Vancouver, hardly represents the rat race.
A great introduction to the North part of the Sunshine Coast is found in Secret Cove, where the Rockwater Resort offers rustic luxury in the form of "tent houses" nestled into a cliffside forest. The heated, slate floored tents, complete with gas fireplaces and soaker tubs, let you rough it in style, with a small eco-footprint to boot.
Originally conceived as a way to bypass planning restrictions by erecting semi-permanent structures - and thus removing the need for the roads, parking spaces etc. - the tent houses are the ultimate green retreat. Only three trees were cut down on the entire site during construction and a winding wooden footbridge leads visitors to their abodes. A 25-minute seaplane ride from downtown Vancouver, Rockwater has become increasingly popular with those seeking refuge from urban stress.
But now the same partners who introduced the tent houses in 2008 have unveiled a permanent residence for those enamoured of the Secret Cove vibe and the lure of a relatively green lifestyle.
Whittakers - only a 15-minute boat ride or a 30-minute drive from Rockwater Resort - is a boutique development of 25 houses that engages craftsman and West Coast contemporary styles to form a singular aesthetic that embraces the spectacular site. Located in the Pender Harbour area, Whittakers overlooks a protected bay and deepwater marina.
Designed by Drew Rose of Stillpoint Architecture, the development offers seven prototype homes that give buyers the flexibility to incorporate personal choices into the design. At the same time, Whittakers insists on strict standards on colours (a limited palette of earth tone stains for the cedar shingle siding for example) and finishes, so as to avoid the unfortunate excesses (read: bright pink houses) of some nearby, less discerning developments.
Its location along an idyllic stretch of Pender Harbour is both the anchor point and the inspiration for the houses. Seven waterfront properties are designed to integrate organically into the sloping landscape, working carefully around existing trees. Free from the tyranny of a uniform grid, the varied topography of the homes combined with the native firs and pines on site offer the added bonus of increased privacy.
One waterfront home had its bolted cedar beam and glass front porch designed around an arbutus tree, which pokes out and upwards from a circular hole. The result is organic installation art, with the tree, the water and surrounding forest blending into a singular aesthetic.
Seven lots on the upland portion of the site will open into forest and meadow, at the same time as they capitalize on views of neighbouring Farrington Cove.
The seven prototype homes designed exclusively for Whittakers will be repeated several times throughout the site, allowing for a harmonious mirroring effect. Both the arts and crafts style and the more contemporary designs have common roots in the traditional "carpenter" built cottages of the West Coast.
The arts and crafts style homes feature low-sloped roofs with broad wing-like eaves, exposed beam and rafter tails. Cedar shingle siding engages with more durable metal roofing and expansive glazing draws in light and view. The more contemporary style homes feature modern shed and flat roofs with traditional exposed beams and knee-brace brackets.
All homes have two storeys as well as an open kitchen/living/dining area with entry, laundry/utility and pantry on the main floor. Buyers can choose from either a three bedroom or four-bedroom model, with some flexibility on the location of master bedrooms and basements depending on site conditions and preference.
Throughout, the relatively spare square footage (ranging from 1725 to 2350 square feet) of the homes is maximized with clever use of space and design features.
Consider the largest "C" type home. One that faces the waterfront makes judicious use of a step-down entry and staggered levels to great effect. As you walk inside, the open kitchen, living, dining area descends with the sloping site and embraces the harbour view with extensive glazing. Vaulted ceilings, peek-a-boo windows and skylights offer a heightened sense of light and space.
The bolted cedar beams lend a sense of tradition and textures play with the slate flooring bordered by cedar strips, while features like two-person stand up showers, soaker tubs and granite kitchen countertops offer luxurious comfort.
While many buyers intend to use their Whittakers homes as recreational ones, increasingly there is a trend toward year round residence. To sweeten the deal, owners are offered special discounts at the Rockwater Resort on everything from spa services to kayaking to a night in a tent house, as well as a year round "concierge" service which includes maintenance, cleaning and rental management.
Gazing out at the harbour, with a stunning view of Texada Island and a narcotic silence, broken only by the sound of gulls and the occasional kayak, it's hard to believe such a paradise is only a half-hour sea plane ride away from Vancouver.
Credit: SPECIAL TO THE GLOBE AND MAIL

Local history on loan

Author: Leblanc, Dave

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/local-history-on-loan/docview/382610964/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Atop a hill across from High Park subway station, what is today a seven-unit condominium was once the home of West Toronto Junction's second mayor, George Johnston St. Leger.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Local+history+on+loan&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Local+history+on+loan&amp;author=Leblanc%2C+Dave&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-23&amp;spage=G.4&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Annette Street library is the starting point for exploration of The Junction's secret history
daveleblanc@globeandmail.com
Pssst, wanna know a secret? The Toronto Public Library produces some of the best local history books around.
Want another one? Often, they're in disguise: The revised and expanded edition of The Most Attractive Resort in Town: Public Library Service in West Toronto Junction, 1888 - 2009 , for instance, is as much a history of the Junction as it is a history of the impressive library on Annette Street.
Okay, here's one more: If you haven't heard of architect James Augustus Ellis (1856 - 1935), it's high time you took a tour of the neighbourhood, as I did one bright and chilly mid-October day with the book's author, Barbara Myrvold. The occasion, if the book's re-release and a love of good architecture wasn't enough, was the 100th anniversary of the opening of the library, designed by Mr. Ellis and partner William Connery and built with funds obtained via a Carnegie grant.
We met in the library's foyer, upon which Ms. Myrvold took me to the basement level to collect local history expert David Wencer in the offices of the West Toronto Junction Historical Society (a tenant since 1997), and then up to the main reception area to see the gorgeous ceiling, uncovered by architects Henno Sillaste and Hiro Nakashima during a 1979 renovation.
"It really is the highlight of this library," she said.
Standing outside the Beaux-Arts building, she explained that when construction was under way it was determined the pillared entrance would face the front lawn of a private residence across the street; the purchase of an extra piece of property allowed a nudge to the west to line up with Medland Street and the view-corridor north to Dundas Street. She pointed, also, to the former Victoria Royce Presbyterian Church - now undergoing a conversion into condominiums - and told the story of Allan Berlin Rice, a member of the congregation. An occasional reporter for the Toronto Globe and chairman of the Toronto Junction Library Board, Mr. Rice was instrumental in securing the Carnegie grant.
We walked past the Ellis-designed 1909 Masonic Temple next door - Ms. Myrvold noted that most of the "movers and shakers" of the early town were Masons - and began our driving tour.
Surrounded by flaming autumn reds at 204 High Park Ave., is the former home of newspaper owner and real estate agent James T. Jackson, designed by Mr. Ellis and built in 1891. Today, it's home to Holy Cross Anglican Priory. After passing many grand homes along this wide thoroughfare, including one for a Heintzman Piano family member (the factory was located in the Junction), we navigated the gentle curve of Gothic Avenue (named "because it's shaped like a Gothic arch," explained Mr. Wencer) until we came to No. 32.
Atop a hill across from High Park subway station, what is today a seven-unit condominium was once the home of West Toronto Junction's second mayor, George Johnston St. Leger. An Ellis design built in 1889, it sits so close to Bloor Street it reminds us that the boundaries of the original town reached much further south than contemporary Torontonians place them: "I know a lot of people say, 'This isn't the Junction, this is High Park' but historically this is the Junction," explained Ms. Myrvold.
The original Romanesque revival bulk of Humberside Collegiate (formerly Toronto Junction High School, 1894) came to fruition during a brief partnership between Mr. Ellis and William Fingland, and we next stopped to admire the carved creatures flanking the entrance. It's a massive school, but Mr. Ellis displayed a deft hand at commissions of all sizes - office buildings such as Campbell Block on the northwest corner of Keele and Dundas, the Heydon House hotel (St. Clair Avenue West and Old Weston Road), small homes, large mansions, banks and the oldest continually operating synagogue in the city, the 1912 Knesseth Israel Synagogue on Maria Street - due to his early carpentry training by his father.
Born near Meaford, Ont., young James began his architectural career by branching out from carpentry into design and construction. Two years after designing the Meaford Fire Hall in 1887, he joined the Ontario Association of Architects. He relocated to West Toronto Junction in 1890, perhaps due to the commissions he'd already received from the Junction's founder and first mayor, Daniel Webster Clendenan.
We wrapped up the day with a look at a home on Glendonwynne Road and another at 24A Woodside Avenue built for John D. Farquhar in 1892, which, like many Ellis designs, reminds me of an Annex home, except that it's flanked by what are clearly builder's homes from the 1920s and thirties.
But that's the charm of the Junction: Houses, commercial and institutional buildings by a world-class architect rub elbows with those of lesser stock. Once a gritty railroad town, it was annexed by the City of Toronto in 1909 and remained under the real estate radar for nine decades as a place with "a fierce, independent spirit," says Mr. Wencer. Since the late 1990s, however, the secret's been out as artists looking for cheap studio space and bargain-hunting hipster couples discover its rough charm.
And now, thanks to Ms. Myrvold's book, the secret of the Junction's colourful history, characters and architecture is as close as the nearest library.

notes on a scandal

Author: Beppi Crosariol

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/notes-on-scandal/docview/382615778/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Here's a riddle. France is the world's third-largest importer of Sicilian wine, almost all of it in bulk. Ever encounter a bottle of Sicilian vino on your French travels? Didn't think so. I don't want to suggest all or even most of France's many struggling winemakers are so unscrupulous as to goose their juice with richly coloured, high-alcohol stuff from Italy's sunny south.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=notes+on+a+scandal&amp;author=Beppi+Crosariol&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-21&amp;spage=L.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=notes+on+a+scandal&amp;author=Beppi+Crosariol&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-21&amp;spage=L.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: We reacted after a high-profile writer sounded off on Canadian wines made with foreign grapes. But, hey, isn't that Sicily I taste in French 'Burgundy'?
Canada has never been particularly good at scandals. And so it was with the great "cellared in Canada" wine fiasco. The squawking was over almost before it started. And, if you ask me, it wasn't much of a scandal in the first place.
Responding to a sudden chorus of consumer complaints, British Columbia and Ontario this month declared war on bottles made with cheap foreign grapes that traditionally were stocked on or near domestic-product shelves. About 40 such brands, typically made with juice from lower-cost regions such as Chile or Australia, are sold by Canadian companies, including Naked Grape from Vincor Canada, French Cross from Andrew Peller Ltd. and Sonora Ranch from Artisan Wine Co.
If you've ever bought one of those brands for a 100-mile dinner, you goofed big time. Ontario law requires that just 30 per cent of the juice in cellared in Canada wines be domestic, while B.C. law requires not a drop of domestic content. You should have bought a wine emblazoned with the Vintners Quality Alliance, or VQA, logo, which guarantees 100-per-cent domestic content and always has.
Lest I appear to be anything but a consumer advocate on this issue, let me say first that I support the initiatives. Clearer labels were necessary and separate store sections are good.
But this has been a tempest in a crystal decanter. Canada has a long history of importing bulk wine and grapes. Governments supported the practice largely to stimulate cash flow for new winery investments, and that's happened. The current "cellared in Canada" designation was endorsed by a broad coalition of growers, winemakers and government officials when it was hammered out in the mid-1990s.
But recently a number of boutique producers have been making noise about the plight of trying to market $50 pinot noirs alongside $8 and $9 bargain wines that appear to come from the same province. Admittedly, not an easy sell.
But few consumers or politicians seemed to care - until Jancis Robinson rode into town. The high-profile British wine writer visited B.C.'s Okanagan Valley this summer.
She followed up with a scathing column on her website under the headline "The Canadian con contd [continued]." Vincor was subsequently lambasted in the B.C. legislature for pasting its Olympic-sponsorship logo on bottles containing foreign juice - inventory that has since been voluntarily pulled.
"I think it is doing a disservice to real Canadian wine and its reputation abroad to continue with this misleading practice," Ms. Robinson wrote. "It is just so difficult to take Canadian producers seriously when they are allowed to mislead the wine-buying public to this extent."
I'll grant her the "disservice" part. But the rest of her complaint strikes me as unfair and, frankly, patronizing. Difficult to take Canadian producers seriously? Really? A Briton need not fly thousands of kilometres to British Columbia to uncover scandal in the wine industry. She need only cross the English Channel.
Here's a riddle. France is the world's third-largest importer of Sicilian wine, almost all of it in bulk. Ever encounter a bottle of Sicilian vino on your French travels? Didn't think so. I don't want to suggest all or even most of France's many struggling winemakers are so unscrupulous as to goose their juice with richly coloured, high-alcohol stuff from Italy's sunny south. But the Sicilian paradox would be interesting to ponder next time you're sipping an unusually rich glass of the house "Burgundy" at a French bistro.
Fact is, winemakers around the world, and especially in sun-deprived northern Europe, have a long history of misleading consumers. It's all supposed to be a thing of the past, of course. But it's clear illegal practices persist. In 2006, Georges Duboeuf, one of the richest and most famous producers in France, credited with turning Beaujolais Nouveau into a worldwide craze, was found guilty of defrauding consumers by mixing wine from lesser appellations into tanks of more expensive stuff. The case involved about 300,000 bottles worth of wine.
Was it an isolated case or rather the tip of an iceberg? I know where I'd place my bet. In 2007, a French consumer group published a report saying that up to a third of wines sold under France's hallowed appellation system could be from a different region than that listed on the label. The group, UFC-Que Choisir, pointed a finger at award panels for the Appellation d'Origine Contrôlee, or AOC, saying they were populated by local industry workers with vested interests. It declared the AOC system was turning into a joke.
I'm not condoning Canadian practices that have misled many consumers. Foreign content should be clearly labelled. But to single out Canada as some kind of cowboy frontier for snake-oil peddlers smacks to me of picking on the little guy.
You want seriously misleading but legal practices? In 2003, when New Zealand faced a harvest shortfall, a few prominent producers pulled a bold stunt. They started blending foreign juice into premium brands that had formerly contained 100-per-cent New Zealand wine. In one case, Montana, a large producer, made its Corbans Sauvignon Blanc with 54-per-cent Chilean grapes. Sacred Hill made two versions of its 2003 Whitecliff Estate Sauvignon Blanc - a 100-per-cent domestic bottling intended for restaurants and high-end retailers and a Chile-New Zealand blend for supermarkets.
It's easy to see conspiracies. But I'm not convinced our provincial retailers here were actively trying to hoodwink shoppers. If anything, stocking cellared in Canada wines next to the VQA offerings, many made by the same parent companies, seems to me a simple matter of merchandising logic and convenience.
And, frankly, there are plenty of Naked Grape and French Cross consumers who don't care where their grapes are grown. They just want wine that tastes good and - something most VQA wines can't boast but which flexible international blends sometimes can - is as consistent as Blue Light or Coors from year to year.
Retailers tend to prefer selling higher-margin brands, after all. In Ontario, the LCBO was already taking steps to literally distance cellared in Canada brands from the VQA shelves. LCBO spokesman Chris Layton says the retailer has been giving marquee treatment to VQA wines through its regular "Go Local" catalogue campaigns and special in-store displays, helping drive VQA sales to double-digit growth over the past year compared with flat sales for imports.
"I think the LCBO has done a good job in making changes to the signage," says Laurie Macdonald, executive director of VQA Ontario, an authority of the provincial government. "They now have signs that say 'VQA - 100 per cent Ontario' and I think it's been a few years since the cellared in Canada wines were shelved under an Ontario banner."
As I said, not exactly world-class scandal material. But I'm kind of amused that at least one esteemed foreign wine writer thinks so.

10,000 tons of fibreglass threaten harbour view

Author: Hume, Mark

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/10-000-tons-fibreglass-threaten-harbour-view/docview/382605406/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "This was not true, and was an improper instruction to constrain the City's rezoning of the water lot," writes Ms. [Irene Faulkner]. "Thus, the Province appears to have improperly given the developer a 'veto' over City rezoning ... [and it] gives the perception that the province may unduly and improperly favour the developer's proposed marina."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=10%2C000+tons+of+fibreglass+threaten+harbour+view&amp;author=Hume%2C+Mark&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-19&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=10%2C000+tons+of+fibreglass+threaten+harbour+view&amp;author=Hume%2C+Mark&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-19&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: mhume@globeandmail.com
Of all the harbours on the Pacific Coast there may not be any with an ambience as pleasing as Victoria's.
The stately facades of the Fairmont Empress Hotel and the provincial legislature look down on the water where float planes land next to tall ships and sea kayakers paddle past whale-watching boats headed for Juan de Fuca Strait.
The harbour is a focal point for the city - beloved by its citizens and visitors alike - and it is not a place you would expect to find under threat.
But Bob Evans, a developer and Conservative Party fundraiser, and the WAM Development Group, an Edmonton-based company that leases, manages and develops real estate, have made quiet a splash with their harbour proposal.
The Victoria International Marina project, which they want to build in 2010, would see a big piece of water across the harbour from the Empress turned into a home for up to 50 mega-yachts. The vessels would be up to 50 metres long and three storeys high - big enough, in other words, to blot out the views from the sea walk across the water to James Bay and the distant Olympic Mountains.
The development would push sea kayakers out of a protected water lane, forcing them to paddle through the marina, literally under the shadows of the luxury yachts, and the construction dredging would stir up bottom sediments laced with pollutants.
No wonder some 7,000 people signed a petition opposing the development.
And no wonder prominent figures, including former Liberal cabinet minister David Anderson, and former Victoria mayors Alan Lowe and Peter Pollen, have voiced objections.
In a recent op-ed piece in the local paper, Mr. Pollen, who was mayor in the seventies and eighties, described the project as "outlandish" and called for its rejection by government.
"The proposed marina is designed for wealthy owners from around the globe to buy moorage and store giant yachts there year-round," Mr. Pollen wrote.
"How appropriate is it to use seven acres in the middle of our small harbour to store 50 of these giant yachts? Most are tax writeoffs for the very rich, and for those concerned about our environment they represent the ultimate in consumerism and environmental irresponsibility," Mr. Pollen wrote.
"Ten thousand tons of fibreglass stored in our harbour will illustrate Victoria's lack of environmental values to the world!"
Victoria lawyer Irene Faulkner, representing the South Island Sea Kayaking Association, has perhaps mounted the most formidable opposition, outlining in a letter to Environment Minister Jim Prentice the environmental dangers the project poses.
And she raises troubling questions about the possible bias government officials have shown in handling the proposal.
Referring to documents obtained under Access to Information requests, Ms. Faulkner points to a 2007 e-mail in which the lead Transport Canada official on the marina file, Irene Lin, states: "I will champion this project..."
Ms. Faulkner also has a copy of a 2007 letter from Stan Hagen, then a provincial cabinet minister, to an individual (whose name is blanked out) in which Mr. Hagen expresses thanks for a briefing on the company's proposed marina and says: "We support WAM Development Ltd.'s plans to initiate tourism activity in the Victoria harbour..."
And there is a 2005 e-mail from an official in the provincial Land Management Bureau, to the City of Victoria, which states the developer, Mr. Evans, "has an interest" in a Crown water lot on the site, which the city wanted to convert to a park.
"This was not true, and was an improper instruction to constrain the City's rezoning of the water lot," writes Ms. Faulkner. "Thus, the Province appears to have improperly given the developer a 'veto' over City rezoning ... [and it] gives the perception that the province may unduly and improperly favour the developer's proposed marina."
Ms. Faulkner calls on Mr. Prentice to appoint an independent, unbiased review panel to hold public hearings on the environmental threats and into whether the project has been handled fairly by politicians and their officials.
That isn't much to ask when the fate of one of the country's most beautiful harbours is at stake.

Commercial real estate bounces back

Author: Ladurantaye, Steve

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/commercial-real-estate-bounces-back/docview/382604783/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "This is a statistical sign of a recovery, even if it's not a full-blown recovery," said RealNet president George Carras, adding that sales are still only half of what they were going into the recession. "You can't call a bottom until it's passed, but this data is positive and very factual - it's real, hard evidence, and not anecdotal comments."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Commercial+real+estate+bounces+back&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-19&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Commercial+real+estate+bounces+back&amp;author=Ladurantaye%2C+Steve&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-19&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: While not a full-blown recovery, sector sees encouraging trends 'across the country' in renewed transactions
Canada's commercial real estate market is on the mend, as an 18-month slump in Toronto has ended and other urban centres are showing signs of renewed activity that suggest the sector has de-coupled from its troubled U.S. counterpart.
After almost two years of flat or declining activity, industry tracker RealNet Canada Inc. said investments in commercial property in the Greater Toronto Area increased by 46 per cent in the third quarter over the second quarter, to $1.31-billion, while the number of transactions increased by 20 per cent.
"This is a statistical sign of a recovery, even if it's not a full-blown recovery," said RealNet president George Carras, adding that sales are still only half of what they were going into the recession. "You can't call a bottom until it's passed, but this data is positive and very factual - it's real, hard evidence, and not anecdotal comments."
More real-estate investors signed deals above the "critical" $10-million threshold. The third quarter saw 27 such deals worth $617-million, nearly double the value in the second quarter, when there were just 17 of those deals worth $313-million, a low point for the recession.
A healthy real-estate sector is considered important because commercial and residential property underpins a significant proportion of the assets of banks, pension funds and other institutions. Troubles in the sector contributed to the demise of some large trust companies in the early 1990s.
CB Richard Ellis vice-chairman John O'Bryan said the Canadian market still faces challenges as corporate tenants negotiate cheaper leases and others abandon warehouses and factories, but the numbers are encouraging as commercial real estate tends to lag the broader economy coming out of a recession. "We're nowhere near the volumes we were seeing in 2007," he said, when the value of deals neared $3-billion a quarter in the GTA. "But before things can get better, they have to stop getting worse and start to firm up - and this is what we are seeing."
While the RealNet data only reflect activity in the GTA, there have been signs of recovery elsewhere and office vacancy rates have stayed below 10 per cent, in contrast to the U.S. where vacancy rates have crept up toward 20 per cent.
"This isn't a local phenomenon - transaction volume is picking up with each passing week across the country," Mr. O'Bryan said. "There has been an exponential jump in inquiries to brokers."
Real estate investment trusts are in a particular position of strength, after raising almost $1-billion in equity in the last year while their main competitors - particularly private buyers - have found capital difficult to obtain. Whiterock REIT, for example, raised about $30-million through bought deals this year and in September took part in an $82-million deal for two office towers in the west end of Toronto.
"We really believe that Canadian commercial real estate is at a good point," Whiterock CEO Jason Underwood said. "The headlines have been so negative because of the problems in the United States, but Canada is so different from a performance standpoint and we believe there are some good opportunities. There's excess capacity in the pipelines and that means you're probably going to see a lot more transactions in the months ahead."
Patrick Lai of Toronto's Redcliff Realty Advisers said it's becoming difficult to justify sitting defensively on cash as quality properties come on the market. Mr. Lai signed a deal in September, buying a Markham, Ont., shopping centre for $32-million. "We all know what's happened this year in terms of the economic crisis, but now we certainly feel this is a good opportunity before everyone else starts to be really interested," he said.

Creepy, freaky and sometimes hokey Canadian history

Author: J. Kelly Nestruck

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/creepy-freaky-sometimes-hokey-canadian-history/docview/382609326/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The Mill: Now We Are [Brody] and The Mill: The Huron Bride play until Oct. 24 (www.theatrefront.com).

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Creepy%2C+freaky+and+sometimes+hokey+Canadian+history&amp;author=J.+Kelly+Nestruck&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Creepy%2C+freaky+and+sometimes+hokey+Canadian+history&amp;author=J.+Kelly+Nestruck&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=R.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: The Mill: Now We Are Brody
Written by Matthew MacFadzean
Directed by Daryl Cloran
*½
The Mill: The Huron Bride
Written by Hannah Moscovitch
Directed by Christian Barry
***
At the Young Centre in Toronto
Theatrefront, a theatre company run by director Daryl Cloran, is floating a new real-estate metaphor for Canada. The country is not the greatest hotel on Earth, as Yann Martel famously put it, but a haunted sawmill with terrible secrets hidden under the floorboards.
The Mill is a series of four horror comedies that explore the country's history and identity using this compelling metaphor as a starting point. The first two parts premiered in Toronto this week: Now We Are Brody by Matthew MacFadzean, set in 1854; and The Huron Bride by Hannah Moscovitch, set in 1834. I saw the second part first, and the first part second, which was in reverse order but chronologically correct.
The Huron Bride works better on almost every level: The comedy and horror are well balanced; the frightening bits actually send chills down your spine; and the allegory is clear.
It opens in the present day with a thought-provoking lecture delivered by a professor of archeology (Richard Greenblatt), who shows slides from his recent excavation of an Upper Canadian mill, under which he discovered a mass grave. We then flash back to the mill in 1834, where Hazel Sheehan (Michelle Monteith) has been brought over from Liverpool by her cousin James MacGonigal (Ryan Hollyman).
In order to keep Hazel separate from the sex-starved men in this sparsely inhabited town, she is quartered in the mill. Soon she starts to see and hear strange things at night - paranormal activity that only increases after she becomes engaged to James. Is it his first bride, a Huron who died under suspicious circumstances, back to seek revenge on behalf of herself and her ancestors?
Moscovitch keeps you guessing as to when violence will erupt and who will initiate it, while Gillian Gallow's gorgeously atmospheric wooden set is covered with antique tools, all of which seem like murder weapons in waiting.
Director Christian Barry takes a psychological approach to generating suspense and fear. Except for the appearance of a child of the corn named Lyca, who seems to have wandered out of a Tim Burton movie, he succeeds.
Now We Are Brody , on the other hand, relies too much on special effects inexpertly executed by director Daryl Cloran. Because the play is being performed in a small theatre with the audience up close, most of the supposedly scary scenes merely come off as hokey. You can see the wires.
In this chapter, written in an uneven tone by MacFadzean, James MacGonigal's daughter Charlotte (Michelle Monteith, again) is drawn to the now abandoned mill by voices 20 years later.
After too many tedious scenes of her moving in and talking to an electronically distorted voice from beyond the grave, Charlotte is discovered by noble French-Canadian lumberjack Alexandre Martiniques (a hilarious Eric Goulem) and local busybody Rebecca Jessup (Maev Beaty), characters who both appear in the first play as well.
The townspeople want Charlotte to leave, while Lyca - still a child, still not frightening - wants her to stay. After a false ending, the bloodbath begins.
Maybe Now We Are Brody suffered from having been seen second rather than first. I wasn't sure why anyone would want to see two horror allegories in a row - especially since little was done to distinguish the time periods. The shows' mythologies and character psychologies are often at odds with one another as well, a peril of all multiple-author projects.
Despite Theatrefront's stated goal of making Canadian history "less boring," these first two chapters of The Mill seem uninterested in actual history. Instead, they simply lay the mindsets and concerns of today upon historical caricatures, the most amusing being the tourtière-eating Alexandre.
The depiction of aboriginals is more problematic, mainly because they are all dead or undead. (Lyca, played by blond-haired, pale-skinned Holly Lewis, is particularly cringe-worthy when she bursts into a traditional song.) There are much more interesting and complex native Canadian characters, ones who are more than just victims for the white folk to feel guilty about, in boring old actual Canadian history.
The Mill: Now We Are Brody and The Mill: The Huron Bride play until Oct. 24 (www.theatrefront.com).
