____________________________________________________________

Canada puts on a new game face

Author: Anderssen, Erin

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/canada-puts-on-new-game-face/docview/382608717/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: His father grabbed him first. "I love you, buddy," he whispered. And as [Nazem] walked down to the stage to pull the Leafs jersey over his head, his family began chanting. "All you started to hear in the silence of the whole Bell centre was '[Sam Kadri]! Kadri!' " Sam says. "It was overwhelming."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canada+puts+on+a+new+game+face&amp;author=Anderssen%2C+Erin&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Canada+puts+on+a+new+game+face&amp;author=Anderssen%2C+Erin&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Some say demographics doom hockey as the national sport. Others think integration is just a generation away. Erin Anderssen finds a glimmer in a potential NHL star
Hockey magic strikes with 35 seconds left in the first period. Before that, this Ontario Hockey League game between the London Knights and the Plymouth Whalers is clunky and scoreless. Nazem Kadri's father, Sam, mutters with exasperation in his first-level box.
"Come on, Naz," he grimaces each time the Knights' star forward lets the puck get away.
Nazem's mother, Sue, watches quietly but no less intently, fielding bathroom requests from her youngest daughter, Rayanne, 5, and organizing plates of chicken fingers. Sister Yasmine, 20, the eldest of the five, is texting, glancing up once in a while at a play. "Boys," her mom sighs.
For nearly 15 years - from the winter Nazem first donned a hockey jersey at age 4, and promptly helped lead his team to a championship victory, to the day this summer when the Toronto Maple Leafs called his name as a first-round draft pick - hockey has been the Kadris' full-time business.
Sam shines with pride as he recalls the day Nazem was born: As he raced into the hospital parking lot, he heard Tom Cochrane's Big League on the radio. "It just came right on: 'My kid is going to play in the big league,' " he says. "I swear to God."
Today, Sue still sends Nazem to games with spaghetti in Tupperware and frets about injuries and how soon he is likely to leave the basement of their home in the north end of London, Ont. Before his 19th-birthday party earlier this month, she found herself thinking, "This might be my last year putting balloons up."
The extended Kadri family - typically 60 aunts, uncles and cousins at each game - is scattered around the John Labatt Centre. Sam's own, elderly parents - his mother easily spotted in a white hijab among clumps of hockey jerseys - are across the ice, two rows up.
They don't speak much English - Sam's father refers to the penalty box as habis , Arabic for jail - but having arrived almost empty-handed 40 years ago from Lebanon, where they'd never heard of hockey, they understand the feat their grandson has achieved. They don't miss a game.
As the clock runs down on the period, No. 91, dancing on his skates, snatches the puck in a pass up the ice. Enough is enough, Nazem's body language says. He sweeps the puck gracefully around a Whalers defenceman, catches it again on the other side, skates in front of the net and flicks it in above the goalie's outstretched glove.
"Now that was pretty!" says Sam, when the cheering has died down. "That's what I'm talking about."
The next night, on Coach's Corner , a gushing Don Cherry will play a clip of this goal and criticize the Leafs for sending Nazem back to the OHL for experience despite a pre-season run in which he scored three goals and five assists.
But it's more than fancy stick handling that makes him special: He has a fairy-tale story that hockey, more than ever, wants to tell. Nazem Kadri is not the first Muslim to be drafted into the National Hockey League - perhaps his most prominent predecessor was Montreal's Ramzi Abid, a left-winger who played several seasons before heading to Europe in 2007. But none has faced such expectations of stardom.
It comes at a time when both minor and professional hockey are intent on drawing ethnic communities into the game.
Maple Leafs general manager Brian Burke admitted on draft day that it would be good news if Nazem inspired more Muslim youth to take up the sport. "If that increases our player pool in a part of society that we're not touching right now, that's great," he said.
NET LOSS
It's often said that the great Canadian game has become a victim of complacency, watching while Canada aged, faces changed and soccer fields became more common than urban rinks.
"For a long time, the hockey tradition has been that if you open the door to the arena, the rink will fill with kids," observes Scott Oakman, executive director of the Greater Toronto Hockey League (GTHL). "That's simply not the case any more."
Hockey is still trying to build a following across ethnic groups, as basketball and soccer have done. Visible-minority teenagers play the sport at about half the rate of their white peers, according to 2005 Statistics Canada data. A study this summer found that only about one-third of Canadian teens regularly watched NHL games on TV in 2008, down 10 points since 1992.
"Hockey has been pigeonholed as an upper-middle-class, white sport to a large degree," says Glen McCurdie, a spokesman for Hockey Canada. "But it has a very important role to play in bringing newer Canadians into the country and welcoming them."
There are increasing numbers of high-profile players from immigrant families, among them Calgary Flames captain Jarome Iginla, whose dad arrived in Canada from Nigeria at 18. But they still account for a small percentage.
"I don't think our sport truly reflects Canadian society," says former NHL goalie Kevin Weekes, now a CBC hockey commentator, whose parents came from Barbados and eventually gave in to their son's pleas to play a game he first learned on the street.
"From my own experience, your parents immigrate here and they turn the television on, and they don't hear a name that sounds familiar, or a face that looks familiar. In that case, you are losing kids right off the bat."
Unlike soccer, which requires only cleats and an open field, hockey is time-consuming and expensive. And it's harder to start playing at a later age and still catch up on skill levels.
In an effort to help, minor hockey - though cash-strapped itself - is offering more free workshops, and the GTHL passed a new resolution to let teams to opt out of games on religious holidays.
But if hockey has been getting short shrift in Canada's newer ethnic communities, it's not for lack of interest. In Muslim communities across the country, ball hockey - a more accessible alternative - has become a phenomenon, spawning serious tournaments where players are ranked and traded.
And the CBC's broadcast of Hockey Night in Canada in Punjabi, now two years old, has drawn "a huge following," says Sukhpreet Singh, a customs officers in Surrey, B.C., who runs a 3,000-member Facebook group on the show. Young Sikh Canadians often watch the show with their grandparents, he says, and it has raised the profile of promising Sikh hockey players.
Many immigrant families understand the doors hockey can open for their children. Samren Sandhu, now a star forward for the University of Ottawa Gee-Gees, had an Indian-born father who worked hard to put him in hockey - first in the small town of Sparwood, B.C., and then in Calgary - knowing it was key to making friends.
Coming home from long shifts at the local mine, where he worked as a machinist, Bharpinder Sandhu spent hours practising with his young son in the basement and analyzing plays on a whiteboard. Now, hockey fever has struck family-wide - the game's always on at gatherings and many of Samren's cousins have signed up to play.
Such dynamics make Nazem Kadri any team's dream. Young, polite and grounded by a warm, devoted family, he represents the game's future in an increasingly diverse nation. In Arabic, Nazem means "leader": A lot of people count on him living up to his name.
HARDWOOD SLAP SHOTS
No matter where you come from, almost all hockey stories start with a father dreaming of his boy playing in the NHL. The eldest of seven children, Sam Kadri was four years old when he arrived in Canada with his parents, who had left war-torn Lebanon for better prospects in Ontario.
His dad worked two jobs as a janitor to pay the bills, and though Sam grew up playing street hockey and pickup games on frozen ponds and being mesmerized Saturday evenings by Hockey Night in Canada , he never asked his parents to sign him up.
"I couldn't see seven kids, and my father being the only one working, and trying to accommodate me playing hockey," Sam says, sitting at his kitchen table with his wife and daughters. But his own kids would be different.
"We had the stick before he started walking," Sue smiles.
"We had the skates before he came out," Sam says.
"I thought he was crazy sometimes," his wife admits.
"She didn't like him rollerblading on the hardwood floors," Sam says. "We toned it down on the slap shot."
By the time Nazem was 2, Sam was a successful businessmen with a used-car business and two things his father never had - the means and time to put his son in hockey. (His daughters, too, but they preferred watching their brother.)
Like dads across the country, he adopted a winter-morning ritual that would last years: Get up in the dark, grab a coffee, warm the car, lace Nazem's skates up in bed, throw his groggy boy over his shoulder and drive him to the rink.
"I could barely open my eyes," Nazem remembers.
With his dad watching faithfully, Nazem made the London Junior Knights Team at 6, and played at AAA level into his teenage years. His sisters were his personal cheerleaders - Rayanne went to her first game when she was one week old - and at out-of-town tournaments, they made friends and went shopping. ("It always cost me double," Sam sighs.)
They spared no expense on equipment and summer skills camps. At 15, Nazem was drafted by the Kitchener Rangers in the OHL, requiring him to move away to be billeted with a local couple. "When I dropped him off," his dad says, "it felt like my heart was being ripped out."
But it all led to the evening of June 26, when about 100 Kadri relatives and friends filled a section at the Bell Centre in Montreal. When the Leafs' turn came up, the local crowd booed Brian Burke. Then Nazem was called.
His father grabbed him first. "I love you, buddy," he whispered. And as Nazem walked down to the stage to pull the Leafs jersey over his head, his family began chanting. "All you started to hear in the silence of the whole Bell centre was 'Kadri! Kadri!' " Sam says. "It was overwhelming."
KNIFE'S EDGE
Raising three children in the small farming town of Avenmore, Ont., a few kilometres outside Cornwall, Mostafa and Zahra Elgazzar understood immediately that the key to integrating their kids was to put them in hockey skates.
When Mostafa came from Egypt in 1972 (promptly falling on the ice outside Montreal's Dorval airport), his hockey knowledge was limited to a short clip in an information video shown at the embassy where he got his visa.
Once Zahra arrived a couple of years later, they were initiated by their first Canadian friend, who would explain the rules as they watched TV and make them ardent fans of the Canadiens and Guy Lafleur.
"I used to wonder, 'How do they do this?' " Zahra says. "The player is on a knife on ice. We were fascinated."
In Avenmore, they were the only Muslim family, referred to as "the immigrants." But with hockey that soon changed. Their boys, Khalid and Omar, became stars, earning the nicknames Terminator and the Egyptian Magician.
Their daughter, Sarah, soon traded figure skates for hockey, and became a talented pint-sized goalie - at 5 feet and barely 100 pounds, her gear weighed more than she did.
While Mostafa worked as a janitor at night and went to school during the day, Zahra churned out sandwiches for practices, worked in the rink cafeteria and prayed in a high corner of the stands when the team was losing - at the urging of the other parents.
But it wasn't always easy. The boys often found themselves the subject of racial slurs on the ice and off-colour jokes in locker rooms, Khalid recalls. "If we arrived late, they'd say, 'Hey, Omar, did your flying camel not start?' But sometimes it went too far."
In Grade 10, Khalid quit a team after a player insulted his mother in the locker room. It was resolved quickly - after all, Khalid was the team's top scorer.
"In the end, it was a net gain," says Khalid, now a married Ottawa lawyer, expecting his first son and still playing hockey. "We got to know each other better. He learned quite a bit and so did I. He was just a kid who hadn't really been exposed to other cultures."
But Canada's obsession with hockey, Omar suggests, also makes people possessive about it. "It's sacred to them. It's as if they protect it," he says, with Khalid nodding in agreement.
However, he adds, "Nazem Kadri is a household name now in the hockey world. I think that's broken down a barrier. Now it's becoming normal for a Muslim to play hockey and to play it well."
"I joke to my teammates, 'Look at Kadri. It's over - we're coming.' "
In the meantime, some hockey parents have taken their own initiatives. Paul Song, a real-estate agent whose family settled in Canada from Korea when he was 10 and who used to lug his hockey gear on the bus to get to games because his parents were busy working, helped start a Saturday-night hockey program in northern Toronto for Korean youth. This year, 70 kids are lacing up.
"Once the kids get on the ice, they force their parents to bring them," says Mr. Song, whose children now play competitively.
Marion Christensen, a devoted hockey mom in northeast Calgary, which has a large ethnic community, took a similar step after "sitting in cold arenas for eight years wanting to see more diversity in hockey." This past summer, with another mom, she organized a free five-day workshop for immigrant children - with complimentary transportation and gear.
"I guess I had this idea that if you get immigrant kids playing hockey, they are going to feel a part of Canadian culture. They are going to feel included because of what they bring to the team and not necessarily looked at because of the colour of their skin and their accent."
In the end, 24 boys and girls 8 to 15 years old signed up, most of them with parents from Sudan - including Khadiga Elmahdi, who says she would not have known how to get her three boys into hockey without it. She knew when she came here seven years ago how important the sport was to Canada's culture. She has found it hard to meet people, but hockey seems like a social entry point for herself as well as for her three sons.
She is waiting for confirmation of their registration in an organized program, with Ms. Christensen's help. Soon she will be juggling practices between her business studies. "Now I will be a hockey mom."
PAYING PENALTIES Toward the end of the third period, Nazem Kadri draws a careless penalty, slashing the top of a Plymouth player's stick. He skates angrily over to the penalty box to sit out the rest of the game.
His father fumes, "He knows better than that," he says fiercely. "He'll be hearing about that later."
Sue shakes her head, and whispers: "He's really just a big teddy bear."
Nazem is generous with his praise for his parents, and the roles that they played in his success. "For them to bring hockey into my life, when it wasn't their lifestyle so much, was definitely a special thing."
His father understands that his son's career is now a business - he recently earned $4,500 signing his name on 300 hockey cards - and when Nazem went to the bank to deposit his hefty check from the Leafs, Sam made sure that only a few thousand dollars went into Nazem's personal account.
Sue, meanwhile, has been coaxing her son to take a course at university this winter "just to keep his options open." Yet when he collided with a helmet last year and broke his jaw, she was the one who blended up shepherd's pie and pasta so Nazem could suck it through a straw and not lose weight. And when a Windsor fan shouted from the rafters, "Get that terrorist off the ice!" it was Sue who was the angriest.
"That hurt a lot. I mean, he's Canadian, born and raised. I thought, how dare you say that to my kid? Any kid?"
They practise their faith with a Western flexibility. During Ramadan, the Knights set aside a room for the family to pray, but typically they say their prayers at home after the game. Unlike many of her female relatives, Sue does not wear the hijab - "I am not there yet," she says. And while Nazem describes himself as a practising Muslim, he can't fast during hockey season.
On Friday night, one of her daughters points to a young brunette in a yellow jacket sitting across the rink - Nazem's girlfriend, she tells her mom. Sue shrugs: "He hasn't brought anyone home yet. I assume that will happen when it's important."
The cheering builds as the buzzer goes off. The Knights have won 2-1, and the fans have watched their star score a fabulous goal. Nazem skates out of the penalty box, almost sheepishly, not looking up at his dad.
"He'll probably try to come home later, so I'm sleeping," laughs Sam. "It's always easier the next day."
Sue, packing up the girls, just smiles.
Erin Anderssen is a feature writer for The Globe and Mail.

Sick Kids' Foundation on the mend

Author: Waldie, Paul

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/sick-kids-foundation-on-mend/docview/382608431/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: According to charity research firm CharityCan, under Mr. O'[Mahoney], Sick Kids' costs jumped 31 per cent annually on average while donations climbed 18 per cent. Mr. O'Mahoney also nearly doubled the size of the foundation's staff and offered hefty salaries to new recruits (last year, 10 employees earned $160,000 Canadian or more).

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sick+Kids%27+Foundation+on+the+mend&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Sick+Kids%27+Foundation+on+the+mend&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-17&amp;spage=M.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Once the envy of many charities, the embattled non-profit is trying to repair its image after CEO's pricey payout
Nadene Milnes is a long-time donor to the Hospital for Sick Children Foundation, but when she found out that the foundation says its former president was paid $2.7-million last year, she started re-thinking how much she gives.
"It's stupid," Ms. Milnes said bluntly from her home in Wasaga Beach, Ont., where she works as a real-estate agent. Ms. Milnes said she still believes in the work of the hospital and will keep giving. But, she added, "I might not donate as much."
For years, Sick Kids Foundation didn't have to worry too much about donors like Ms. Milnes. Thanks to a sterling public image - who wouldn't support a cause that helps make children healthy? - the foundation has become the envy of charities across the country.
It raises nearly $100-million some years and has a network of 300,000 donors and 10,000 volunteers.
It's also a key source of funding for the hospital, providing around $60-million annually toward new equipment and research programs.
But a series of controversies over the last few months has left the foundation's reputation tarnished and officials scrambling to reassure donors.
The problems started in January with the sudden departure of several top executives, including president Michael O'Mahoney.
Then there was a $5-million lawsuit, filled with allegations the foundation botched a fundraising project that could have raised $1.2-million.
Finally, in September, the foundation said it paid Mr. O'Mahoney $2.7-million last year, which included $2.1-million in severance. (Mr. O'Mahoney disputed those figures in a statement but declined to elaborate.)
All of this came as the recession dried up donations and battered the foundation's investments, causing its total assets to fall 13 per cent to $489-million as of March 31, 2009, the first drop in five years.
"For them, I'm sure it's a bit of a nightmare," said Hilary Pearson, chief executive of Philanthropic Foundations Canada, which represents private foundations.
"No charity board wants to be in the position that they are in."
Ms. Pearson, whose organization does not represent public foundations such as Sick Kids, believes the foundation will over come its problems. "I do think they'll get through it, because I do think, at the end of the day, people have tremendous faith in the institution."
But others say it will take some persuading to get them to contribute.
The severance payment "is a concern," said Toronto philanthropist Jim Fleck. "One of the considerations when someone is giving to an institution is what percentage actually goes to doing whatever it is you are supporting and what percentage goes to the administration [toward] getting the money."
Sick Kids is trying to turn things around. It hired Ted Garrard, a well-respected fundraising executive from the University of Western Ontario, as chief executive and announced a major overhaul of its operations. The restructuring included reducing the number of employees, cutting costs and reviewing all fundraising activities to make sure they are cost effective.
"What we had to do was to address some of the legacy matters before we ... [went] forward," Mr. Garrard said. His own salary - $400,000 with up to $100,000 in bonus - will be less than Mr. O'Mahoney's base salary, which was $574,000 (U.S.) last year.
Mr. Garrard, an economist who once worked as a policy adviser to the Ontario Liberal Party, represents a sharp contrast to his predecessor.
Mr. O'Mahoney arrived at Sick Kids in 2003 from Washington, D.C., as something of a fundraising superstar. Charismatic and energetic, he brought an aggressive approach to raising money.
His competitive style put him into conflict with other charities. It didn't help that he organized fundraising drives and door-to-door campaigns outside Toronto, cutting into efforts by local charities. He took aim at workplace contributions to the United Way, encouraging employees to direct their gifts to Sick Kids. When United Way officials complained, Mr. O'Mahoney shot back that the United Way was a rival, not a colleague.
Mr. O'Mahoney defended his relations with the United Way and other charities, saying that he and his staff "worked collaboratively with United Way and their fundraising efforts."
Mr. O'Mahoney also had many successes during his tenure.
He attracted several major gifts, including $30-million from the Labatt family and $3-million from Toronto businessman Mitchell Goldhar. He also tripled the size of the donor base and more than doubled the foundation's annual revenue to $98-million.
"I am very proud of the achievements made during my leadership of the foundation," he said in a statement. "I delivered and surpassed every expectation and measurable objective."
According to charity research firm CharityCan, under Mr. O'Mahoney, Sick Kids' costs jumped 31 per cent annually on average while donations climbed 18 per cent. Mr. O'Mahoney also nearly doubled the size of the foundation's staff and offered hefty salaries to new recruits (last year, 10 employees earned $160,000 Canadian or more). He also launched an expensive advertising campaign called "Believe," which featured television and newspaper ads promoting the foundation and the hospital.
One of the maverick fundraiser's more unusual ventures was a planned soccer tournament featuring top European teams such as Juventus, AC Milan and Glasgow Rangers FC. The idea was to hold games in cities across Canada with proceeds going to the foundation.
Sick Kids officials started working on the project last year with Toronto businesswoman Angela Nowacin, who had European soccer connections. The foundation agreed to pay her up to $40,000 a month and cover some of the costs for two trips to Europe, according to court filings.
But just before Mr. O'Mahoney left, the foundation abruptly cancelled the tournament and a related sponsorship deal. It paid Ms. Nowacin $80,000, according to court filings. She launched a $5-million lawsuit in February for breach of contract and alleges the foundation missed out on what could have been a $1.2-million opportunity. In a statement of defence, the foundation alleges there was no formal contract and that Ms. Nowacin's work was unsuccessful.
Mr. O'Mahoney questioned the severance package quoted by the foundation, saying in a statement, "the amount cited [Sept. 30] does not tally with the numbers in the severance package offered to me. It represents a sum that is far greater than the one I was offered." He did not provide details.
Foundation chair Patsy Anderson said the board had no regrets about the hiring. "Mr. O'Mahoney was a very energetic and innovative leader," she said, adding that he raised $489-million in total. "He was very, very unique, a great leader in a high-growth market."
Mr. Garrard, 51, plans a new approach to fundraising at the foundation. He wants to put more emphasis on attracting larger gifts instead of relying on costly fundraising activities such as lotteries and door-to-door drives. Currently about one-third of the foundation's annual gifts are $10,000 or more. Mr. Garrard said that figure needs to double to two-thirds of the total.
He has also set an ambitious goal of raising $750-million over the next five years, about 53 per cent more than Sick Kids raised during the last five years. "There's never been a fundraising goal that I haven't felt capable of taking on," he said.
Donations have started picking up, he added, and the foundation's investments have regained much of their losses in recent months as the stock market recovers. Total assets are back above $500-million.
Sydney Birrell is one of those ready to give the foundation another chance.
He and his family have raised $3.5-million for the foundation in the name of their son James, who died in 2001 at the age of 8 after being diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a cancer affecting the central nervous system.
"I was pretty perturbed by stuff that has been going on," he said from his home in Peterborough, Ont. "But it's history. They have made major changes and they are going in a new direction. I am persuaded that they are doing things very well now."

DONE DEALS / LAKE SHORE AND BATHURST

Full text: 231 Fort York Blvd., No. 405
Asking price: $269,900
Selling price: $275,500
Previous selling price: $156,394 (2007)
Taxes: $1,485 (2009)
Days on the market: five
Listing agent: Anna Michaelidis, Royal LePage Urban Realty
Agent Anna Michaelidis knew this one-bedroom suite would sell quickly with no other properties to available within the high rise, which is part of a condominium complex on the former Molson Brewery site by Fort York.
However, she still took extra steps to stage the vacant fourth-floor unit with everything from furniture to pillows.
"We had about 75 showings in the course of four or five days," says Ms. Michaelidis. "Being the only one [for sale] and showing ... like a model suite really helped us secure the highest price in the building to date."
It's also important that the unit features wall-to-wall and full height windows and private outdoor space facing east. "From the balcony, you get a beautiful view of the CN Tower and all the beautiful buildings," says Ms. Michaelidis. "A lot of [other units] face the highway."
In other aspects, the unit is fairly average with a breakfast bar between the open kitchen and living and dining area.
Other essentials include a full bathroom, ensuite laundry facilities and underground parking.
A monthly fee of $263 covers heating costs and upkeep of fitness facilities, such as the pool, hot tub and gym. Residents can also socialize at the theatre and rooftop garden.
"The building is quite nice," adds Ms. Michaelidis.
Local amenities include parks, Waterfront Trail and yacht clubs, plus public transit and the QEW.

Humber river cradles a new project

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/humber-river-cradles-new-project/docview/382612444/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "I have never, ever worked on a nicer piece of land," says Lanterra chairman Mark Mandelbaum. "The river wraps around the project, so almost every single unit has a commanding view of the river, even on the south side."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Humber+river+cradles+a+new+project&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-16&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Humber+river+cradles+a+new+project&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-16&amp;spage=G.6&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: RIVERHOUSE AT THE OLD MILL
LOCATION: Kingsway
BUILDER/DEVELOPER: Lanterra Developments
SIZE: 868 to 2,125 square feet PRICE: $500,000's to $2-million
CONTACT: To register, phone 416-766-7343 or visit www.riverhousecondos.ca
In the prestigious Kingsway area, the Old Mill Inn and Spa is a popular destination where hotel and spa guests are pampered amid panoramic views of the Humber River valley.
Across the street, on the banks of the Humber, this new condominium projects aims to give homeowners a similar experience with spacious luxury suites, fashionable amenities spaces and unobstructed vistas of the surrounding landscape.
Lanterra Developments is now giving registered buyers a preview of the 10-storey residence - named the Riverhouse at the Old Mill - that will rise from what is now a parking lot at the historic hotel northwest of Bloor and Jane streets.
"I have never, ever worked on a nicer piece of land," says Lanterra chairman Mark Mandelbaum. "The river wraps around the project, so almost every single unit has a commanding view of the river, even on the south side."
Though the scenic setting will appeal to buyers across the city, the upscale development caters to locals downsizing from large, stately homes.
"We think that the people who are going to buy here are people in the area that are very discerning in their tastes," says Mr. Mandelbaum. "I don't think there are any condo options of that calibre [in the area]."
Many residents want to stay in the established community for its small-town ambience, tree-lined streets and outdoor attractions, from parks to walking trails.
The site is within a short walk to the Old Mill Tennis Club and countless shops and restaurants in the Kingsway Village and Bloor West Village.
"One of the other things that [the project] has - which is absolutely unique - is that it's about a 30-second walk to the Bloor subway stop," says Mr. Mandelbaum.
"That's not something you can normally find in a project where there's so much scenery and greenery around it."
Further engaging the visual senses, Page + Steele / IBI Group Architects designed the elegant façade with brick, limestone, precast stone and glass.
Munge Leung Design Associates will oversee all interior spaces, starting with a lobby with rich wood finishes, decorative columns and stone tile floors.
Residents will be able to use an indoor pool and hot tub with an outdoor terrace, a steam room and a gym.
Meanwhile, social gatherings could be held in a party room with a caterer's kitchen, a library featuring a fireplace, and an adjacent room overlooking the Humber River.
Lavish appointments will continue in the suites, with coffered entry foyers, engineered hardwood floors in the principal rooms and smooth, nine-foot ceilings. Units on the top two floors will be a foot taller.
The kitchens will have designer cabinetry, granite countertops and glass tile or marble backsplashes with Miele fridges, cook-tops, wall ovens and dishwashers.
Ensuite bathrooms will be finished with marble floors and vanities, soaker tubs and glass shower stalls.
There will be more than 80 suites available between 868 and 2,125 square feet, though units can be combined.
"There are a couple of units that have open kitchens," says Mr. Mandelbaum. "But generally speaking, the unit designs tend towards the more classic design with formal rooms and very significant entry foyers."
Units will come with laundry machines, parking and a monthly fee of 56 cents per square foot.
As a preview bonus, purchasers of suites larger than 1,893 square feet will receive a gas fireplace and locker.
Move-in dates are set for spring 2013.

The man who could make money disappear

Author: McArthur, Greg

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/man-who-could-make-money-disappear/docview/382610762/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: For example, the company's records show that a financial adviser for Pete Estler, a Colorado-based entrepreneur and chief executive officer of an upscale vacation company, e-mailed Newport to say that an offshore corporation had purchased a $300,000 painting that Mr. Estler had hung in his home. The offshore corporation should arrange insurance, the e-mail says, because "it may bring up questions if Pete insures it." One former Newport employee says Mr.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+man+who+could+make+money+disappear&amp;author=McArthur%2C+Greg&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-10&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+man+who+could+make+money+disappear&amp;author=McArthur%2C+Greg&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-10&amp;spage=F.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: With Ottawa vowing to crack down on corporate crime, Greg McArthur examines the bizarre case of Michael Ritter, the high-profile Alberta 'wealth manager' who served just 18 months of a 10-year sentence after stealing millions of his clients' dollars
High above the silt-stained North Saskatchewan River, the mansions hover like a prairie oasis. In this exclusive enclave just down the street from one of Edmonton's more prestigious golf courses, Michael Ritter is busy reconnecting with his toys.
He spends his time playing host to friends in his Celtic-themed basement modelled on a local pub, splashing around his hot tub and walking Monte, his skittish and spoiled little Havanese. At 52, he has discovered Facebook, where he recently announced: "Michael Ritter finally got his Jaguar running again after not driving it for over three years!"
The Jag had been idle because Mr. Ritter, once a prominent wealth manager and former chief parliamentary counsel to the Alberta Legislature, was behind bars, convicted of theft and fraud involving what the judge described as a "staggering" amount of money. He admitted to stealing $10.5-million (U.S.) from one client and helping another to revive a $270-million Ponzi scheme that had been shut down south of the border.
Released last year, Mr. Ritter walked out of jail to find the world about to change.
The financial collapse has exposed a dark side to the global economy with the prosecution of such white-collar criminals as Bernie Madoff and "Sir" Allen Stanford. Vilified for perpetrating the biggest fraud in U.S. history, Mr. Madoff seems destined to die behind bars, and Mr. Stanford, the Texas financier accused of bilking investors of $7-billion (U.S.), faces 250 years in jail. Meanwhile, their assets - the villas, yachts, cars and condos - are under attack from creditors and prosecutors.
Closer to home, authorities are scrambling to respond to the collapse of empires built by financial advisers such as Montrealer Earl Jones and two Albertans recently accused of mishandling hundreds of millions of investment dollars.
Talking tough on fraud, securities regulation and offshore tax evasion is all the rage in Ottawa, and last month the government announced that it will increase mandatory minimum sentences for those convicted of fraud.
"Canadians lose faith in the criminal justice system when they feel that the punishment does not fit the crime," Justice Minister Rob Nicholson said. "The legislation we plan to introduce will send the message that committing fraud will have serious consequences."
Given the outrage, it seems like a good time to ask what the consequences are for white-collar crime in Canada. Mr. Ritter is a case study.
Although given the maximum sentence of 10 years when he was convicted in October, 2006, he served just 18 months in a minimum-security prison. He also failed to recover the millions of dollars he was asked, as part of his plea bargain, to track down as restitution for his victims.
Back in his three-storey refuge, with its home theatre and cherrywood humidor, he's not keen to look back. "I don't want to speak with the media," he says through the intercom.
Such reticence is something new for the high-flying Mr. Ritter, but professionally he was very skilled at keeping a low profile. He went to jail for taking people's cash, but his real specialty - as revealed by a 369-page catalogue of records seized by the police and obtained by The Globe and Mail - was helping them hide it.
It's how he helped to turn Edmonton into a magnet for dirty money.
THE IMAGE
When it comes to Michael Peter Ritter, only a few facts are undisputed: He was born on March 16, 1957. He has a severe peanut allergy, a warm, cherubic face and the gift of gab.
The son of a principal at a Catholic high school, he's brainy and fancies himself a social progressive. In interviews, he has acknowledged that he struggled as a young man to come to terms with the fact that he's gay.
In academe, though, he was a picture of confidence. He attended the University of Alberta, where he caught the attention of law and politics professor Leslie Green, who says, "I found him both as a student and as a friend a charming person."
He left for England to pursue a law degree, and came back telling people that he had begun his studies at the University of London and finished them at the London School of Economics. He also said he had been admitted to Gray's Inn, one of four professional associations for English barristers - a membership that entitled him to dine and study in a building straight out of Harry Potter . As well, he'd interned in the House of Lords legal division, attended the Université de Genève and advised the Swiss Bankers Association.
The boy from the oil patch had gone cosmopolitan. And what better place to apply his new skills than in the legislature of his home province?
In 1988, Progressive Conservative MLA David Carter, then speaker of Alberta's Legislative Assembly, hired Mr. Ritter as chief parliamentary counsel; he was to advise lawmakers on everything from conflict-of-interest guidelines to the constitutionality of proposed bills.
"Parliamentary procedure works better than NyQuil, but he had this personality that was able to make this topic come alive," says Howard Yeung, a former employee who was still in high school when he met Mr. Ritter during Alberta's annual model legislature for students.
He could quote obscure rules of procedure, and seemed fascinated with laws of jurisdiction - specifically how someone could do something in one place that's not condoned elsewhere.
For example, one day in 1992, when questioned by a television reporter about his expenses, Mr. Carter grabbed a cameraman and slammed him into the wall. There was an uproar, and Mr. Ritter was called in to quell the throng. He calmly told reporters that, in the confines of the legislature, the Speaker could do whatever he wanted as long as he had the approval of the House. "There are no other outside authorities that can review the matter," he declared.
Stuart Serediuk, the cameraman on the receiving end of the attack, recalls thinking: "That cannot be right. That cannot be right."
Still, he felt obliged to follow Mr. Ritter's edict, and he wasn't alone. Even now, two decades later, senior Edmonton lawyers still seethe at the memory of a warning from Mr. Ritter that, if they tried to serve a politician with legal papers in the legislature, they would be arrested.
Even they deferred to him, however, although there were nagging doubts. Why, for example, had he never joined the Law Society of Alberta? When asked, Mr. Ritter simply said that, as a legislative counsel, he was independent and not required to join.
It would be more than a decade before the skeptics learned that his credentials were almost completely made up. He had never graduated in London, and Gray's Inn, the Université de Genève and the Swiss Bankers Association had no record of him.
In 1993, Mr. Carter retired, and Mr. Ritter left with him. In an exit interview with the Edmonton Journal, he mused about starting a gift-card business, saying, "I don't think I'm cut out to be a good bureaucrat - I'm surprised I actually pulled it off for six years."
He made the leap with pizzazz, throwing a huge party on the 18th floor of Edmonton's highest tower, with ice sculptures, caviar and a raft of local luminaries, to launch his new venture. But he wasn't selling gift cards; Canadian Offshore Financial was to specialize in protecting people's assets.
Mr. Ritter had concocted a surefire formula for concealing fortunes from prying eyes. Pay a $25,000 start-up fee, and he and his staff would create a corporation or trust in Central America or on some South Pacific island, and then ensconce your money in a foreign account, usually Swiss.
There is nothing wrong with having such an account, as long as you disclose its contents and any income earned to the Canada Revenue Agency. The problem is that the secrecy laws for Swiss accounts are so strict that, unless such disclosure is made, authorities don't know an account exists.
"These laws protect offshore investors from ... both private and governmental authorities," the company advertised.
Later renamed Newport Pacific Financial, the business caught on, sparking heady times for its cadre of young employees, most of them just out of the University of Alberta law school. Their boss was a dizzying personality. One minute, he would be dashing out the door to catch a flight to Switzerland and the next announcing that he had ordered in sushi for everyone. Monte was always reserved a spot on the boardroom table, and ate off his own plate. And the parties Mr. Ritter threw were legendary. One night, he rented sumo-wrestler suits and guests took turns bouncing off each other in a boozy haze.
More significant is the fact that he managed almost overnight - and operating in a regulatory vacuum because the service he offered required no official oversight - to turn Edmonton into a hub for international wealth. Teams from foreign institutions such as Credit Suisse and AIG Private Bank, until recently a Swiss affiliate of the insurance giant central to Wall Street's collapse, descended on the snow-banked streets, eager for a piece of the action.
THE CLIENTELE
Newport offered one-stop offshore shopping for "people of means." But who exactly were these "people"? A former lawyer for Newport, and a friend of Mr. Ritter, declines to speak on the record, but offers this description of the clientele: "Some people don't trust governments and so they've got assets in different places."
Even so, the ex-staffer contends, Mr. Ritter "was the most vigilant person in terms of making sure we knew who the clients were, that we weren't handling any money that was inappropriate."
However, a summary of the computer files and thousands of pages of documents the RCMP eventually seized from Newport, as well as interviews with former associates and law-enforcement officials, suggests that Mr. Ritter's radar wasn't foolproof.
Newport employees vividly recall the summer day in 2002 when a man with a heavy accent and dressed in black walked into the office. He was Bogdan Petrescu, and a former staffer says, "Mike told me Bogdan controlled tobacco imports into Romania."
Mr. Petrescu came to be one of Newport's bigger clients, and sometimes allowed Mr. Ritter to use his villa on the Caribbean island of St. Kitts. He also was featured in State Mafia , a book published the same year by two Romanian journalists, and the Romanian Ministry of the Interior has confirmed that it investigated allegations of smuggling, but no charges were ever laid.
Another international client was James Sheret Jr., a convicted stock-market manipulator from California who had a beachfront home in Malibu and a Newport-created bank account in Switzerland. He made more than $1-million by sending a barrage of phony e-mail endorsements for nearly worthless penny stocks, which he sold when the price spiked.
The documents show that he was one of several tech-savvy rogues who streamed into Newport's offices as governments around the world were struggling to tame the Wild Wild West of the Internet.
Brian McDaid, a high-profile spammer who was shut down and fined by U.S. authorities in 2007 for claiming his medical products reversed the aging process, secreted hundreds of thousands of dollars in Switzerland through Newport.
The company also assisted Gamma Entertainment, a Montreal online pornography service that in 2004 paid two teenagers to distribute its pop-up ads to unsuspecting Internet users. One teen went to prison for hacking into a network of 400,000 computers.
When authorities tried to trace someone's money, the trail would reach Newport and go cold. "There were often judgments coming for clients, where [investigators] were trying to track the assets," says Patrick Mitchell, a former pilot and personal assistant to Mr. Ritter, "but Mike knew how to protect them. There was nothing they could do."
The seized records also help to explain a bizarre photograph that emerged during the investigation. Taken in 2001, it shows Mr. Ritter and Mr. Carter, the former legislative speaker, posing with enough $20 bills to fill a kitchen sink. Five years later, one of his ex-employees testified in court that for three years in a row Mr. Ritter personally delivered millions in cash to AIG Private Bank in Zurich. One year, the money arrived at Newport in a gift-wrapped box.
The identity of the client was never made public. But the Newport material seized by the Mounties shows that an offshore corporation created for "Fred Carpenter - a.k.a. 'The Fruit Man' " had $220,000 in cash being held somewhere in a box marked "Jelly Beans," and former staffers confirm that Mr. Carpenter was the client in question. At the time, he owned of a wholesale fruit business in Calgary that has since declared bankruptcy, with dozens of creditors trying to recover more than $830,000 they are owed.
The trustee overseeing the distribution of the company's assets recently filed a court document declaring that, shortly before Fred's Fruit Company filed for bankruptcy, it made a "fraudulent" payment of $400,000 to a numbered company controlled by Mr. Carpenter (who did not respond to numerous interview requests).
Mr. Carter, who is also an ordained Anglican priest, says he helped Mr. Ritter carry the money to Switzerland, but didn't think there was anything suspicious about the trip: "Wasn't my business."
Asked how he would react if he found out the goal was to evade taxes, Mr. Carter replies: "Hey ... that's been going on for decades."
UNTRACEABLE PLASTIC
Many of Newport's clients appear to have been perfectly ordinary - doctors, dentists and diplomats pop up repeatedly in the documents taken from its office. But one name will be familiar to many Canadians, that of Olympic ice dancer Isabelle Duchesnay.
Ms. Duchesnay, a Canadian who won a silver medal while representing France at the 1992 Games in Albertville, insists that she was not a client of Newport or Mr. Ritter. "I never spoke to him really," she says. "I didn't know a thing."
But she also declines to explain why Newport records include a series of transactions involving her, including $3,000 wired to her on Jan. 2, 2002. The money had come from a Swiss account with the code name "Tango."
"Everything's been taken care of because everything is in compliance with everything," says Ms. Duchesnay, who lives in Aylmer, Que. "I'm as free as a bird."
But former Newport officials confirm that she was a long-time client, and one of them recalls an angry phone call he received from her family when a credit card issued by a Swiss bank did not cover the purchase of a pair of earrings. "My sympathies were particularly low that day," the ex-employee says, "but we made sure the card was working again."
Offshore credit cards permitted clients to gain access to their funds as though they were using a debit card. The foreign bank would simply debit their accounts to pay the bill, and account statements were always mailed to Newport, not the card holder.
In fact, keeping a distance between transactions and the people making them was a Newport priority.
For example, the company's records show that a financial adviser for Pete Estler, a Colorado-based entrepreneur and chief executive officer of an upscale vacation company, e-mailed Newport to say that an offshore corporation had purchased a $300,000 painting that Mr. Estler had hung in his home. The offshore corporation should arrange insurance, the e-mail says, because "it may bring up questions if Pete insures it." One former Newport employee says Mr. Ritter reminded clients of their legal obligation to report their earnings to authorities, but says there was a nudge-nudge, wink-wink undertone to the warning. "His moral was, 'Look, people buy fancy sports cars all the time, and if they're driving too fast, they get arrested or they get a speeding ticket.' Same with these [accounts]."
But even when Newport was hitting its stride - at its peak, employees estimate, it was overseeing between $100-million and $200-million - it appears that most outsiders didn't have a clue what it was doing. The people who usually ask hard questions, the media, were still too busy soliciting Mr. Ritter's opinion about legislative issues. Besides, the silver-haired scholar appeared to have the official seal of approval. He helped law students taking part in an international debate competition known as the Jessup Moots and hung out with some of Edmonton's leading lawyers. In 1998, the federal government of Jean Chretien invited the company on its "Team Canada" trade mission to Latin America.
Perhaps the last of the accolades heaped upon Mr. Ritter came from no less than the Chief Justice of the Alberta Court of Queen's Bench, Allan Wachowich. On Dec. 5, 2002, during a ceremony held to call a U of A law graduate to the bar, the judge told her how fortunate she was to have been under Mr. Ritter's tutelage.
(The Chief Justice now concedes that he knew next to nothing about Mr. Ritter. "Everybody believed he was a lawyer. He held a job where you were required to be a lawyer," he said in an interview.)
A week later, the Mounties arrived at Newport's doors with a search warrant.
TIPPING POINT
In 2001, Dan Gordon, a young stock trader, had a problem most people will never encounter. After you steal tens of millions from your employer, what do you do with it?
When the 25-year-old graduate of Yale University stumbled onto Newport's website, he figured he had the answer. Mr. Gordon, then the head of Merrill Lynch's energy trading unit, had persuaded the investment bank to free up $43-million for a complicated hedging contract. But rather than enter into such a contract, he enlisted Newport to move the cash to a Swiss account.
Then the 6-foot, 4-inch whiz kid started spending the money. Lots of it. He pulled out so much - $32.5-million - that the Swiss bankers alerted Newport. When large sums of money move around, authorities tend to notice.
Mr. Ritter chastised his young client. But he also was able to freeze the remaining $10.5-million and then, after nearly a decade of helping people protect their money, he started helping himself to it.
He gave $4-million to a friend in California named Larry Osaki, whose investors believed he was importing latex gloves from China and selling them at huge profit. In reality they, much like Bernie Madoff's victims, were buying into a massive Ponzi scheme. There were no gloves, and money from new investors was being used to pay off old ones.
The fraud had reached a staggering $270-million when it was shut down by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. But not for long.
Rather than accept his loss, Mr. Ritter helped Mr. Osaki keep the scheme alive. They gave it a new name, Village Capital Trust, and registered it in Belize, but the phone lines led to Newport's boardroom where a crew of young women took the calls.
Unaware of what had happened, U.S. customers trying to find out where their money was were puzzled. "We got a phone number once for a Canadian office, and there were people answering: 'Hello, Village Capital,' " recalls Dane Ryan of Santa Cruz, Calif., whose family lost hundreds of thousands of dollars. "I don't know if they had a staff that didn't know what was going on, or what."
After Mr. Ritter got involved, investors put $7-million more into Village Capital, which promised a remarkable return of 20 per cent every quarter - a profit margin that would raise eyebrows among experienced investors.
Duane Roylance, a Utah fence installer, gave $48,000 to Village Capital, and now says: "I'm 72 and still running my company instead of retired."
Before long, the receiver appointed by a U.S. court to track down Mr. Osaki's assets caught wind of Village Capital, and Newport employees started asking why the U.S. callers were so upset. Eventually, staffers such as Howard Yeung, went to the authorities.
Meanwhile, Dan Gordon's energy unit in New York was sold, and the buyer had some tough questions about $43-million that appeared to have vanished into thin air.
PUNISHMENT
On Oct. 27, 2006, Michael Peter Ritter stood before an Edmonton judge and declared himself to be "guilty."
For four years, he had tried to avoid this moment of truth, launching court challenges and burning through several defence lawyers. When judgment day began to look inevitable, he discreetly obtained a Belizean passport as Adam Michael Philipp D'Orleans, but assistant Patrick Mitchell handed it to the authorities.
In the end, Mr. Ritter pleaded guilty and, in return, the United States agreed to drop the extradition proceedings it had launched. Mr. Osaki remains in jail in California, not due for release until 2021.
The Canadian prosecution team - which was essentially two people, a Mountie and an assistant Crown attorney - was eager to sift through the computer files and thousands of pages seized from Mr. Ritter's office and see who was using his services. But then they realized that, no matter how many charges were added, Mr. Ritter would never get more than 10 years, the maximum sentence.
"I honestly think there was a real lost opportunity there because I think it was a real treasure trove," says Greg Lepp, who prosecuted Mr. Ritter and is now an assistant deputy minister in Alberta's Justice Department.
"It becomes sort of a practical thing too. Because the cops are pretty short-staffed. They're up to their wazoo just with easy stuff. ... So, yeah, they're sitting on this huge server that's got all this international money laundering, but where do you start? It's overwhelming."
Auditors from Canada Revenue also were itching to comb through the records, but even now, almost seven years after the raid, they have yet to get their hands on them because of a torrent of legal challenges from Newport and Mr. Ritter.
Recovering any of the money has been equally frustrating.
As part of his guilty plea, Mr. Ritter was supposed to help the Mounties track down what remained of the Merrill Lynch millions and to return what he could to the victims of Village Capital. He dutifully complied, but the police traced about $2.7-million to accounts in Vienna only to confirm what they had suspected.
"It was already spent," Sergeant Marjorie Maier says. "A lot of it went to legal fees."
Mr. Ritter also agreed to retrieve $1-million he had used as a down payment on a condominium in Italy, but the receiver in California concluded that Italian legal costs would far outstrip anything investors were likely to get back.
In the end, all that was recovered from the stolen $10-million was $391,957.63 - from the sale of aircraft and real estate that Newport owned.
Mr. Ritter still enjoys the Jaguar and the home on 53rd Street, but authorities say they no longer belong to him. The car is registered to someone else, and a few months before he pleaded guilty, a numbered company that held title to the house transferred ownership, perhaps in lieu of payment, to the last of his defence lawyers, Robbie Davidson. (Mr. Davidson was unavailable for comment.)
Back in Santa Cruz, Dane Ryan is trying to save the house his mother-in-law remortgaged so she could invest more than $300,000 in those rubber gloves. "She's in her 80s and she's got $1,000 a month coming in," the retired high-tech worker says.
"It got to the point where she couldn't make her mortgage payments any more, so we're just struggling."
THE ROAD AHEAD
When Mr. Ritter's 10-year sentence was announced, it was seen as a huge victory for the Crown - one of the longest jail terms for white-collar crime ever obtained in Canada. But 18 months later, the National Parole Board adhered to the standard policy of releasing non-violent offenders who have served one-sixth of their time, and he left the minimum-security prison at Grande Cache, Alta., for a halfway house.
Now, during the day, he can be found back in the house on 53rd Street, using the computer to alert his friends about his pursuit of "another" postgraduate degree. He also has been spotted taking in a play or cruising Edmonton in the Jag with Monte by his side.
Just before the end of the year, he will be eligible for full parole. Is there more he could do to help people like Mr. Ryan's mother-in-law or Mr. Roylance, the senior citizen still installing fences in Utah? The subject has been addressed in public only once - by his lawyer, while speaking to the media after his client's sentencing in 2006.
"He's made amends," Mr. Davidson said, "as best he can."
Greg McArthur is a Globe and Mail reporter. He wrote this story with reports from Katherine O'Neill and Dawn Walton of the newspaper's bureaus in Edmonton and Calgary.

A push to polish downtown's 'jewel box'

Author: Weder, Adele

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/push-polish-downtowns-jewel-box/docview/382620235/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: These days, one can hardly see anything behind the dirty Plexiglas that replaced the original glazing more than 30 years ago. Until recently, the deteriorating façade wasn't as noticeable, Mr. [Ian Watts] says, because the surrounding vicinity was also rather derelict-looking. But in the past decade, the empty lot on the north side of the Dal [Grauer] has filled up with the giant condo-and-cinema complex known as Electric Avenue; and on the south side is the restored Electra condo tower.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+push+to+polish+downtown%27s+%27jewel+box%27&amp;author=Weder%2C+Adele&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-09&amp;spage=S.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=A+push+to+polish+downtown%27s+%27jewel+box%27&amp;author=Weder%2C+Adele&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-09&amp;spage=S.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   BC Hydro's foot-dragging on refurbishing the Dal Grauer Substation is a drag on the neighbourhood, say critics. 'In any other major city, they'd be forced to do it.'
On a prime stretch of downtown Vancouver real estate stands a low-rise building sheathed in peeling tiles and pitted Plexiglas. Known as the Dal Grauer Substation, it's an infrastructure workhorse, supplying electricity to downtown and the west end since 1953. It's also a once-revered architectural icon, whose fate - be it full restoration or continued degradation - could well affect the value and appeal of local real estate in the years to come.
As the strip of Burrard Street between Nelson and Smithe develops into a superblock of gleaming condos, real-estate agents and community leaders are joining the cries of heritage advocates demanding the substation façade's restoration. The enhancement to property values would be indirect, downtown specialist agent Ian Watts says, but enduring.
"I can't say property values would immediately rise $50 a square foot if they restored it," says Mr. Watts, who has sold many units in the condos that flank the substation. "But it would be a much more appealing street to walk down." Adds downtown agent Nic Blachette: "A restoration would turn the substation into an admired public amenity that would draw tourists and locals alike, in turn generating business for the smart cafes in the vicinity."
The substation was built from 1952 to 1953, a time when corporate titans were seen as partners walking in lockstep with community values. It is named after legendary BC Hydro chairman Albert Edward (Dal) Grauer, renowned in his day as a populist with cultural sensitivity. Mr. Grauer was a friend of prominent west coast architect Ned Pratt, whom he commissioned to design the substation (and then, a few years later, the adjacent corporate headquarters, which was eventually converted into the Electra condo tower.) British Columbia Hydro and Power Authority, then known as British Columbia Power Corporation, was so proud of this marvel of beauty and technology that it showcased the substation on the cover of its 1953 annual report.
The transparency of the façade suggested openness and integration with the community. West coast artist B.C. Binning designed a vivid interior colour arrangement behind its glazing, effectively creating a large three-dimensional Mondrien-like tableau of public art. Shortly before his death in August, the well-known retired architecture professor Abraham Rogatnick recalled the substation as "a piece of public art."
"When we'd drive on Burrard Street, we used to slow down to see it, especially at night, when all those beautiful colours showed through the glass. It was like a beacon of light beckoning you downtown."
These days, one can hardly see anything behind the dirty Plexiglas that replaced the original glazing more than 30 years ago. Until recently, the deteriorating façade wasn't as noticeable, Mr. Watts says, because the surrounding vicinity was also rather derelict-looking. But in the past decade, the empty lot on the north side of the Dal Grauer has filled up with the giant condo-and-cinema complex known as Electric Avenue; and on the south side is the restored Electra condo tower. Across the street, the 42-storey luxury Patina condo tower is under construction and the 1940s-era YMCA building is being restored. In contrast, Mr. Watts notes, the aging Dal Grauer façade stands out as "junky-looking" in this strip of new and restored architecture. "Why leave just this one eyesore?" he asks.
BC Hydro officials respond that they are just being cautious about how they spend Crown money. "We do value the historic, cultural and architectural importance of the Dal Grauer Substation," spokeswoman Susan Danard says. "That is why we are keeping open the option of restoring the building when it makes good financial sense."
Restoring the Dal Grauer would cost roughly $2-million, Ms. Danard says, and so is not a priority during a time when consumers are concerned about rate hikes. "We need to keep our customers' costs down during these difficult economic times. Keeping Dal Grauer in excellent working order and providing a reliable supply of electricity to downtown Vancouver is the priority. Aesthetic improvements are also important, but unfortunately they will have to wait until better economic times. Right now our customers are tightening their belts, and so are we."
Restoration advocates note that a $2-million expenditure would barely register with such a mammoth company. (BC Hydro's profit for the three months ending June 30 clocked in at $74-million; its capital-expenditure plan for fiscal 2010 stands at $1.6-billion.)
A restored Dal Grauer would help return Burrard Street to its earlier role as a ceremonial promenade and gateway to downtown, says Don Luxton of the Vancouver Heritage Association, to the benefit of property owners and passersby alike. "These grand gestures always add to the public realm and make for a more desirable neighbourhood," Mr. Luxton says.
BC Hydro has brought the substation to the brink of restoration at least three times, engaging architects Peter Busby and Robert Lemon for the task. In 2007, BC Hydro negotiated a density-transfer agreement with the City of Vancouver and promised to restore the substation as heritage and public art, but the project collapsed when the City abruptly halted its density-transfer program later that year. In December, 2008, the restoration was once again shelved indefinitely.
The repeated stalling of the restoration has angered condo marketer Bob Rennie, who purchased and is restoring the historic Wing Sang building in Chinatown, not for profit, he says, but as a project for both personal and community benefit.
"Everything you do to an area enhances that area, but not every decision is a financial one," Mr. Rennie says. "Heritage rises above the immediate dollar value: you're preserving the future .This is our little jewel box in downtown Vancouver. [BC Hydro] should lead by example - whether it's energy conservation or architectural conservation. In any other major city, they'd be forced to do it."
Adds Mr. Watts: "It would be such good PR for Hydro if they restored it - it would show they cared about the community. If you have to have a substation there, why not make it a work of art?"
Previously commissioned heritage architect Mr. Lemon is hopeful that BC Hydro will resurrect their restoration plans, but cautions that the longer the delay, the greater it will eventually cost. "It would be just phenomenal to have that façade restored to its original transparency," he says. "If they want to come back to us, we're open."

Done Deals / LESLIE AND STEELES

Author: Yu, Sydnia

Abstract: "It's unique because this is a 2.5-storey house, but it doesn't look like it," he says. "[As well] it's a very quiet, middle/upper-class residential area."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Done+Deals+%2F+LESLIE+AND+STEELES&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-09&amp;spage=G.10&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   38 Saddletree Dr.
Asking price: $695,000
Selling price: $678,000
Previous selling price: $435,000 (2001)

Lot size: 53 by 149 feet
Days on the market: 30
Listing agent: Bill Thom, Re/Max Realtron Realty Inc.
If not for the GO Train line running behind this detached brick house, its spacious floor plan and pleasant setting on a winding crescent would have fetched it a higher sale price in less time, says agent Bill Thom.
"It's unique because this is a 2.5-storey house, but it doesn't look like it," he says. "[As well] it's a very quiet, middle/upper-class residential area."
Four- and five-bedroom properties are the norm, but this roughly 3,200-square-foot house contains six bedrooms and three bathrooms.
In the last few years, thousands were spent on upgrades like Brazilian cherry-wood floors, granite kitchen counters and vinyl windows. "It has a lot of features," adds Mr. Thom.
The house can be entered from the enclosed front porch and double garage, as well as from the eat-in kitchen and fireside family room, which both have rear walkouts off the deck and patio.
A combined living and dining room completes the main level.
On the second floor, there are four bedrooms, including one with a walk-in closet and a master suite built with his-and-her closets and an updated five-piece bathroom.
A skylight illuminates one of two bedrooms on the top level. "It was like a little hideaway," says Mr. Thom. "Little kids may want to play with their friends up there."
The basement was professionally finished with a sauna, gym and recreation room with a wet bar and brick wood-burning fireplace.
Local attractions include reputable schools and highways, including the Don Valley Parkway and 401.

WHAT LIES BENEATH

Author: Buck, Naomi

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/what-lies-beneath/docview/382604809/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: After the fall of the Wall, "the city had found no way to deal with this history," says Dietmar Arnold, a city planner who has written a history of Berlin's underground. To change this, he founded Berlin Underworlds, a non-profit association that preserves the city's bunkers, subway stations and tunnels and makes them accessible to the public. In the first year of operation, the Underworlds had 2,000 visitors; last year, 150,000 people took one of their tours.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=WHAT+LIES+BENEATH&amp;author=Buck%2C+Naomi&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-07&amp;spage=R.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=WHAT+LIES+BENEATH&amp;author=Buck%2C+Naomi&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-07&amp;spage=R.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   In Berlin's sandy soil, Nazi bunkers and Cold War fallout shelters are getting some new life. Twenty years after the fall of the Wall, Naomi Buck goes through the steel doors to see a contemporary art gallery and tour underground fortresses
When Berlin became capital of the united Germany in the nineties, the city had to confront many ghosts of its architectural past: the Berlin Wall - now running through prime real estate - and Nazi-era municipal buildings, some of which became home to government ministries.
But nobody wanted to acknowledge the history embedded in the city's sandy soil. Unlike other European capitals, which have turned their underground infrastructure into tourist attractions (think of the Paris catacombs), Berlin wasn't quick to celebrate its network of Nazi air raid bunkers and nuclear fallout shelters. But now those military monoliths are finding new life as historical attractions, and in one case as an edgy contemporary art gallery.
After the fall of the Wall, "the city had found no way to deal with this history," says Dietmar Arnold, a city planner who has written a history of Berlin's underground. To change this, he founded Berlin Underworlds, a non-profit association that preserves the city's bunkers, subway stations and tunnels and makes them accessible to the public. In the first year of operation, the Underworlds had 2,000 visitors; last year, 150,000 people took one of their tours.
Berlin Underworlds offers thematic tours of Second World War bunkers and atomic shelters, along with subway stations and sewers - many of these systems are interconnected. The main entrance to the Underworlds is at the north Berlin subway station of Gesundbrunnen, right under a Flakturm ("flak tower") built in 1940 to house anti-aircraft guns. BERLIN 7
After the war, the Allies demolished most of this monstrous bunker, but the northern wall, 42 metres high, was left standing, for fear that its blasting would ruin the rail tracks beneath it. One of the Underworlds tours takes visitors through the overgrown ruins of this forbidding structure and down into a seven-storey bunker.
Another tour visits the atomic fallout shelter at the subway station Pankstrasse, which is still fully equipped to house 3,346 people for several weeks. And the most popular tour shows visitors three successful and seven unsuccessful escape tunnels that were built from East to West Berlin, as well as some Geisterbahnhöfe - ghost train stations, located where West Berlin subway lines passed through East Berlin and which were heavily guarded to prevent defections.
For those who prefer to leave their heels on and stay above ground, there is a very civilized way to tour a Berlin bunker - thanks to Christian Boros, a public-
relations magnate and art collector who last year converted one of Berlin's largest bunkers into a home for his art collection.
The Boros Collection, with roughly 500 works by the likes of Damian Hirst, Olafur Eliasson, Wolfgang Tillmans and Daniel Richter, is one of Berlin's most exciting collections of contemporary art.
As interesting as the art is the bunker in which it resides - its designer, Hitler's star architect, Albert Speer, considered it a work of art in its own right.
Located in the heart of Mitte, the Reichsbahnbunker Friedrichstrasse was built in 1942 as Allied bombing escalated. It was built to house 2,000 people - travellers through the nearby Friedrichstrasse train station, as well as visitors to the Deutsche Theater next door and local residents.
Designed to exude the Nazis' confidence of victory, the bunker featured marble cladding and magnificent spiral staircases.
After capitulation, the bunker was used by the Red Army as a jail. In East Germany, it became a storage facility for tropical fruits - with its two-metre-thick outer walls and sophisticated ventilation system, the "Banana Bunker," as East Berliners called it, served as a city block-sized fridge.
After the fall of the Wall, the bunker was claimed by Berlin's techno and fetish scene and enjoyed a reputation as home to Germany's "hardest" parties, which reached a pinnacle in 1995 with an event called Sexperimenta.
Boros spent five years restoring the place. A protected monument, this original structure, with its five storeys, hardened concrete walls, and Speerian flourishes, had to be maintained.
Many of the art pieces were commissioned for the spaces they occupy, such as Kris Martin's For Whom - a massive bell that swings silently over the visitors' entrance. Or Scandinavian artists Elmgreen and Dragset's hyper-realistic rubber figure of a man lying in a hospital bed, looking out one of the bunker's few windows, and giving guests to the hotel opposite a bit of a scare.
French writer Stendhal is said to have pondered in Berlin, "What could have possessed people to found a city in the middle of all this sand?"
Whatever possessed Berliners then seems to possess them still, with their determination to dig around and retrieve the history that is buried under and behind the city's formidable surfaces. Endorsed by the city's senate or not, Berlin's underworlds have been discovered and are eminently worth a visit.
***
If you go
Berlin Unterworld English-language tours require no advance reservations. Tours typically require sensible footwear, flashlights and subway tickets. www.berliner-unterwelten.de/guided-tours.3.1.html Boros Collection Reinhardtstrasse 20; 49 (30) 2759 4065; www.sammlung-boros.de. Tours, available in English, are available only on weekends and must be booked in advance.
