The damp side of the moon

Author: Taylor, Paul

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/damp-side-moon/docview/382602876/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: The 12.6-metre-long rocket will hit the moon first, blasting an estimated 350 tons of lunar material skyward. LCROSS, following closely behind, will gather images and data and relay them immediately to Earth. Within minutes, LCROSS will pass through the expanding debris plume before it also crashes into the moon.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+damp+side+of+the+moon&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-05&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+damp+side+of+the+moon&amp;author=Taylor%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-05&amp;spage=A.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   With plan to crash a rocket into a lunar crater, NASA hopes to get evidence that water lies frozen on the moon's south pole
The moon was once thought to be a waterless world.
Now, however, many scientists believe vast stores of the precious resource lie frozen in polar craters where the sun never shines.
On Friday, they will get a chance to see if their hunch is correct.
A U.S. rocket will be deliberately crashed into a 98-kilometre-wide crater, named Cabeus, near the south pole of the moon. The impact is expected to throw up a huge cloud of debris, rising six kilometres above the lunar surface. Telescopes - in space and on Earth - will be focused on that material, analyzing it with special instruments for evidence of water.
And there's even a possibility some amateur sky watchers in western North America will be able to witness the celestial dust-up with their backyard telescopes.
Finding lunar water would be welcome news to those who have their hearts set on establishing permanent human bases on the moon and beyond. (The United States is currently reviewing its long-term space plans.)
"It could be an incredibly valuable resource," said Anthony Colaprete, the lead scientist overseeing the mission for the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The cost of shipping a pound of water to the moon is roughly $50,000 (U.S.) A lot of money could be saved if future moon colonists can use local water for drinking and growing crops. Or, it could be broken down into hydrogen and oxygen to produce rocket fuel for deep-space missions.
Previous moon missions have already provided tantalizing hints of water. Last month, scientists, using data from India's Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft and other lunar orbiters, revealed that trace amounts of water appear to be bound up in rocks and soil across much of the surface.
But other scientists hope to find substantially higher concentrations at the poles, where the sun doesn't rise much above the horizon. Some crater bottoms are in perpetual darkness and the temperature dips to a bone-chilling - 238 C, potentially preserving ice from comets and asteroids that has rained down on the moon over billions of years.
"There are about 14,000 square kilometres of shadowed real estate at the two poles," said Dr. Colaprete.
If the top few metres are made up of just 1 per cent water-ice, the craters could hold as much as 1.3 trillion gallons of water, he speculated. "That's quite a bit."
For an accurate assessment, however, scientists must excavate a big hole in a polar crater. And that's precisely what they hope to do by sending a probe on a collision course with the moon.
The probe is called the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite, or LCROSS for short. It's currently attached to the upper stage Centaur rocket that boosted it into space in June.
(The same rocket also launched another probe, called the Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter - or LRO - which is mapping the moon.)
About 10 hours before the planned impacts, LCROSS will separate from the Centaur rocket, which will then lead the way in the final plunge to the lunar surface.
The 12.6-metre-long rocket will hit the moon first, blasting an estimated 350 tons of lunar material skyward. LCROSS, following closely behind, will gather images and data and relay them immediately to Earth. Within minutes, LCROSS will pass through the expanding debris plume before it also crashes into the moon.
The impacts are timed to occur when it is the middle of the night in Hawaii, the home of numerous internationally funded observatories - including the Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope - which sit on mountaintops.
"It is nice to have a lot of telescopes at the same place," said Christian Veillet, executive director of the CFHT. "But if the weather is bad, it's going to be bad for all of us" and obstruct the view.
As a backup, major observatories in the western United States will be also focused on the moon, and amateur astronomers are being urged to take pictures and share them with NASA. The Hubble Space Telescope and LRO in lunar orbit will be watching, too.
"We would like to have as many eyes and instruments watching these impacts as possible because this is the way we will get the most data," said Jennifer Heldmann, who is leading the LCROSS observation campaign.
*******
See it live on the Web
The death dive of a U.S. rocket into the moon is set for 7:30 a.m. ET on Friday. But that timing isn't great for amateur sky watchers in eastern North America. Morning sunlight will drown any chance of seeing the faint debris cloud rising from the moon's surface when the rocket wallops into it.
Observers in the western part of North America, where it will still be dark, have better viewing odds. However, they will need a decent-sized telescope - one with a light-gathering mirror at least 25 centimetres in diameter. Even with the proper equipment, it will be a challenge spotting the proposed crash site. One small crater looks much like another to an untrained eye.
But don't fret about missing the show. Possibly the best seat will be in front of a computer. On one of its Internet sites (www.nasa.gov/ntv), the U.S. space agency will be streaming live images from the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite (LCROSS), providing a bird's-eye view of the main rocket body plunging toward the moon.
"It will look like a ring, or doughnut, rising up out of the crater and expanding outwards," said the lead mission scientist Anthony Colaprete, describing the anticipated plume from the impact. Paul Taylor

Centaur upper stage rocket Empty fuel tank and rocket engine have remained with LCROSS for the journey to the moon.
GETTING THERE
The Atlas rocket blasted off on June 18, 2009.
Five days later, LCROSS made a slingshot pass around the moon to get it into an orbit that would allow it to strike the moonís south pole.
IMPACT
Ten hours before impact, LCROSS and upper stage will separate.
IMPACT TIME : 7:30 a.m. EDT, Friday, Oct.9.
LCROSS will monitor the explosion and debris plume from the upper stageís impact into the moonís south pole and four minutes later will impact into the surface itself.
The debris cloud will allow LCROSS and ground-based observers to measure its properties in a bid to locate water on the moon.
NASA will stream live images of the rocket impact at www.nasa.gov/ntv

Subtle shift, dramatic ambition

Author: Erman, Boyd

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/subtle-shift-dramatic-ambition/docview/382604073/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's testimony to how Canaccord in many ways has already arrived. Many of the right people already know there's a new Canaccord. Those who just see it on the horizon need to be reminded. Branding does that."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Subtle+shift%2C+dramatic+ambition&amp;author=Erman%2C+Boyd&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-03&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Subtle+shift%2C+dramatic+ambition&amp;author=Erman%2C+Boyd&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-03&amp;spage=B.3&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   A name change is part of Canaccord's plan to grow beyond its brokerage roots into the lucrative wealth management sector
CAPITAL MARKETS REPORTER
Canaccord Capital Inc. is hoping a little rebranding goes a long way, as the country's largest independent brokerage tries to signal it's serious about moving up the food chain in the financial services industry.
On Dec. 1, the parent company's name will change from Canaccord Capital to Canaccord Financial to reflect an attempt to avoid being pigeonholed as just a securities firm and highlight a new, broader focus on money management.
The division of the company that looks after money for individual clients will also be renamed, becoming Canaccord Wealth Management, shedding the old moniker of Canaccord Private Client.
The company's top executives acknowledge that the changes are subtle, more evolutionary than revolutionary. Yet they have grand ambitions for what the new names herald - a Canaccord that wants to compete more directly with bank-owned brokerages, offering a wider range of services such as insurance from a vastly larger network of offices across the country.
"The industry needs to know that there's a new Canaccord arriving," said John Rothwell, who joined the firm last year from rival Wellington West to direct the revamp of wealth management business. "As much as the rebranding might be symbolic, it will be a springboard for us to be able to grow."
The change comes as Canaccord comes off a tough couple of years, marked by becoming tangled in the asset-backed commercial paper fiasco (almost all of Canaccord's clients got all their money back) and a general downturn in the financial services business that's been particularly tough on smaller firms.
The move creates a natural tension with Canaccord's roots as a small, scrappy shop that was home to brokers who were known more for buying and selling small-capitalization stocks that the company's investment bankers focused on.
The company doesn't want to leave the best of those brokers and clients behind, but Mr. Rothwell acknowledges that the changes are about adding top performers to the company's complement of investment advisers.
Already, some of the company's broker force has been culled, taking the number of adviser teams down to 335 at the end of the most recent quarter from 354 a year earlier.
At the same time, Canaccord can't stray too far from its heritage and become too much like the banks it wants to compete with, lest it lose what makes the firm attractive to clients and advisers who don't like dealing with big institutions.
Recruiting top advisers is the key to the wealth management business. There's only so much head office can do with logos and advertising. The real job of bringing in clients with lots of money to manage falls to the individual brokers, who depend on the strength of their relationships and the depth of their networks to rope in assets.
As a result, many of the changes at Canaccord are designed to "better service our existing advisers and clients, and also to get in a better state of preparedness to better serve the people who aren't even here yet," Mr. Rothwell said.
That means simplifying everything about the way Canaccord markets investment products, making them attractive to brokers because they're easy to sell and to clients because they're easy to understand.
Examples include simplifying the names of different types of products to eschew the fancy branding that other firms use to signify that some types of accounts are aimed at higher rollers.
"If you have some wealth, your greatest luxury is time," said Mr. Rothwell, stressing that the changes "attract attention from a different type of client and potentially the kinds of advisers that you want to know."
Canaccord is also counting on something that clients will never see to spark growth in its wealth management business. The firm is shifting to a new model of paying many brokers, trying to make it more attractive to work for the firm.
The idea, pioneered by competitor Raymond James, is to give the brokers more control and a shot at bigger paydays, in return for assuming more of the risk.
In many ways, it's like the difference between a franchised fast-food restaurant and a company-owned store.
Most brokers operate in the equivalent of a company store, where the rent and all the expenses are paid by head office. In a franchise, the local manager owns the real estate and pays many of the costs, but has a chance to earn more money. For the client, there's little difference; for Canaccord, the payoff comes in lower costs.
With this model, Canaccord is betting it could potentially have four times as many offices as it currently has.
"There are 100 cities in Canada that deserve to have a Canaccord branch in them," Mr. Rothwell said.
Canaccord hired two top executives from Raymond James, who were pioneers of the idea, to implement the plan.
That's when "we realized that the Canaccord brand is starting to resonate," he said.
"It's testimony to how Canaccord in many ways has already arrived. Many of the right people already know there's a new Canaccord. Those who just see it on the horizon need to be reminded. Branding does that."
******
What investors should know
SHARE PRICE
Canaccord Capital shares have come a long way in the past year, recovering from a beating they took while the company was fighting through the asset-backed commercial paper (ABCP) affair and a slump in the securities industry. The recent rally has taken the stock past the $10.67 average price target of analysts, according to Bloomberg.
REVENUE/PROFIT
Revenue took a hit as companies cut back on financing, and as a plunge in markets cut fees on trading. That, plus costs related to ABCP, led to a loss for Canaccord in the previous fiscal year. Analysts expect the company rebounded to a profit in the most recent quarter.
ASSETS UNDER ADMINISTRATION
The markets' crash took a major toll on the value of assets that clients hold at Canaccord. The totals are on the rebound and - if Canaccord can bring in big-name advisers - should keep climbing.
Boyd Erman

HOW IT ALL WENT WRONG / the mistrust / the betrayal / the deception / the secret deals

Author: Waldie, Paul

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-all-went-wrong-mistrust-betrayal-deception/docview/382603679/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: [Richard Rodier] infuriated [Earl Scudder] by making a direct pitch to [Jerry Moyes]. "I don't need your permission to talk to your client or anyone else," Rodier said in an e-mail to Scudder. "Nor do I care that, at your meeting with [[Jim Balsillie]] in Dallas, you were crying to him that I was abrasive. I've been working with him for 4 years. He knows. He likes it.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=HOW+IT+ALL+WENT+WRONG+%2F+the+mistrust+%2F+the+betrayal+%2F+the+deception+%2F+the+secret+deals&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-03&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=HOW+IT+ALL+WENT+WRONG+%2F+the+mistrust+%2F+the+betrayal+%2F+the+deception+%2F+the+secret+deals&amp;author=Waldie%2C+Paul&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-03&amp;spage=S.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   The saga of the failed Phoenix Coyotes sale started over dinner in a New York restaurant in September of 2008. Almost immediately there was tension, and it eventually permeated the entire affair
Jeff Shumway felt uneasy as he sat down for dinner with Richard Rodier in a New York restaurant.
It was September of 2008, and Shumway, the chief executive officer of the Phoenix Coyotes, was in New York for another meeting with NHL commissioner Gary Bettman to discuss the Coyotes' sorry finances.
Shumway knew Rodier represented Canadian billionaire Jim Balsillie and that they had been trying for years to buy an NHL club and move it to Hamilton, enraging NHL brass. Shumway was no fan of Bettman, but he wasn't impressed by Rodier's approach. During dinner he offered some advice.
"I believe my exact words were that they had to learn to play nice in the sandbox," he recalled in a deposition filed in court. "Running around to every team that may or may not be in financial trouble and trying to strike a back-door deal didn't seem to me the way to handle it."
Shumway's words proved prophetic. Over the next year, Rodier and Balsillie kept up their pursuit of the Coyotes in the face of fierce resistance from Bettman. They finally conceded defeat this week after Arizona bankruptcy court judge Redfield T. Baum threw out their bid and essentially handed the Coyotes to the league. Balsillie said he won't appeal and Rodier has backed away, heading off for a holiday in Montreal and declining to comment. Everyone else involved in the saga also declined to comment or was unavailable.
But the details of how Balsillie's deal came together are outlined in hundreds of pages of court filings. They portray a behind the scenes struggle filled with mistrust, betrayal and secret deals.
The story begins long before Balsillie offered to buy the Coyotes. It starts in September of 2006 with a feud.
Jerry Moyes knew nothing about hockey when he invested in Steve Ellman's real estate venture in 2002. Ellman planned to build a $1-billion (all currency U.S.) office, shopping and entertainment complex in Glendale Ariz., a Phoenix suburb. He'd just acquired the Coyotes, along with Wayne Gretzky, and the complex included a new arena for the team, financed by the city.
The partnership didn't last long. Moyes disagreed with Ellman's plans and in September of 2006 they split. Moyes took the team plus a payment from Ellman.
Moyes went to few games, rarely visited the Coyotes' office and put Shumway in charge even though his real job was managing Moyes's investments.
Gretzky technically worked for Moyes, not the Coyotes, even though he was the team's coach. Gretzky's employment arrangement, which included earning up to $8-million annually, was governed by a "deal memo" he signed with Moyes in 2006. Shumway spent years trying to negotiate an employment contract between Gretzky and the Coyotes, but Gretzky never signed it.
Moyes did not want to hang on to the Coyotes. In late 2007, he asked his lawyer, Earl Scudder, to find a buyer. Scudder tried a dozen people. None made an offer.
Then there was Rodier. He'd been calling for weeks during the summer of 2008, proposing Moyes sell the Coyotes to Balsillie through bankruptcy and sending the Hamilton Bulldogs of the American Hockey League to Phoenix as compensation.
One potential buyer finally surfaced, Jerry Reinsdorf. He owned baseball's Chicago White Sox and the NBA Bulls and had a house in Phoenix. Glendale had just built a spring training complex for the White Sox and officials asked Reinsdorf to help the Coyotes. Reinsdorf met Shumway in August but said he wasn't interested.
Shumway knew the club couldn't survive. The Coyotes were losing more than $30-million annually and had already tapped the NHL for financial assistance.
On Jan. 23, 2009, Shumway went back to managing Moyes's money. Moyes told Scudder to keep looking for buyers. It wasn't long before Rodier called.
Balsillie, co-chief executive of Research In Motion Ltd., was such a hockey fanatic he named RIM's boardrooms after hockey legends. "I have been convinced for several years that one of the most important contributions I can make to my country and my community is to bring a seventh NHL franchise to [Hamilton]," he said in a filing.
Rodier had worked with Balsillie for four years and developed a strategy of using the bankruptcy court to get around the league's rules on relocation. He'd been following the Coyotes' fortunes since his dinner with Shumway in New York. With Shumway gone, Rodier moved in.
He called Scudder on April 1, offering $190-million, but only if Moyes filed for protection in Canada and Arizona. Scudder mentioned the pitch to Bettman a couple of days later and got an ear full. Bettman told him to stop talking to Rodier, stressing that moving the club was a league responsibility. He reminded Scudder that the NHL had voting control over the club, not Moyes.
Bettman was having his own problems finding a buyer. He'd been talking to Reinsdorf, but in an e-mail to deputy commissioner Bill Daly on April 4, he said "this is looking more and more difficult since no one seems to be excited about a team losing 40mm."
Scudder and Moyes were fed up with the NHL and kept talking to Rodier. But Moyes wasn't keen on bankruptcy and he was skeptical about Rodier's strategy. A brief meeting with Balsillie in Dallas smoothed things over, but by late April, no deal was in sight.
Everything changed on May 1. Bettman called Scudder and told him the NHL had a potential offer from Reinsdorf.
Moyes was spooked. He was convinced Bettman had cut a secret deal and was going to leave him with nothing. Negotiations with Rodier ramped up. Moyes dropped his reluctance to file for Chapter 11 and Rodier agreed to pursue a filing only in Arizona. But mistrust was building.
Rodier infuriated Scudder by making a direct pitch to Moyes. "I don't need your permission to talk to your client or anyone else," Rodier said in an e-mail to Scudder. "Nor do I care that, at your meeting with [Balsillie] in Dallas, you were crying to him that I was abrasive. I've been working with him for 4 years. He knows. He likes it. You haven't seen abrasive from me yet, and I hope you don't." Scudder shot back, questioning Rodier's credibility while another lawyer for Moyes called Rodier unethical.
Rodier felt Moyes was getting cold feet and he warned him that Balsillie could go elsewhere.
The deal finally came together just before the meeting with Bettman. Moyes put the Coyotes in Chapter 11 and announced Balsillie's bid to buy the club for $212.5-million and move it to Hamilton.
Bettman arrived at Moyes's office and handed him a letter announcing the NHL had taken control of the Coyotes.
Over the next four months, the battle raged in court. Bettman attacked Moyes, alleging he ran the team into the ground and lined his own pockets. He accused Balsillie of being a liar and pulled together a 21-page internal memo on why he shouldn't be an owner. Moyes, Balsillie and Rodier fought back, alleging the NHL was an "illegal cartel" and claiming the league undermined the sale process.
It's not clear what will happen to the Coyotes. The NHL hopes to find a local buyer but most observers doubt that will happen, meaning the league will either relocate or kill the franchise. Meanwhile, Moyes remains the majority owner, the NHL funds daily operations and fan support plummets.

Ready for its closeup

Author: Ireland, Carolyn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ready-closeup/docview/382610698/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "You don't have air conditioning in a 150-year-old house," Mr. [Fred Simpson] says. "You sort of have to learn the old style."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ready+for+its+closeup&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Ready+for+its+closeup&amp;author=Ireland%2C+Carolyn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   cireland@globeandmail.com
Since 1840, the road that climbs from the Dundas Valley to the Niagara Escarpment above has curved past the genteel gates of Springhill.
In all of those years, few passersby have had more than a glimpse beyond the stone walls of the storied estate in Flamborough, Ont.
The family that has lived at Springhill for the past 70 years has always maintained a veil of privacy around the house that dates to circa 1830. Even the home's tower has remained partly obscured by the surrounding 200-year-old trees.
So the neighbours may be surprised to learn that - had they ventured down the lengthy drive - they might have glimpsed international film star Jacqueline Bisset strolling across the lawns. Hollywood actors such as Shirley MacLaine, Geena Davis and Christian Slater have all filmed scenes on the grounds of Springhill. Film and television production companies love to use the house and outbuildings because so little change has taken place in the past 100 years or so.
Fred Simpson has been very deliberate in his restraint on progress since he took over as the owner and guiding spirit of Springhill in 1963. The former banker first arrived as a boy after his mother bought the house at auction in 1938. His family is only the third to reside there, and Mr. Simpson remains mindful of that legacy.
The Simpson clan has always preferred family gatherings to grand parties and they cherished the seclusion afforded by the stone walls, tall trees and the property's perch on the mountaintop above Dundas, Ont.
The property has shrunk considerably over the years: 140 acres have been whittled down to 15 today. But those acres still include a fruit orchard, perennial gardens and majestic stands of maples and oak trees.
The original barn, circa 1830, still stands. In the main house, fine woodwork, pedestal sinks and stained glass windows imported from England have all been preserved. Fresh air comes from the breeze blowing across the top of the Niagara Escarpment.
"You don't have air conditioning in a 150-year-old house," Mr. Simpson says. "You sort of have to learn the old style."
The house was originally built as a 11/2-storey cottage by James Hamilton and Ann Hatt. Dr. Hamilton, who was born in Scotland in 1797, immigrated to the area and delivered most of the babies in Dundas for many years. The house was set on the mountaintop just west of Spencer Creek ravine.
Inspired by the many springs that flowed from the mountain's face, Dr. Hamilton named the house Springhill, according to the Dundas Historical Society Museum.
The illustrious Dr. Hamilton also served in the militia at the time of the Upper Canada Rebellion and, in one of his more notorious ventures, was convicted for the tarring and feathering of a local man whom the doctor and his cohorts accused of adultery.
After Dr. Hamilton's death, Springhill was sold to John and Catherine Fisher in the 1870s. Mr. Fisher, the prosperous owner of a local paper mill and other holdings, began to revamp the house in about 1880 by building a stone addition at the rear.
A few years later, the Fishers had a 3½-storey tower constructed in the Romanesque Revival style. The tower's mansard style roof is crowned with iron railings.
In 1938, the Fisher family put the house up for sale. The catalogue of auctioneers Ward Price Ltd. describes the house as a pioneer homestead "brought up to the luxury of the present day living standards of the country gentleman. ...
"One may gaze from the lawns of Springhill over the beautiful Dundas Valley and, on a clear day, see ships passing through the cantilever span at Burlington Beach," the auction house said.
Mr. Simpson's mother triumphed at the auction and soon took her father for a drive to see the property. "He told her she was crazy," Mr. Simpson relates.
Despite the patriarch's reservations about the Depression-era economy, the Simpson family moved there in 1938.
"She knew what she was doing," says Mr. Simpson, who brought his own wife and three daughters back to the house in 1963.
As a boy, Mr. Simpson remembers roaming pastures, streams and trails that zigzagged down the escarpment.
Four gardeners were employed at the time to work on the grounds and in a greenhouse on the property. About 50 acres were dedicated to farming, Mr. Simpson says, and his mother kept horses, cattle and a milking herd of eight Guernsey cows.
The property stretched right to the tiered waterfalls that are today part of the Spencer Gorge and Webster's Falls Conservation Area.
"I can remember swimming in the pool at the bottom of Webster's Falls," Mr. Simpson says.
Eventually much of the property was appropriated by the government for parkland. Mr. Simpson's parents also divided off some parcels for his three siblings.
With so many family members close by, Mr. Simpson's three daughters grew up surrounded by cousins.
And Mr. Simpson says he has taken on the roles of chauffeur, gardener, handyman and stable boy for the past four decades.
He describes the previous owners, Dr. Hamilton and Mr. Fisher, as fanatics for maintaining the trees. When his daughter reminds him that he has been no less vigilant in trimming and tending, he allows that, "I guess I'm a bit of a tree buff."
Mr. Simpson currently has the house listed for sale with Lesley Cumming of Sotheby's Realty, with an asking price of $3.599-million.
The property includes a stone guest house, a refurbished carriage house and the original barn.
These days, Flamborough is home to many hobby farmers and commuters in the Golden Horseshoe.
Mr. Simpson has found the house popular with film directors in recent years.
Anne of Green Gables: A New Beginning was filmed there by Sullivan Entertainment.
Mr. Simpson walked into the den one day to find Ms. MacLaine eating pizza.
"We got to know her pretty well," he says.
Ms. Davis filmed The Long Kiss Goodnight at Springhill. And the producers of Murdoch Mysteries often use the house as a backdrop.
Mr. Simpson says he enjoys the movie shoots and has never moved out of the house to accommodate them. The production companies make some changes, but little has to be done because the woodwork is unpainted and the fixtures are appropriate to the period.
The cash, he says, allows him to invest in keeping the landmark and its aged plaster, stone and wood in top form. The grounds are manicured and nothing is allowed to deteriorate.
"Everybody thinks you make lots of money, but 90 per cent I put back in."

DONE DEALS / LAWRENCE AND WESTON

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/done-deals-lawrence-weston/docview/382610659/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It was a traditional Canadian Arts and Crafts home, so it had naturally high ceilings, lots of wood trims and leaded glass," she says. "The character was intact."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DONE+DEALS+%2F+LAWRENCE+AND+WESTON&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=DONE+DEALS+%2F+LAWRENCE+AND+WESTON&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.13&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   5 Grattan St.
Asking price: $439,900
Selling price: $429,000
Previous selling price: $278,000 (2001)
Taxes: $2,607 (2008)
Lot size: 40 by 130 feet
Days on the market: 11
Listing agent: Anita Merlo, Bosley Real Estate Ltd.
For many buyers who visited this two-storey house, it pleased them that it appears the same as when it was built about 90 years ago, says agent Anita Merlo.
"It was a traditional Canadian Arts and Crafts home, so it had naturally high ceilings, lots of wood trims and leaded glass," she says. "The character was intact."
Adding to the ambience, most rooms have hardwood floors, including a living room with a wood-burning fireplace, an adjacent dining room and a central family room with a bay window.
Three years ago, modern elements were incorporated, such as porcelain heated floors, granite counters and mahogany cabinetry in the kitchen.
The latter also has sliding doors to a deck and secluded backyard facing northeast. "The way the property was situated ... you basically had all day sunshine in this house, which was very nice," adds Ms. Merlo.
All four bedrooms and a four-piece bathroom are upstairs.
Down in the basement, which has a separate entrance, there is a powder room and a recreation room with a walkout.
Three-car parking is available, including a detached garage.
Local amenities include parks, schools and shops, as well as a hospital, GO Train station and highway 400 series.

I miss the humble old province

Author: Robertson, Patricia Dawn

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/i-miss-humble-old-province/docview/382608983/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Now that's the humble, layaway-plan kind of Saskatchewan that I've come to love. Now that we're a choice economic destination, I miss the tattered old Saskatchewan. In the past year, we've gained 16,509 new residents.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=I+miss+the+humble+old+province&amp;author=Robertson%2C+Patricia+Dawn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=A.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=I+miss+the+humble+old+province&amp;author=Robertson%2C+Patricia+Dawn&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=A.17&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   When I heard Peter Mansbridge giddily announce on The National that Saskatchewan is experiencing a population boom, I just about fell off my $300 Brick leather sofa.
Saskatchewan last witnessed a crush of newcomers in 1952-53, when they drilled for oil at Climax. It was also a bumper period for crops.
This recent wave of optimistic newcomers has me pining for the good old days of thrift and economic stagnation, those listless autumn evenings squandered monitoring the Prince Albert CTV affiliate for my favourite pre-winter ad.
It was produced by a family clothing retailer desperately trying to drum up regional business: "Now's a good time to put a small deposit down on your children's winter boots," intones the announcer without a hint of irony.
Now that's the humble, layaway-plan kind of Saskatchewan that I've come to love. Now that we're a choice economic destination, I miss the tattered old Saskatchewan. In the past year, we've gained 16,509 new residents.
For grumpy upstarts like me, this is bad news. I prefer a new neighbour to be the kind whose cars break down, who lines up an underpaid job at the local bar or recycling centre then stays on due to inertia, not for economic gain.
I curse Premier Brad Wall and his uppity Saskatchewan Party. I miss our backward socialist NDP premier Lorne Calvert. He knew how to "gate-keep" prosperity and keep us sparsely populated and down-at-the-heel.
If I craved prosperity and overcrowding, I could have stayed in Alberta. If I want to maintain my downward mobility, I may have to relocate back to Calgary. Who knew?
My sodbuster partner Grant and I came here from the oil patch in 2004. He promised me cheap real estate, wide-open spaces, underpaved roads and the occasional shack-wacky farmer who confronted you with a surly thousand-yard stare at the Co-op.
Now with all of the fancy new residents in our midst, I may have to upgrade my wardrobe from my moth-eaten curling sweater and rubber boots. If I don't, I'll face taunts from the young moms at the post office with their Calgary-inspired hairstreaks and shiny new minivans.
I remember fondly when Saskatchewanians used to boast the country's oldest insured vehicles. It's as if Flint, Mich., morphed into Boca Raton, Fla.
Like all decent Prairie people, I hate change and I'm an underachiever. I told a Prairie books editor recently that I was congenitally incapable of making money and he replied: "You're hired."
I also prefer to dwell in the past. When I'm not listening to Neil Young's weepy Prairie Wind CD, I'm busy wrestling my younger brother Tim for our favourite family heirloom: a silver-plated and autographed Saskatchewan Roughriders serving platter, circa 1963. Tim was a 1964 Grey Cup baby, born while my sportswriter father was absent covering the game, so he feels justifiably entitled to this Prairie prize.
While I'm on the topic of football, I also yearn for the good old days when cash-strapped farmers showed their Rider Pride by trading wheat for game tickets. With all of these arrivistes in our midst, how will I know if that man in the pumpkin helmet seated next to me is a bandwagon jumper or a real sodbuster with roots dating back to pre-Riel Rebellion Saskatchewan, like Grant's family?
Pardon me if I sound just like an Antebellum Age Southerner waxing eloquently about how life was grand before the Civil War. I'm just going to have to get used to our new residents, the money in our midst and all of the social pressures that accompany prosperity.
But there's a glimmer of down-market hope on the horizon.
I visited the Interlake region of Manitoba recently and discovered a few untainted outposts where our family could resettle. But I'm not sure how long that social disparity will endure now that NDP premier Gary Doer has been dispatched to Washington.

Shortened wait time a bonus on remaining units

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/shortened-wait-time-bonus-on-remaining-units/docview/382608107/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's somewhat unique in that respect," Mr. [Jim Ritchie] says. "Who wouldn't want hotel services on occasion?"

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shortened+wait+time+a+bonus+on+remaining+units&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Shortened+wait+time+a+bonus+on+remaining+units&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Accolade
Location: North York
Builder/developer: Tridel
Size: 679 to 2,050 square feet
Price: $270,000 to $1,035,000
Sales centre: 181 Wynford Dr., north of Eglinton Avenue. Open Monday to Thursday from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Saturday, Sunday and holidays from noon to 6 p.m.
Contact: Phone (416) 385-0305 or visit www.tridel.com/accolade)
Purchasing a new condominium often requires buyers to wait years between the time they select their floor plans and the moment they pick up their keys.
Tridel can speed up that process to as little as 90 days at Accolade - a newly completed high-rise at Eglinton Avenue and Wynford Drive - where homeowners began moving in last week.
"Some people don't like to go through the whole pre-sale process and prefer to be able to walk into the building, see all the amenities and look out the windows," says Jim Ritchie, senior vice-president of sales and marketing.
"If someone was to visit with us now ... not only would they be able to see a finished model suite, but they will see completed recreational facilities and the lobby."
Buyers interested in the 34-storey residence can tour the guest suite, fitness centre and a fireside-party room with a bar, kitchen and access to a billiards lounge, dining room and media lounge.
Tridel also made arrangements with the Crowne Plaza hotel next door to allow residents to utilize its facilities, such as a restaurant, yoga room, indoor pool and spa treatment rooms.
Housekeeping and room service are available on a pay-per-use basis.
"It's somewhat unique in that respect," Mr. Ritchie says. "Who wouldn't want hotel services on occasion?"
The 327-unit tower is surrounded by local attractions and essentials including supermarkets, the new Shops at Don Mills, golf courses and popular Edwards Gardens.
"This was a location that appealed to a number of people," Mr. Ritchie says.
Units facing north and south overlook Don Valley parklands and the Don Valley Parkway, which can take commuters downtown within 15 minutes. "We are just east of the Don Valley Parkway and it's certainly accessible to transportation," Mr. Ritchie says.
Though 85 per cent of the suites are sold, there is a wide range of one-bedroom-plus-dens to three-bedrooms available. "There is diversity in suite sizes," Mr. Ritchie says.
Designs typically incorporate master bedrooms with private bathrooms and open kitchens, and principal areas with balcony access.
On the upper levels, the Signature and Penthouse suites will offer kitchens with breakfast areas, master suites with walk-in closets and second bedrooms with en suites in some cases.
These units will be ready for occupancy at the beginning of next year and finished with upscale materials, such as engineered wood floors and 50-ounce broadloom carpeting.
Elsewhere, units will be dressed with laminate floors and 35-ounce broadloom.
The building will incorporate several green initiatives, from low-E, argon-filled, double-glazed windows throughout to Energy Star appliances within individual units.
Last of all, each unit comes with parking and a monthly maintenance fee of 38 cents per square foot.

This ground-level suite has the benefit of a one-of-a-kind layout and location in an eco-friendly building in Roncesvalles Village, says agent Christopher Bibby.
Each unit in the newly built residence, called High Park Lofts, is entered from an interior corridor, yet this 900-square-foot space is one of three with a second street-level entrance.
"It was zoned work/live, so the good thing with [the seller's] unit is that someone could have bought it and used it as an art gallery or office," Mr. Bibby explains.
"People in this specific neighbourhood don't mind being on the street because it's a very inviting neighbourhood."
Local residents enjoy frequenting local shops, restaurants and places of worship. Commuting to other parts of the city is convenient via the subway and Go Train station on Bloor Street.

Loft style features include 12-foot ceilings, large windows along the front den and an open living and dining area with a gas fireplace.
Hardwood floors flow throughout, even in the kitchen where there are stainless-steel kitchen appliances, including a gas stove. "This unit showed quite well," adds Mr. Bibby.
Other perks include ensuite laundry machines, an exterior locker and parking.
A monthly fee of $531 covers the cost of heating, which is fuelled by capturing energy below the Earth's surface. "It's the first condominium in the city with geothermal heating," says Mr. Bibby. "Down the road, there will be long-term savings."
For extra space, owners can use a recreation room and rooftop garden. "It has a spectacular view of the city and you can see the entire downtown core and CN Tower," adds Mr. Bibby.

Low-rise project meant to blend with Queen West neighbours

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/low-rise-project-meant-blend-with-queen-west/docview/382606403/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "We have this saying, 'Get to know your neighbour and get to know your neighbourhood,' " Ms. [Alie Warren] says. "So you're really moving into the fabric of the neighbourhood itself versus just being part of a high-rise development."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Low-rise+project+meant+to+blend+with+Queen+West+neighbours&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Low-rise+project+meant+to+blend+with+Queen+West+neighbours&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-10-02&amp;spage=G.8&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   Two Gladstone
Location: Queen West
Builder/developer: Streetcar Developments
Size: 527 to 1,064 square feet
Price: $229,900 to $509,900
Contact: To register phone 416-362-2988 or visit www.twogladstone.com
Streetcar Developments has built a solid reputation for creating boutique loft condominiums in the city's lower east side, from the Queen City Vinegar Co. Lofts to the Corktown District.
For the first time, the builder's latest venture is destined for another hot neighbourhood clear across town.
This weekend, registered buyers will be invited to the grand opening of Two Gladstone, named after its address at the northwest corner of Queen Street West and Gladstone Avenue, across from the Gladstone Hotel.
The eight-storey residence will contain only 54 suites.
"That would set us apart from most developers in the neighbourhood," says Alie Warren, the builder's vice-president of sales and marketing.
New projects planned for the area are typically high-rises packed with 300 to 400 units, says Shakeel Walji, creative director at the Walsh Group, which is the team helping to market Two Gladstone.
"In terms of height, it's the same size as the Gladstone [Hotel], so it matches really well with the context of the neighbourhood," Mr. Walji says. "It's not one of these tall towers that screams out gentrification."
In fact, the strong collection of local attractions - including trendy restaurants, galleries and designer shops - is the reason why recreational facilities will not be added within the building.
"We have this saying, 'Get to know your neighbour and get to know your neighbourhood,' " Ms. Warren says. "So you're really moving into the fabric of the neighbourhood itself versus just being part of a high-rise development."
The builders also picked up the site for its proximity to public transit. However, bus routes on Gladstone Avenue will be rerouted once construction is done on a tunnel connecting the north and south sections of Dufferin Street nearby.
"Gladstone Avenue will become more of a quiet, residential street," Ms. Warren adds.
By 2011, purchasers can move into the sleek building.
"It is contemporary - as all of our buildings are - however, we always take a nod to the neighbourhood ... and try to complement the surroundings," Ms. Warren says.
"We have the beautiful, historic Gladstone Hotel right across the street from us, so we tried to tie that into some of the brick colouring and design."
Suites will range from one- to two-bedroom-plus-den units with 527 to 1,064 square feet.
"We do have a lot of large outdoor spaces for a lot of the units," Ms. Warren adds. She also notes that they will feature natural gas outlets.
For the most part, floor plans will be open concept with nine-foot ceilings, sliding bedroom doors and kitchen cabinetry along one wall.
Interior decor will include hardwood floors, porcelain tile surfaces, and stone counters in the kitchens. "Everything is basically upgraded as it is," Mr. Walji says.
To reduce energy consumption, units will be outfitted with Energy Star appliances, dual-flush toilets, and heating, ventilating, and air conditioning systems.
There will also be bicycle storage on site. "A lot of people in that neighbourhood do like to ride their bikes, so that would be very handy for a lot of buyers," Ms. Warren says.
Parking can be purchased for $27,000, and lockers from $2,500.
Monthly maintenance fees will be 47 cents per square foot, including gas and water costs.

Abstract: The arrival of the salary cap spelled the end of the conventional dynasty, but the Penguins have a good chance to become the first team since the Detroit Red Wings of the late 1990s to win two consecutive Stanley Cups. Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin (above) are two of the best three forwards in the league and they are still developing. Goaltender Marc-André Fleury showed in last spring's playoffs he is among the league's elite.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=SIX+DAYS%2C+SIX+NHL+DIVISIONS+%2F+TODAY%3A+THE+ATLANTIC&amp;author=Shoalts%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-29&amp;spage=S.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   NEW JERSEY DEVILS
The last couple of years have not been kind to the Devils. The move to a new arena in Newark, N.J., has not produced a financial bonanza and the exodus of free agents continued last off-season with Brian Gionta and John
Madden saying goodbye, along with head coach Brent Sutter. Also, goaltender Martin Brodeur is not getting any younger. But Jacques Lemaire has returned to coaching duties and his defensive philosophies usually produce success with nondescript lineups. And Brodeur (above) may be 37 but he's still good enough to push the Devils through the playoffs. The problem is, they probably won't get there.
NEW YORK ISLANDER
Only the Phoenix Coyotes keep this from being the worst organization in the league to play for but, unlike the Coyotes, the Islanders have shown signs of life. They signed goaltenders Martin Biron and Dwayne Roloson for some decent insurance on the perennially injured Rick DiPietro and his lifetime contract. There is also No. 1 draft pick John Tavares (above) to provide hope for future scoring and underrated defenceman Mark Streit. Unfortunately, things drop off precipitously after that. Owner Charles Wang will not spend more than the minimum on payroll until or unless local politicians approve his real-estate development plans that include a refurbished arena. Who knows when that will be?
NEW YORK RANGERS
John Tortorella may not make a lot of friends but the guy can coach. He showed that last season by propelling the problem-ridden Rangers into the playoffs. This season, he has Marian Gaborik (above), Ales Kotalik and Vinny Prospal to provide enough offence that, along with the goaltending of Henrik Lundqvist, may make up for the team's many deficiencies on defence. Not to mention in the front office as well, although general manager Glen Sather managed not to match his huge pratfall of 2008 when he signed faded defenceman Wade Redden to a long, expensive contract. The playoffs are probable but holes at centre and defence rule out a long run.
PHILADELPHIA FLYERS
There are a lot of ifs with this team, but if a few things fall into place the Flyers could be one of the top four teams in the Eastern Conference. The ifs start in goal, where general manager Paul Holmgren issued a parole from Russia to Ray Emery. But he has to prove he is no longer the handful the Ottawa Senators finally tired of and has the discipline to match his talent. The Flyers lost some scoring with the departures of Mike Knuble and Joffrey Lupul but the arrival of defenceman Chris Pronger is a huge step forward. If the Flyers can stay healthy, scoring stars Mike Richards, Simon Gagné and Jeff Carter (above) could take them a long way.
PITTSBURGH PENGUINS
The arrival of the salary cap spelled the end of the conventional dynasty, but the Penguins have a good chance to become the first team since the Detroit Red Wings of the late 1990s to win two consecutive Stanley Cups. Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin (above) are two of the best three forwards in the league and they are still developing. Goaltender Marc-André Fleury showed in last spring's playoffs he is among the league's elite. Losing Rob Scuderi hurt the defence, but if Jay McKee should more than fill the gap if he stays healthy. Crosby will have a full season with wingers Bill Guerin and Chris Kunitz, which should shake any Cup hangover.

Design that invests in a better world

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/design-that-invests-better-world/docview/382611868/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Mr. [Stephen Burks]'s strategy came into focus in early 2005, when he visited South Africa for the first time. In a Cape Town township, he found an artisan whom he describes as "a side-of-the road, wire and bead souvenir gift-item producer." Working with this man's interest in wire-frame construction, Mr. Burks designed a collection of furniture that could be made by someone with few high-tech skills.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Design+that+invests+in+a+better+world&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-25&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Design+that+invests+in+a+better+world&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-25&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 'Conscious consumers ... are looking for more authentic products that tell a story,' says Stephen Burks
jmays@globeandmail.com
If your taste in home furnishings runs to the unusual and up-market, you might already have something by the hot young American designer Stephen Burks.
It could be a papier-mâché table made from shredded magazines by South African crafts folk, and marketed by Cappellini. Or it might be a silk duvet cover fashioned by artisans in India. Or a table and chairs crafted in nylon and zinc tubing, distributed by the Italian manufacturer Moroso, that Mr. Burks did in collaboration with traditional weavers in Senegal.
What you may not know is that, in buying a Burks piece, you invested in a contemporary industrial design practice that is more like community organizing than the standard model of an isolated genius slaving away in an atelier.
To find out more about this talented designer's approach, you can catch Mr. Burks's keynote address this afternoon at the IIDEX/NeoCon Canada design fair in Toronto. Or just read on: I talked with him last week by phone from his home town of New York.
"Design is a powerful force in business in the first world, so why can't it be acknowledged as a potentially powerful business force in the developing world?" Mr. Burks said. "Look at how postwar Italy developed out of ruin to become this powerhouse of design in only 60 years! I like to use that as an analogy for what can happen in the developing world, if we use design appropriately, if we work with existing cultures. ...
"We're trying to build a bridge from the developing world to the first world through product development and through distribution."
Mr. Burks's strategy came into focus in early 2005, when he visited South Africa for the first time. In a Cape Town township, he found an artisan whom he describes as "a side-of-the road, wire and bead souvenir gift-item producer." Working with this man's interest in wire-frame construction, Mr. Burks designed a collection of furniture that could be made by someone with few high-tech skills. At first, the artisan had only a handful of collaborators from his township, but the operation soon grew to employ 50 local workers. The Tatu collection is now marketed worldwide by Artecnica.
Since the breakthrough Capetown experiment, Mr. Burks has similarly joined forces with artisans across Asia, Africa and South America. His scheme depends on the interest of "conscious consumers" in the developed world who, he says, "already have the fancy sofa, the fancy lounge chair and lamp and so on, and are looking for more authentic products that tell a story, products that come from a place. I think everything we experience today is so mediated through technology, we have very little authentic experience, and our products can begin to speak to that, and really connect us all through the culture that we share."
But can a model that seems to be working well for Mr. Burks in the developing world function effectively in the developed world? No problem, the designer said.
"Considering that unemployment is at its highest rate in decades in many cities around the world, it's totally viable that people can begin to make a living using their hands. ... We don't try to get everything made by hand in these products, but we try to use the hand for the things that the machine can't do. It's a matter of moving certain crafts traditions into the future through their combination with industrially produced components."
What Mr. Burks brings to the table, in addition to advanced design intelligence, is insider contact with some of the most prominent names in the luxury-goods industry. Since founding his studio, Readymade Projects, in Brooklyn in 1997, he has done packaging for such clients as Estee Lauder, Missoni, Karl Lagerfeld, Calvin Klein and Clinique, and he continues to create home furnishings for an array of Italian manufacturers.
"It's not just about transforming the American home as the site for social change, but about offering the consumer a product that has social change integrated into the production process. Social change is part of the deal."
Stephen Burks's keynote address begins at 4 p.m. today at the
IIDEX/NeoCon Canada design
fair at the Direct Energy Centre
in Toronto.

Title: Design that invests in a better world

30-SECOND SPOT / DISPATCHES FROM THE WORLD OF MEDIA AND ADVERTISING

Author: Houpt, Simon

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/30-second-spot-dispatches-world-media-advertising/docview/382611777/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Have you heard from your friendly neighbourhood Nigerian scammer lately? Maybe he's too busy playing with his Sony PS3. In an ad for the popular console, a gamer asks the company about (true) rumours they've dropped the price to $299 (U.S.). "You can't believe everything you read on the Internet," replies a company spokesman, "otherwise I'd be a Nigerian millionaire by now." Uh oh: The government of Nigeria caught wind of the ad and asked for compensation.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=30-SECOND+SPOT+%2F+DISPATCHES+FROM+THE+WORLD+OF+MEDIA+AND+ADVERTISING&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-25&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=30-SECOND+SPOT+%2F+DISPATCHES+FROM+THE+WORLD+OF+MEDIA+AND+ADVERTISING&amp;author=Houpt%2C+Simon&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-25&amp;spage=B.5&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: 1 Does the bumpy economy have you reaching for the Pepto-Bismol? You're not the only one: Despite a price point about 60 per cent higher than generic brands, the liquid form of Procter & Gamble's magical pink stomach-soothing potion has added 0.7 points in market share over the last year; its tablet form has added 2.5 points. P & G credits in part a comical campaign featuring a flatulent donkey. The other secret of their success? A willingness to keep spending last year even as the recession took hold. That takes guts. And if there's anything the makers of Pepto-Bismol know about, it's guts.
2 Is fashion advertising bad for your health? Concerned that airbrushed models are projecting a too-perfect image that could prompt impressionable young women to develop eating disorders, 50 members of the French parliament are calling for a warning to be slapped on all retouched photographs, whether they be in ads, on packaging, or as part of a political campaign. Touting the law, French parliamentarian Valerie Boyer said in a statement this week: "These images can make people believe in a reality that often does not exist." Like, say, all advertising?
3 Has Don Draper quit smoking? A cigarette held suavely in his right hand is as much a part of the ad man's identity as a highball and a leer. But in Canadian transit ads for AMC's Mad Men , Draper's smoke has been cut out of the iconic silhouette, the victim of local anti-tobacco laws. "Smoking is a big part of the show," said Jan Diedrichsen of Rainbow Network Sales, which reps the network's shows abroad. "But it's much more important for us to get promotion for the show than to stick to our guns and have cigarettes on there."
4 Have you heard from your friendly neighbourhood Nigerian scammer lately? Maybe he's too busy playing with his Sony PS3. In an ad for the popular console, a gamer asks the company about (true) rumours they've dropped the price to $299 (U.S.). "You can't believe everything you read on the Internet," replies a company spokesman, "otherwise I'd be a Nigerian millionaire by now." Uh oh: The government of Nigeria caught wind of the ad and asked for compensation. If we were Sony, we'd totally offer cash, as soon as Nigeria sends a bank account number where we can wire the money.
5 Actually, maybe Nigeria should just wire the money to our favourite magazine editors; they could use the help. If you pick up the October issues of U.S. consumer monthlies, they'll likely seem lighter than usual, and it's not just because you've been working out. Ad pages are down 20.1 per cent compared to a year ago, according to Media Industry Newsletter. In the wake of the real estate bubble collapse, the biggest losers include Architectural Digest (down 49.4 per cent), Veranda (47.4 per cent) and Dwell (45 per cent). Still, we're betting there would be readers for anyone who wants to start up Apocalyptic Survivalist's Fancy.

Listing agents: Douglas and Trevor Freeman, Freeman Real Estate Ltd.
Within two days of advertising the sale of this one-bedroom plus den suite in Little Italy, a handful of buyers submitted competing offers to agents Douglas and Trevor Freeman.
"A lot of people want to live in that area, but the majority of the houses are much more than $300,000 or $350,000," Trevor Freeman says. "So there's really only a couple of buildings in the area."
Completed on the fifth floor of a fairly new mid-rise, the 700-square-foot suite was finished with hardwood floors, stainless steel kitchen appliances and floor-to-ceiling windows facing south.
"It shows very well, and it had a nice view of the city," Mr. Freeman says.
There is an open kitchen with a granite-topped peninsula and extended breakfast bar that separates a living and dining area with glass doors to a Juliet balcony.
The den contains a built-in desk and shelving, including a hideaway Murphy bed. "It acted well as a second bedroom," the agent says.
The master is the only enclosed space with a walk-in closet and a second Juliet balcony.
The unit also comes with a full bathroom and stacked laundry machines, plus a locker and underground parking, "which is key, especially in that area," Mr. Freeman says.
The monthly fee of $396 covers the cost of heating and upkeep of common facilities, such as the gym, party room and recreation room.
Residents can also find a variety of social events at local restaurants, lounges and cafes along College Street.

The expensive downside of the new frugal consumer

Author: McKenna, Barrie

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/expensive-downside-new-frugal-consumer/docview/382616056/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: When Ben Bernanke gathers today with his Federal Reserve colleagues around the central bank's massive oak-and-glass boardroom table, it's a safe bet they'll discuss the fate of U.S. consumers.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+expensive+downside+of+the+new+frugal+consumer&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-22&amp;spage=B.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=The+expensive+downside+of+the+new+frugal+consumer&amp;author=McKenna%2C+Barrie&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-22&amp;spage=B.9&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: bmckenna@globeandmail.com
When Ben Bernanke gathers today with his Federal Reserve colleagues around the central bank's massive oak-and-glass boardroom table, it's a safe bet they'll discuss the fate of U.S. consumers.
Mr. Bernanke has acknowledged the recession is almost certainly over.
The larger concern now is what will power the recovery.
For decades now, the consumer has been the country's economic engine, accounting for 70 per cent of activity.
But there are signs this is changing. We may be witnessing a new age of frugality, not unlike what occurred after the Depression of the 1930s.
The Great Recession has had a powerful effect on Americans. Their net worth has fallen to $50.4-trillion (U.S.) from $62.6-trillion since the slump began at the end of 2007. Roughly $5-trillion in housing wealth and $6-trillion in stock wealth has vanished, and will likely take years to rebuild.
The response has been predictable. Americans are rapidly paying down debt, spending less and saving more. Personal spending has tumbled in four of the past six quarters - the first time that's occurred since the U.S. government started tracking it in 1947. Consumer spending fell in 2008 for the first time since 1980, and it will likely be lower again this year.
After years of piling on debt, Americans are now rapidly shedding it - by nearly $170-billion so far. Measured as a percentage of disposable income, household debt has fallen to 129 per cent from a peak of 136 per cent.
That's still high by historic standards, which suggests the belt-tightening may still have a way to go. The average debt-to-income ratio of the past 30 years in 93 per cent. The ratio was 100 per cent at the start of this decade, and to get it back to that level would mean getting rid of another $3.2-trillion of debt, economists Julian Jessop and Paul Ashworth of Capital Economics estimated in a recent report. And that could take another 3½ years, they figure.
Less debt means less credit for many other things, and a new normal.
Fewer and smaller cars. Less extravagant homes. A lot fewer gadgets, fixtures and furnishings in those homes. And a more modest travel and dining budget.
Lower spending will also take a bite out of state and local tax receipts, and by extension the services governments provide.
On the other hand, it is possible that Americans will merely go back to their spendthrift ways, as they did after each of the previous post-Second World War recessions.
But there's reason to believe this cycle is different. The Baby Boom generation lost a large chunk of its retirement savings in the stock and real estate crash. With so many of them nearing retirement, they'll need to quickly rebuild their savings while they're still in their prime income-earning years.
Something has to give. A recent study by AlixPartners LLP concluded that spending will eventually recover, but at a significantly lower level - roughly 86 per cent of pre-recession levels.
If that scenario plays out, it will have a profound effect on the economies of countries such as Canada, which depend so heavily on exports to the U.S.
Imagine for a moment the impact on Canada if the new normal means Americans buy smaller homes, more austere furnishings and fewer cars. That would mean less demand for Canadian lumber, steel, oil, cars, auto parts, construction materials and the like.
"Consumers are no longer in a position to power the U.S. economy, let alone the global economy as they have done for most of the past quarter century," Moody's Economy.com chief economist Mark Zandi argued in a recent report. "With incomes under pressure, debt loads overwhelming and nest eggs diminished, it will be difficult for consumers to simply do their part in contributing to economic growth."
More troubling still, the United States has yet to tackle one of its greatest long-term challenges - adequately funding its generous social security and Medicare regimes. Both programs are running out of cash, and Americans will eventually have to pay vastly higher taxes or get a lot less when they retire.
It isn't the way most Baby Boomers imagined they'd be walking into the sunset.

Film fest's new home takes a bow

Author: John Bentley Mays

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/film-fests-new-home-takes-bow/docview/382607912/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Five theatres, with seating for 550, 350, 250, 150 and 80 people respectively, will accommodate TIFF's vigorous festival and year-round lineup of film screenings. Allowance has been made in the design of all these theatres for both digital and 35-millimetre projection, and four feature stages for performances, panel discussions, lectures and other non-film events.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Film+fest%27s+new+home+takes+a+bow&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-18&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Film+fest%27s+new+home+takes+a+bow&amp;author=John+Bentley+Mays&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-18&amp;spage=G.2&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: Still under construction, Festival Tower plays to its audience
jmays@globeandmail.com
Hogtown is home to numerous movie fêtes, but none with more sheer star power and widespread local loyalty than the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF). The one important thing TIFF hasn't had until now, however, is a single address from which to run its various activities. (In addition to the big festival held each September, TIFF operates Cinematheque Ontario, a large movie library and a host of other year-round programs.) But that will be remedied next spring or summer, when festival director Piers Handling and his staff decamp from their offices scattered across downtown Toronto and set up shop in the new 42-level Festival Tower, now nearing completion at the junction of King Street West and John Street.
Designed by the well-known Toronto firm of Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg, this mixed-use high-rise is composed of two parts. The portion at street level and up to the height of a 10-storey building, to be called the Bell Lightbox, will include TIFF's staff headquarters, library and theatres, restaurants, an art gallery and a gala exterior flight of steps modelled on one that graces a modernist villa in Capri.
This stairway rising above King Street West could be viewed, I suppose, as a rather extravagant architectural gesture in a time of economic austerity. But what would a votive shrine to cinema be without an exotic stair? Think of the final scenes of Gone With the Wind , and the descent of mad silent-screen star Norma Desmond in Sunset Boulevard . Festival Tower's exterior stair, along with one planned for the ground-floor lobby, are touches of fantasy that should be allowed even in - or especially in - hard times.
As I found during a hard-hat walkabout last week, TIFF's digs in the new structure promise to be generally deluxe: roomy for the staff who work behind the scenes of the festival, well-provided with natural light streaming into the space through tall windows and welcoming to the movie-going public.
Five theatres, with seating for 550, 350, 250, 150 and 80 people respectively, will accommodate TIFF's vigorous festival and year-round lineup of film screenings. Allowance has been made in the design of all these theatres for both digital and 35-millimetre projection, and four feature stages for performances, panel discussions, lectures and other non-film events. (I tried to find out if TIFF will be lending out its technologically cutting-edge theatres to outside groups, but, perhaps due to the crush of the festival now under way, the press people didn't return my call.) Turning from the Bell Lightbox to the tower's second element, the 37-level condominium stack, one finds less to be excited about. It's conventional high-end Toronto condo housing: expensive ($800 a square foot), and a bit too finely diced: Units range from just 487 square feet in area (in a studio apartment), up to only about 2,300 square feet in the largest penthouse suite.
But there are compensations available to anyone who chooses to live in the relatively modest spaces of Festival Tower. One is the view from the lower storeys (which, in many parts of town, is tiresome). It's attractively hard and urban, with tall buildings round about that are already built or on the way. Not all these neighbouring structures are interesting - the Holiday Inn next door is an aesthetic calamity - but the total ensemble of structures visible from the tower has a tough, tight look that I, for one, wouldn't mind waking up to.
Another recompense is, of course, TIFF - though the busy comings and goings of movie stars, moguls, fans and paparazzi around the tower each September might become trying. But residents will be able to avoid some of the hubbub - not all will want to, I suspect - by entering the condominium block through its private entrance, off John Street.
And while new condo complexes occasionally have screening rooms, few I've seen are as plush as the one planned for Festival Tower. It's a 60-seat theatre outfitted to the same high-tech levels as the spaces dedicated to TIFF's activities.
So far, I haven't said anything much about Festival Tower's exterior. That's because I don't know what to make of it. Judging the King Street façade is surely premature: The trim's not on yet, and a few splashes of gleaming metal or sparkling light could abruptly modify its appearance. As things stand now, however, there seems to be an awful lot of glass muscling its way toward the street - a 10-storey, block-long cascade of it, a Niagara of glass.
But be that as it may, Toronto has something to look forward to, once Festival Tower gets up and running: a fresh focus for this town's ongoing fascination with the movies.

Community gets second-phase release this weekend

Author: Yu, Sydnia

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/community-gets-second-phase-release-this-weekend/docview/382606202/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: "It's nicely located in Bradford with a lot of commercial services already in place," says Ms. [Sandra Frasson]. "Usually, it's the other way around: homes are moving in and people have to wait for retail to follow."

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Community+gets+second-phase+release+this+weekend&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-18&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=Community+gets+second-phase+release+this+weekend&amp;author=Yu%2C+Sydnia&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-18&amp;spage=G.7&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text: SUMMERLYN VILLAGE LOCATION: Bradford BUILDER/DEVELOPER:
Great Gulf Homes SIZE: singles from 1,465 to 3,270 square feet; semis from 1,445 to 1,945 square feet PRICE: singles from the $290,000s to low $400,000s; semis from $260,000s to high $290,000s SALES CENTRE: 22 Downy
Emerald Dr., off Summerlyn Trail, north of Highway 88 (Holland Street). Open
Monday to Thursday from
1 p.m. to 8 p.m.; weekends and holidays from 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
CONTACT: Phone 905-775-3461 or visit greatgulfhomes.com With the bulk of 180 homes sold in the first phase of a low-rise community in Bradford, Great Gulf Homes will release a new collection of semi-detached and detached houses this weekend.
The grand opening of the second phase of the project - called Summerlyn Village - begins tomorrow. Colleen Rusholme, 97.3 FM EZ Rock's Morning Show co-host, will be on location for a barbecue held the next day from noon to 4 p.m.
"The site's done very well from a sales standpoint," says Sandra Frasson, vice-president of sales and marketing. "It's gone from a construction site to an actual neighbourhood where people are living."
Located just 30 minutes north of Toronto, the 340-acre site will grow to encompass 1,000 families, as well as recreational and public facilities off Holland Street West (Highway 88) just west of Professor Day Drive.
"We wanted to develop a master-planned community where someone could live and play," says Ms. Frasson.
For instance, there will be a new school, library, recreation centre, and town centre.
A pond, creek, wildlife corridor and natural wetlands will offer a scenic backdrop, along with native plantings throughout and 60-acres of protected woodland home to century-old oaks and maples. Also in the works are new parks, including one to open this fall, and an extensive trail system. A ten metre tall berm will act as a natural buffer along the site's western boundary and contain trail with signage outlining exercise routines.
"People are becoming much more active," says Ms. Frasson. "They can take their kids biking and they can take a walk. And when they're walking its actually something interesting as opposed to just walking around the block."
Buyers in the second phase can move into homes next fall, and immediately make use of established schools, GO Train station and shops in the small town. More stores are also being developed nearby along Holland Street.
"It's nicely located in Bradford with a lot of commercial services already in place," says Ms. Frasson. "Usually, it's the other way around: homes are moving in and people have to wait for retail to follow."
Taking cues from local neighbourhoods, the site embraces heritage streetscapes, from old-world English-style lampposts to brick facades with trimmed peaked gables, accent windows, shutters and front porches.
Four model homes are on display, including the 2,020-square foot Chicory and 2,235-square-foot Primrose design on 36-foot lots, and the Birch and Maple layouts - 2,435 and 3,160 square-feet respectively - on 40-foot lots.
"People like what they see and gravitate to those plans," adds Ms. Frasson.
Most designs will be two-storeys with single or double garages, main floor laundry rooms, dining rooms and eat-in kitchens. In some cases, there are dens and second floor family rooms.
"There are lots of open spaces and new fresh ideas on kitchen layouts," says Ms. Frasson. "They're really family-friendly plans."
Interiors will feature fireplaces, decorative columns, broadloom and natural oak railings and pickets.
