How to climb out of a hole this big...$2,775,000,000 IN THE RED

Author: Ebner, David

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/how-climb-out-hole-this-big-2-775-000-red/docview/382608512/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: This new-found pragmatism stems from the rot in the B.C. economy, the deadwood underpinnings that were easily obscured during the province's prolonged expansion. The hard reversal in B.C.'s fortunes is severe and, in some of the worst ways, its woes resemble those of the United States. It's suffering from the after effects of an expansion that was too reliant on a hot real estate market and consumer spending and characterized by soaring imports and weak exports.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=How+to+climb+out+of+a+hole+this+big...%242%2C775%2C000%2C000+IN+THE+RED&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-05&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=How+to+climb+out+of+a+hole+this+big...%242%2C775%2C000%2C000+IN+THE+RED&amp;author=Ebner%2C+David&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-05&amp;spage=B.1&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   For most of this decade, British Columbia's economy outpaced the rest of Canada's. But the reversal of fortunes in the province has been severe. The unsettling truth: many of its economic woes resemble those of the U.S. - too much reliance on real estate and construction jobs, not enough strength in exports. But as the province suffers a comedown, there are a few hopeful signs of a new economy taking root - and a serious debate about how to move beyond boom-and-bust cycles
debner@globeandmailcom
Colin Hansen's shoes tell the tale.
All through last autumn, as the global financial system teetered on the precipice of implosion, as the United States sunk deeper in to recession, British Columbia's Finance Minister insisted the province would be able to shake off the anvil taking everyone else down.
Such blithe - and baseless - optimism is now gone. Mr. Hansen, who delivered the province's second budget this week for fiscal 2009-10, chose to wear his oldest pair of black brogues, in the tradition of Canadian finance ministers using footwear to relate the story of their budgets.
It is a stark contrast to the boom years earlier this decade, when incomes, employment and economic output in Canada's westernmost province outpaced the rest of country. In 2005, Mr. Hansen wore a pair of running shoes, a symbol of the province's momentum. The next year, new finance minister Carole Taylor wore a posh pair of Gucci pumps.
B.C. is in trouble. Like elsewhere else, the government deficit has exploded, from $495-million budgeted in February to nearly $3-billion now. Mr. Hansen's sunny disposition has vanished and, while B.C. is expected to recover from recession, the minister was frank that maintaining that growth could be tenuous - a fall back into recession is a "distinct possibility."
This new-found pragmatism stems from the rot in the B.C. economy, the deadwood underpinnings that were easily obscured during the province's prolonged expansion. The hard reversal in B.C.'s fortunes is severe and, in some of the worst ways, its woes resemble those of the United States. It's suffering from the after effects of an expansion that was too reliant on a hot real estate market and consumer spending and characterized by soaring imports and weak exports. Last year, B.C. imported $24-billion more in goods and services from other provinces and countries than it sold to them, the province's biggest-ever trade deficit.
As with the U.S., British Columbia is grappling with soaring numbers of unemployed. B.C. has lost 67,000 jobs since August, 2008 - nearly 2½ times the number lost in Alberta. At its peak, fully 10 per cent of the provincial work force was employed in construction - a proportion that's "off the charts," said economist Douglas Porter at BMO Nesbitt Burns Inc.
The recession brought with it plunging revenue from forestry, natural gas, and personal and corporate income taxes, leaving a $2-billion gouge in the provincial treasury and necessitating Mr. Hansen's red-ink revision this week. "The main theme is fiscal austerity," said Jock Finlayson, executive vice-president of the Business Council of British Columbia. "It'll characterize the next three or four years. We're not going to see a dramatic, sudden turnaround."
Beyond the trade deficit, other key economic fundamentals - from exports to productivity and business investment - do not bode well. The 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver and Whistler offer a glimmer of good times, but B.C. is an economy in transition with no clear direction on where it's going to go.
Still, as the province suffers a comedown from an economic high, there are distinct stirrings of the future, a curious blend of old and new - and a serious debate about where it should focus its efforts to move beyond the boom-and-bust cycles of forestry, natural gas and real estate. Most of all, the province desperately wants to avoid a repeat of the 1990s, which is widely remembered as a lost decade for B.C. as the rest of the world boomed.
Life after forestry
Even before the recession, B.C. business leaders were worried. The Business Council of B.C., a pan-industry group, organized a series called Outlook 2020 comprised of four meetings this year and 29 policy papers, all trying to imagine how and where an economy rooted in forestry goes in the 21st century.
For David Emerson, the former federal minister of trade and industry who has also managed forestry company Canfor Corp. and the Vancouver International Airport, the future of B.C.'s economy depends on stronger exports.
The province has to see itself as the bridge between Asia and the U.S., Mr. Emerson said. In Asia, B.C. has to forget about waiting for Ottawa to forge closer ties and make the move itself - more aggressively flogging its resources there, which it has slowly begun to do. And Mr. Emerson wants B.C. to recognize post-secondary certifications from Asia and push for a far greater exchange of professors and scientists, for research and technology partnerships - all with the aim of building stronger trade links.
"You need to cross the cultural divide to stoke trade," Mr. Emerson said. "We ought to be creaming it in Asia and we're really not."
B.C. is not an export power, a fact that belies the province's geography as an obvious gateway to Asia. Politicians certainly like to market the province as an export hub, given the strength of the local Asian community and the size of the Port Metro Vancouver.
But trade as a percentage of the B.C. economy is, in fact, significantly smaller than the rest of Canada, where trade titans such as Alberta and Ontario dominate, according to an Outlook 2020 study by the University of Victoria and led by business professor Jen Baggs. Just 17 per cent of the B.C. economy is merchandise exports, barely half that of Canada (30 per cent) and Ontario (32 per cent) and far behind Alberta (38 per cent). In dollar terms, B.C. exports just $8,000 per citizen, province statistics indicate, less than three-quarters of the Canadian level of $11,300.
Mr. Emerson, like others in the province, sees some of B.C.'s future in the past. B.C. grew as a resources economy and the province's businesses have the opportunity to create technology with resources, much like Finland has done with forestry.
"There's almost unlimited scope to spin technology off our resource base," Mr. Emerson said.
Jonathan Rhone is among a vanguard of executives trying to do exactly that.
New technologies
When he graduated from University of British Columbia in the mid-1980s, with an undergraduate degree in environmental studies, B.C.'s economy was one dominated by forestry, a business essentially unchanged for decades: Cut down trees, put them through a mill, sell the wood to the U.S.
His father was not impressed when Mr. Rhone lost interest in going to law school and demanded the young man get a "real job." So, he packed off for Calgary and found work in the oil business.
Mr. Rhone returned in the early 1990s, and in 2003 co-founded Nexterra Systems Corp., one of 100 or so technology-intensive small firms in the Vancouver region. Together generating about $1-billion in annual revenue, it is the core of a burgeoning clean-power cluster of companies.
Nexterra designs small-scale biomass facilities to generate heat and electricity for customers such as universities. Its technology led to a $30-million partnership this year with General Electric Co. to build an advanced gasification system. The company's systems are built at foundries in smaller centres in the province, places like Kamloops, Kelowna, and 100 Mile House, whose fortunes have for years have ebbed and flowed on forestry.
Fed with wood, the technology uses air, steam and oxygen to convert the fuel, at 900C, into a synthetic gas, which can then be used to produce heat or steam. Working with GE, Nexterra wants to advance the system so that it can be used to power turbines in existing infrastructure that generate electricity. The numbers are still small but the gains have been rapid: Nexterra's revenue has surged to $20-million from less than $1-million two years ago.
The company's first customer was Tolko Industries Ltd., a forestry company that uses the technology on a mill near Kamloops to replace natural gas. But the big opportunity is in exports; Nexterra has made sales of its systems to the University of South Carolina and to Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, the largest energy research lab in the United States.
The promise of B.C. as a clean-energy capital is Mr. Rhone's vision for the province's economic future, the envisaged blend of resources and technology. He pictures the sector - which also includes firms like Westport Innovations Inc., which designs technology so diesel engines can run on natural gas, and upstart electricity generators such as Plutonic Power Corp. - as a $5-billion industry within a decade and a crucial part of the province's economy.
"I'd like B.C. to really double down on this sector. If this is truly one of the fastest-growing markets in the world, are we going to be sellers - or are we just going to be buyers?" Mr. Rhone said. He's convinced that the combination of the current small cluster of companies in the business, as well as Vancouver's attributes as a beautiful place to live and the province's natural resources, can be combined to make B.C. a winner in an industry on which other jurisdictions around the world have pinned big hopes.
The Liberal government of Gordon Campbell has made some of the right moves to encourage the development of such emerging businesses. It has slashed taxes businesses pay, as well as personal income taxes. It has simplified a tangle of provincial regulations. The province is the first jurisdiction in Canada to enact a carbon tax. Putting a price on fossil fuels is considered a cornerstone of building a clean-energy economy. And it has set up a $25-million fund specifically for clean energy.
But the dollars are a fraction of what's being spent elsewhere, especially in recession-fighting stimulus packages. According to consultancy New Energy Finance, Canada is pumping $800-million in to clean energy as part of its $40-billion stimulus injection. But U.S. programs aimed at clean energy dwarf Canada's.
Still, several well-known B.C. entrepreneurs have been lured away from traditional industries toward clean energy. One is Ross Beaty, chairman of Pan American Silver Corp., one of the world's top silver producers. Mr. Beaty's day job is chief executive officer of Magma Energy Corp., which had a $110-million initial public offering this summer and wants to become a major geothermal power company.
Don McInnes is another. He was once a mining financier. Today, he is CEO of Plutonic Power, which is building a $660-million power project north of Vancouver with GE. The project uses run-of-river technology, which takes part of the flow of a river into a pipe and runs the water through a turbine to generate power. While controversial in B.C., the Liberal government is staunchly behind such efforts and Plutonic-GE have proposed a much larger $4-billion project
First steps
Attracting companies such as GE to work in B.C. is seen by economists and business leaders as an important step to rebuilding the provincial economy. Mr. McInnes sees B.C.'s abundance of hydro power - and the potential to greatly expand it - as another major strength if exploited, particularly for rural areas of the province.
But there's also the potential - though contentious in B.C. - for power exports, which Mr. McInnes sees as a win for the province, as do some environmentalists like climate scientist Andrew Weaver at the University of Victoria.
Mr. McInnes looks south to Google Inc. in California and its massive appetite for electricity to power the servers that make its online products work. In Kelowna, a local company called RackForce, in a partnership with IBM, has opened part of a large data centre. Competing regions such as Oregon also rely on cheap hydro energy to attract server farms used by Google and others.
"Google has come from nowhere and now Google as a company consumes [the equivalent of] a third of the electricity [used by] of all of British Columbia," Mr. McInnes said. "We have a tremendous opportunity to build on clean energy. It's not just generation of clean electricity. Who wants to consume it - and let's bring them here."
All of this talk about building a new economic base is motivated by a desire to tame the wild ebbs and flows, that have long characterized a resources-based economy.
"I don't think I've ever been to a government meeting where someone doesn't say, 'We have to diversify the economy, we're too vulnerable to resources,'" said Jim Brander, a business professor and international trade specialist at University of British Columbia.
But that doesn't mean it's a universally held view. Instead of running away from historical and current strengths, Mr. Finlayson at the Business Council of B.C. argues resources should remain the primary focus. "If you ask the questions: What do we produce that the world wants to buy? What are we good at? Where do we have competitive advantage? The answer, overwhelmingly, is resources, resource-based goods, and technology connected with that."
Today's troubles in B.C., beyond the battering the economy has taken because of the global recession, are the result of growing pains, according to people like Daniel Muzyka, business dean at UBC. The province is in transition. It's no longer a resources-only economy. But isn't yet something more.
Still, there are modest signs of a new economy taking root. Nexterra may be one. Another is a move by Walt Disney Co.'s Pixar unit, the computer animation pioneer set to open its first studio outside of California in Vancouver's Yaletown neighbourhood. To the south, in Richmond, Microsoft Corp. two years ago opened a software development centre, one that the local political and business leaders hope sparks a spinoff of smaller upstart firms.
"Getting Disney here was terrific. We have to do more of that," Mr. Muzyka said. "But the next five to 10 years are going to be bumpy."
******
Six companies building B.C.'s economic future
Nexterra Systems Corp.
Industry: Biomass
The six-year-old Vancouver company has seen annual revenue jump to $20-million from less than $1-million in just two years. Nexterra designs biomass systems that generate heat and steam - and soon, electricity - and the company has a $30-million development partnership with General Electric Co.
Copper Mountain Mining Corp.
Industry: Mining
Headed by veteran miner Jim O'Rourke, the company is reopening and expanding a dormant copper mine about 300 kilometres east of Vancouver. The $400-million development, set to open in 2011, will be the second-biggest copper operation in B.C. and third largest in Canada.
EnCana Corp.
Industry: Natural gas
Canada's No. 1 gas and oil producer is headquartered in Calgary but is the largest private sector capital spender in B.C., as it pours money into the province's remote and rugged northeast. Several huge gas
deposits, including Horn River, were discovered by EnCana
earlier this decade.
West Fraser Timber Co. Ltd.
Industry: Forestry
Even though forestry has been crushed by the housing crash in the United States, and swaths of the province's forests have been decimated by the pine beetle, B.C. has some of the world's best sawmills. West Fraser, the leader, forecasts a strong future when recovery finally emerges.
Pixar
Industry: Film animation
The Walt Disney Co.-owned computer animation pioneer, maker of this summer's hit Up , will soon open its first studio outside California in a Vancouver's creative cluster called Yaletown, a neighbourhood full of old brick buildings that once housed light industrial enterprises. Pixar was drawn by a tax break, local talent and proximity to headquarters.
Microsoft Canada Co.
Industry: Software
The world's dominant software maker has development centres in many countries and two years ago opened one in the Vancouver suburb of Richmond. Par Singh, the centre's managing director, sees the hundreds of employees as a spark for the region's tech future: "If I look at an analogy of a mall, I want us to be an anchor tenant."
David Ebner
******
B.C. SNAPSHOTS
MERCHANDISE EXPORTS
While B.C. sits on the Pacific Ocean, the province itself is not a heavyweight exporter. It ranks far behind provincial rivals and, Canada as a whole, in merchandise exports as a share of 2008 gross domestic product:
B.C.: 17 per cent
Alberta: 38 per cent
Ontario: 32 per cent
Quebec: 24 per cent
Canada: 30 per cent
PRODUCTIVITY
B.C. labour productivity growth, measured by real GDP per hour worked, has grown slowly in the past two decades. It is a tricky measure of the economy, in terms of how to boost it, but it is an important sign of a society's ability to create wealth:
B.C.: 0.7 per cent
Canada: 1.3 per cent
SMALL BUSINESSES
About half the jobs in B.C. are at small businesses, and small businesses contribute a higher percentage to the GDP than anywhere else in Canada. While the entrepreneurial nature of the economy is good, small businesses tend to have less capital spending than large enterprises.
B.C.: 26 per cent
Alberta: 20 per cent
Ontario: 21 per cent
Quebec: 24 per cent
Canada: 22 per cent
NEW GEAR
A driver of productivity is money spent on new machinery and equipment to get more, better work, done faster. This type of spending is often undertaken by large companies on new factories, for example. B.C. ranks behind Canada in terms of such investments as a percentage of GDP.
B.C.: 6.2 per cent
Canada: 7.3 per cent
Compiled by: David Ebner/Globe and Mail and Douglas Porter/BMO Nesbitt Burns
Sources: Statistics Canada, BC Stats, Centre for the Study of Living Standards, University of British Columbia

CRIME BOOKS

Author: Cannon, Margaret

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/crime-books/docview/382608304/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: Skip ahead lots of years. [Parker Harrison] has been paroled to a place called Whisper Ridge, a spectacular estate where a woman named Alexandra Sanabria ran a unique program to rehabilitate paroled killers. But Whisper Ridge never really got going because Sanabria and her husband disappeared one night. Twelve years later, Harrison wants [Lincoln Perry] to find out what happened.

Links: http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CRIME+BOOKS&amp;author=Cannon%2C+Margaret&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-05&amp;spage=F.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

http://gw2jh3xr2c.search.serialssolutions.com/directLink?&amp;atitle=CRIME+BOOKS&amp;author=Cannon%2C+Margaret&amp;issn=03190714&amp;title=The+Globe+and+Mail&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;date=2009-09-05&amp;spage=F.11&amp;id=doi:&amp;sid=ProQ_ss&amp;genre=article

Full text:   ALL THE DEAD VOICES
By Declan Hughes, Morrow, 311 pages, $30.50
Fans of the classic hardboiled mystery are a difficult group to satisfy. The style is often copied, but seldom do writers actually manage to combine great character-driven novels with iconic prose styling, terrific dialogue and a stellar sense of place.
Dubliner Declan Hughes delivers all that and more; this series is Raymond Chandler updated and polished to hardboiled perfection. Ed Loy once lived in L.A., but he's returned to his Irish roots. His Dublin is the city of the Celtic dream, with former IRA thugs transformed into pseudo-English gentry, where skinny new mothers huddle outside the maternity hospital sucking on cigarettes, while across town, thin rich wives head up charity drives and their husbands field race horses and ride the property-development roller-coaster.
Ed Loy, kitted out in his handmade linen suits, cashmere coats, Dax lace-ups, French cuffs and sterling links, is literally tailor-made to be the investigator of the hour, at £1,000 a day. He has two cases going. The first is to find the killer of a local soccer star, the brother of an old friend. The boy may have been a drug peddler or worse, but he died on Loy's watch, and Loy considers himself responsible to the family.
Then there's sexy little Anne Fogarty, whose father was murdered 15 years earlier, supposedly by her mother's lover but, Anne claims, really by one of three once-powerful IRA leaders, two of whom are now equally powerful heads of crime families and the third a leader of Dublin society. Old politics and new money make very strange bedfellows in the New Ireland.
Hughes weaves all the history, background and conflict into clear, elegant prose. This isn't a wordy novel with lots of filler, food and bad sex. Every paragraph matters, and the dialogue snaps, as Loy drifts from high Irish to Dublin drawl with wit and charm. This is the fourth novel in this fabulous series, and I've loved them all. You will too.
SKELETON HILL
By Peter Lovesey, Soho Press, 336 pages, $24
Peter Lovesey has more than two dozen great mysteries to his credit, including the excellent Sergeant Cribb series, the Bertie series, featuring King Edward VII, and the Hen Mallin novels. Skeleton Hill , his 10th novel with Inspector Peter Diamond, is absolutely one of this best of the batch. Lovesey's combination of wit, deduction and great characters is on display in a cunning mystery that would make Agatha Christie envious.
Skeleton Hill, just outside Bath, was the location of a small but important battle in the English Civil War. As such, it's the place for a re-enactment of the event. The story begins as two corpses decide to drift off for a quiet beer. After all, it's summer, those Cavalier uniforms (exact copies of the originals) are heavy and hot. Rupert and Dave introduce themselves, and then head off to a copse where Dave has hidden a six-pack of lager. They dig up the treasure, discovering that thieves have taken most of it, and in the process uncover a bone. It appears to be human, but they decide it's old and they rebury it. From this innocent act, a crime is born.
Lovesey's history, and his plots, are always impeccable, so we enjoy the twists of both as Diamond investigates what appears to be a clear case of local vigilantism. In Bath? Heaven forbid! This is a lovely, lively story with marvellous characters and lots of local colour. If you haven't discovered Lovesey and Diamond, this is a perfect place to begin.
VENGEANCE ROAD
By Rick Mofina, Mira, 396 pages, $8.99
Canadian author Rick Mofina started his writing career as a crime reporter. That experience always shows in his novels featuring crime reporters. These pros really research a story and that dash of realism gives his novels real punch. Vengeance Road , another tale of murder and the hunt, is one of Mofina's best yet.
The setting is Buffalo, N.Y., where reporter Jack Gannon is marooned. A few years ago, he almost won a Pulitzer. But now he's just a cog to keep the Buffalo Sentinel from dying. There's talk of layoffs. Times are hard and getting desperate. So Gannon waits by the police scanner hoping for a big story, and his ticket to the big time. When a body is discovered in the local park, Gannon follows the clues, uncovers information about the victim and discovers that the major suspect is a Buffalo cop. The story is red hot - and then it implodes.
Mofina keeps his focus solidly on Gannon, which allows him to keep on the trail as the murder morphs into a kidnapping and another murder. There are both clues and a chase, and it all works beautifully. This is a snappy little weekend novel for those last limpid days at the lake.
THE SILENT HOUR
By Michael Koryta, St. Martin's, 304 pages, $27.95
This is Koryta's fourth novel and the latest instalment in the Lincoln Perry series, for which Koryta received an Edgar nomination. The Silent Hour is every bit as good as Envy the Night and maybe even better.
The story begins with a strange confession of murder. Or is it a confession? In any event, Parker Harrison admits to a crime, enters a plea, has no trial and is sentenced to life in prison with possibility of parole.
Skip ahead lots of years. Harrison has been paroled to a place called Whisper Ridge, a spectacular estate where a woman named Alexandra Sanabria ran a unique program to rehabilitate paroled killers. But Whisper Ridge never really got going because Sanabria and her husband disappeared one night. Twelve years later, Harrison wants Lincoln Perry to find out what happened. Perry distrusts Harrison, but wonders: If Harrison had anything to do with Sanabria's disappearance, why would he want it investigated? So Perry sets aside his misgivings. At least until the bones of Sanabria's husband turn up, buried at Whisper Ridge.
Koryta is definitely one of the best of the new generation of U.S. mystery writers. If you haven't already discovered Lincoln Perry, The Silent Hour is a great place to start.
SWAP
By John McFetridge, ECW, 304 pages, $24.95
If you're interested in learning about the backside of Toronto the Good, Swap is a great place to begin. Drugs, guns, gangs and just plain nastiness hide in the suburbs, just outside the shiny city centre. For Vernard Get, a Detroit homeboy in search of lucrative partnerships, Toronto's biker gangs are a perfect fit. They deliver the dope, he delivers the guns. Of course, he's a bit mystified by bikers who ignore their Harleys in order to drive SUVs, but who cares about appearances?
While Get is planning his get, Toronto detectives Price and McKeon have a pair of dead bodies on their hands. The couple are Mr. and Mrs. Clean, not so much as a traffic ticket. Someone sailed by and shot them as their car headed up a freeway ramp. Who knows what company these nice family folk may have been keeping?
McFetridge has his difficulties keeping the plot moving, and some of the dialogue owes a bit to Quentin Tarantino, but this is a slick little story.

THIS WEEK / HIGHLIGHTS

https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/this-week-highlights/docview/382615159/se-2?accountid=14656

Abstract: HBO's first regular drama and most episodes in the series remain the TV equivalent of a punch in the gut. Set in the confines of the maximum-security unit of a New York state prison, the series drew glowing reviews for its stark storylines that likely discouraged many young viewers from pursuing a criminal career. Tonight's episode comes from the midway point of the show's first season.

Full text:   FRIDAY
SEPTEMBER 4
FOOD
Eat, Shrink and Be Merry
Food, 7:30 p.m.
Who says that eating healthy has to consist of green salads and tofu? Fun-loving Janet and Greta Podleski, creators of the bestselling Crazy Plates and Looneyspoons cookbooks, put a healthy spin on mealtime favourites such as burgers and lasagna in this lively food series. Tonight, the sisters take part in a small-town community supper where greasy fried chicken is the annual tradition. Always up for a challenge, the pair take on a local caterer with their own faux fried version.
COMEDY
Howie Do It
Showcase, 8 p.m.
Toronto comic and Deal or No Deal host Howie Mandel lets his imagination run wild in this hidden-camera series. First shown on NBC last season, the show takes the same tack as the old Candid Camera show of the fifties: Set up a prank, haul in a sucker, then let hidden cameras record the fun. In tonight's pilot episode, a man in a bunny costume is sent off to deliver a singing telegram - at a funeral. Howie also gets involved by playing a TV director of a mouthwash commercial and a waiter who likes to stick his fingers in the customer's food. Who says the golden age of comedy is dead?
DRAMA
Medium
CBS, CTV, 9 p.m.
Oscar-winner Anjelica Huston ( Prizzi's Honor ) returns to her role of no-nonsense private investigator Cynthia Keener in this chilling episode from last season. In the storyline, soccer-mom-psychic Allison (Patricia Arquette) seeks out the crusty detective when she begins having dreams that a kidnapping victim who Keener once rescued may be connected to the disappearance of a real-estate mogul's wife.
MOVIE
Take Me Home:
The John Denver Story
CMT, 10 p.m.
First broadcast on CBS in 1999, this TV-movie features a standout performance by Chad Lowe as the late folk-rock superstar. The film traces Denver's rocky relationship with his Air Force pilot father (Gerald McRaney) and his early struggles in the music industry. The story also depicts Denver's love for his first wife Annie (Kristin Davis of Sex and the City ), the inspiration of his single Annie's Song , and chronicles his battles with depression and alcohol in the eighties.
******
SATURDAY
SEPTEMBER 5
DOCUMENTARY
Lost Adventures
of Childhood
CTV, 7 p.m.
One of last season's best Canadian documentaries, this film from Scott Harper confirms the theory that putting children into regimented lockdown is adversely affecting the way kids learn and grow. Today's parents are overtaxing their offspring with far too many activities, whereas generations before were allowed to roam free-range. The stats make one wince: 41 per cent of U.S. kids claim to be stressed all the time; 70 per cent quit their designated sport by age 13, citing "burnout."
REALITY
Jon & Kate Plus 8
TLC, 8 p.m.
The very public lives of Jon and Kate Gosselin continue to fill the tabloids. The TV series that made the Gosselins famous is still running, and the current season was filmed right after the celebu-couple separated last spring. What with eight kids, they split the visiting duties: Kate takes the boys to a dude ranch and dresses them up in little cowboy boots and hats; Jon stays home with the girls for a princess dress-up followed by a scavenger hunt.
MOVIE
World Trade Center
CBC, 10 p.m.
Some critics felt it premature for Oliver Stone to release this film just five years after the events of Sept. 11, 2001, but the director of Platoon and Wall Street has always gone his own way. Stone frames his depiction of that horrible day on the true-life experience of two Port Authority policemen, played by Nicolas Cage and Michael Pena, who went into the World Trade Center following the collapse of the twin towers. Stone switches perspective between the rescuers and their anxious families, with scenes of the occasional survivor being pulled from the rubble.
COMEDY
Saturday Night Live
NBC, Global, 11:30 p.m.
A solid comic performance from film star Anne Hathaway made this one of SNL 's better outings last season. Broadcast before last fall's U.S. presidential election, the show opens with ex- SNL er Tina Fey reprising her portrayal of Sarah Palin. Even funnier is the sketch with Hathaway playing a slightly twisted Mary Poppins.
******
SUNDAY
SEPTEMBER 6
DOCUMENTARY
Martin Clunes:
A Man and his Dogs
TVO, 7 p.m.
British thespian Martin Clunes - best known for Doc Martin - displays his lifelong love of all things canine in this documentary. Clunes travels to Australia, Africa and the U.S. in search of the ancestors of his own pooches.
MOVIE
The Girl in the Café
TVO, 9 p.m.
The craggy film actor Bill Nighy delivers a masterful performance in this TV-movie first shown in 2005. The star of such films as Love Actually and Still Crazy plays Lawrence, a lonely middle-aged bureaucrat of high rank who happens to meet a much younger woman named Gina (Kelly Macdonald) in a cafe. Instantly smitten, Lawrence then makes the unwise decision to invite Gina to accompany him to the G8 Summit in Reykjavik, where she makes her own political leanings felt in no uncertain terms.
SCIENCE
Mythbusters
Discovery, 10 p.m.
Skip past the repeats for this new episode of the true-or-false reality series hosted by Jamie Hyneman and Adam Savage. Tonight's new episode finds the hirsute handymen looking at urban myths regarding prison escapes and jailbreaks. In this show, the science team test the likelihood of cutting through steel cell bars with dental floss and reopen the oft-repeated yarn about a prisoner who put his ball and chain in the prison cannon and fired himself to freedom. A story like that just has to be true, right?
DESIGN
My Big Amazing Renovation
HGTV, 10:30 p.m.
A pleasant alternative in the home-makeover genre, this series focuses on renovations of extreme scope. Tonight's episode focuses on a quaint waterfront home near Miami. Owners John and Alison bought the modest thirties-era domicile to accommodate their growing family, but now they want to make some changes. Their lofty plans include a luxury master suite, overhauling the kitchen and adding a new swimming pool and doc - and money seems to be no object. Let the reno games begin.
******
MONDAY
SEPTEMBER 7
BIOGRAPHY
Chuck Jones:
Memories of Childhood
TCM, 7:30 p.m.
This short and sweet documentary celebrates the accomplishments of animator Chuck Jones. Most famed for his contribution to Warner Bros. cartoons and his creation of the animated holiday special How the Grinch Stole Christmas , Jones took his creative muse from his own upbringing in Spokane, Wash., and Los Angeles. The program includes one of the last filmed interviews with Jones, who reveals the inspiration behind such animated characters as Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck.
COMEDY
How I Met Your Mother
CBS, 8 p.m.
Some people swear this is the funniest show on network television; others have never seen it. Those in the latter group might want to sample the sitcom about a group of aimless twentysomethings looking for love in all the wrong places. In the first of tonight's two episodes, the hapless single dude Ted (Josh Radnor) gets dizzy for a girl he just met, prompting his more cynical pals Barney (Neil Patrick Harris) and Marshall (Jason Segel) to teach him a cruel lesson via text message. In the second episode, Ted runs into an old flame and tells his future kids (the entire show is a flashback of sorts) about the importance of being in the right place at the right time.
HISTORY
History Detectives
PBS, 9 p.m.
Still airing new episodes, this PBS series has steadily improved over the summer and now rivals the Antiques Roadshow in terms of unique finds and curios. In this evening's first segment, art appraiser Elyse Luray examines a piece of abutment believed to have come from a famed Civil War-era bridge. Next, expert Gwendolyn Wright looks at a penny stamp connected to a landmark civil-rights case from the thirties. And lastly, sociology professor Tukufu Zuberi considers a set of metal sheets that appear to be the printing plates for jazz great Duke Ellington's classic song Take the 'A' Train.
DRAMA
CSI: Miami
CBS, CTV, 10 p.m.
This show might not be the strongest entry in the CSI franchise, but it sure has staying power. Tonight, humourless CSI boss Horatio (David Caruso) leads his team through the grim investigation of a man who was boiled alive. Simultaneously, Horatio has to deal with the emotional unravelling of his erratic ex-wife Julia (Elizabeth Berkley).
******
TUESDAY
SEPTEMBER 8
FOOD
Everyday Exotic
Food Network, 7:30 p.m.
Roger Mooking brings considerable life experience to this popular cooking series. A former musician and a third-generation restaurateur, Mooking took his formal culinary training at George Brown College and later ran the EPIC dining room at Toronto's Royal York Hotel. And unlike Michelin-ranked chef Gordon Ramsay, he's not a beast. Tonight, Chef Mooking prepares lemongrass snapper in yellow tomato sauce, accompanied by broccoli with crispy garlic and mini potatoes dressed in homemade ginger butter. Here's to the good life.
HISTORY
Cities of the Underworld
History, 8 p.m.
The eclectic history series begins its third season tonight, with Don Wildman returning as host. In the season opener, Wildman travels to the gambling mecca of Las Vegas, where he forgoes the blackjack tables in order to descend hundreds of feet under the pavement. Unbeknownst to gamblers and tourists, many casinos have located their surveillance and security operations underground. And from days of Vegas past, there's an endless labyrinth of tunnels dating back to Prohibition.
DRAMA
The Cleaner
A & E, 10 p.m.
The basic premise of this A & E original drama has worn a little thin in the second season - how many ways can "extreme interventionist" William Banks (Benjamin Bratt) deliver the same speech on sobriety? - but the show is still worth watching for the strong performances from its supporting players. Former Battlestar Galactica regular Grace Park, in particular, is most interesting as Banks's teammate, Akani. In tonight's new episode, a former client seeks out the Cleaner's expertise to save his drug-addicted girlfriend.
DRAMA
Oz
HBO Canada, 11 p.m.
Running from 1997 to 2003, Oz was HBO's first regular drama and most episodes in the series remain the TV equivalent of a punch in the gut. Set in the confines of the maximum-security unit of a New York state prison, the series drew glowing reviews for its stark storylines that likely discouraged many young viewers from pursuing a criminal career. Tonight's episode comes from the midway point of the show's first season. Enterprising inmates O'Reilly and Adebisi take advantage of their cafeteria positions to slowly kill the mob boss running the prison drug trade.
******
WEDNESDAY
SEPTEMBER 9
DESIGN
Stager Invasion
TLC, 7:30 p.m.
Since launching last June, this home-makeover series has become a sturdy ratings performer for TLC. Hosted by home stager Lisa Lynch, the series is no-frills TV personified: Find a slow-moving home, dress it up and watch buyers get in line. Lisa and her home-staging team are handed a near-insurmountable mission in tonight's new episode: The owner of a home in a buyer-friendly area is on the brink of foreclosure. The problem: For some reason, the owner applied a jungle theme to the house years before, which has prospective buyers running away.
REALITY
Pitchmen
Discovery, 8 p.m.
Watching this show has become an eerie experience. Filmed earlier this year, the docudrama-style series followed the efforts of TV pitchmen Anthony (Sully) Sullivan and Billy Mays to find new and exciting products to foist upon consumers in late-night infomercials. Mays died last June, presumably from a cocaine overdose, which casts a pall over the series. In any case, tonight the pitchmen meet with the European-born inventor of the Dual Saw - a regular circular saw that cuts in both directions at the same time - but they see more potential in the cleaning product called Shuffles, which is little more than fluffy slippers that double as dust mops. Operators are standing by.
DRAMA
Glee
Fox, Global, 9 p.m.
The next High School Musical has finally landed. Fox debuted Glee with a one-hour pilot last spring and has held off launching the series until tonight. The first show established the primary players: Ex-broadway star Matthew Morrison takes the central role of high-school teacher Mr. Schuester, who makes it a personal mission to resurrect McKinley High's foundering Glee Club. The singers are, of course, a cross-section of American youth - the jock, the cheerleader, the punk rocker et al. In the second episode, the Glee Club performs for the first time - to a mixed response. Expect an extended run for Glee .
DRAMA
Melrose Place
Global, 10 p.m.
There's more kitsch than class in this update of the popular nineties soap, but will viewers even notice? As on the first version, the story focuses on the complex professional and personal lives of an attractive group of twentysomethings in an L.A. apartment complex. In supposed homage, the complex is managed by Melrose original character Sydney Andrews (Laura Leighton). The remainder of the cast look like they came from the casting call for a Gap commercial. Also in keeping with the original, the first episode of the new show opens with a bloody body found floating in the building's pool. Some shows never change.
******
THURSDAY
SEPTEMBER 10
MOVIE
Some Girls
CHCH, 7 p.m.
Nearly two decades before Patrick Dempsey became famous as Dr. McDreamy on Grey's Anatomy , he was your typical male movie heartthrob. Dempsey and Jennifer Connelly are the reasons to watch this 1988 romance flick, plus there's a Canadian connection. Dempsey is in fine, randy form as Michael, a college student who agrees to visit girlfriend Gabriella (Connelly) and her family in Quebec during Christmas. Once there, he's beset by quirky Canucks: Gabriella's father is a writer who wanders around the house in the nude; her grandmother believes Michael is her dead husband and so forth. And the worst news: Gabriella wants to break up. Not the best teen romance, but Dempsey shows early promise (and more than a little of his posterior).
DRAMA
The Vampire Diaries
CTV, 8 p.m.
Launching tonight, this series from The CW, based on the novels by L.J. Smith, will likely find its audience among the same kids who made the movie Twilight one of last year's biggest hits. The pilot opens with the focal character Elena (Nina Dobrev) starting her first day at high school following the death of her parents. In between algebra and gym class, Elena meets the brooding new kid Stefan (Paul Wesley) and makes an immediate connection. What Elena does not know is that Stefan is a vampire who is fighting the urge to drink her blood. As they grow closer, Stefan's nasty brother Damon (Ian Somerhalder) arrives with plans to claim Elena for himself.
DOCUMENTARY
Rise Up: Canadian Pop Music in the Eighties
CBC, 9 p.m.
Where were you in '82? If you were into or part of the Canadian music scene, odds are you had big hair, bigger shoulder pads and knew all the words to The Safety Dance . The second part of CBC's documentary opus covers the era when the music changed dramatically: CDs replaced audio cassettes and synthesized digital music became the order of the day. More importantly, the eighties brought the arrival of the art form known as the music video, which begat the creation of MTV and MuchMusic.
DRAMA
90210
Global, 10 p.m.
OMG. The kids of 90210 are back for a second year. The first campaign of The CW's 90210 remake went largely unnoticed by most; if anything, the show was eclipsed by catty Internet gossip and tabloid reports about Canadian cast member Shenae Grimes. Expect more of the same this fall. In tonight's season opener, Naomi (AnnaLynne McCord) and Silver (Jessica Stroup) meet the son of a famous movie star, and an errant text message sours a relationship for Dixon (Tristan Wilds). Curiously, Grimes appears to have fallen out of the storyline altogether.
